section: + 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.1 Core Concept + 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.2 Station Order and Race Sequence
content:
Now I have comprehensive data from all the key sources. Let me compile the complete reference document.

---

# HYROX Complete Reference Document â€” AI Coach Knowledge Base

> **Sources cited throughout:** Official HYROX 25/26 Season Rulebook (hyrox.com), roxlyfe.com, hyroxdatalab.com, hybridfitnessmedia.com, pace-club.com, Brandt et al. (2025) published in *Frontiers in Physiology*, Men's Health UK, Concept2.com, fitnessexperiment.co, warriorperformancelab.com.

---

HYROX is an indoor mass-participation fitness race combining running and functional workout stations. It was co-founded by Christian Toetzke and designed by Mintra Tilly (Director of Sport). The format is standardised worldwide: **8 Ã— 1 km runs** alternating with **8 functional workout stations**, always performed in the same fixed order. Every racer â€” regardless of division â€” runs the same total distance of **8 km**. Divisions differ only in the weights, loads, and (historically) rep counts at the stations.

*(Source: Official HYROX 25/26 Singles Rulebook, Section 1 "Concept")*

The race always follows this exact sequence:

| Segment | Activity |
|---------|----------|
| Run 1 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 1** | SkiErg â€” 1,000 m |
| Run 2 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 2** | Sled Push â€” 50 m (4 Ã— 12.5 m) |
| Run 3 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 3** | Sled Pull â€” 50 m (4 Ã— 12.5 m) |
| Run 4 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 4** | Burpee Broad Jump â€” 80 m |
| Run 5 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 5** | Rowing â€” 1,000 m |
| Run 6 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 6** | Farmers Carry â€” 200 m |
| Run 7 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 7** | Sandbag Lunges â€” 100 m |
| Run 8 (1 km) | â†’ |
| **Station 8** | Wall Balls â€” 100 reps |
| **â†’ Finish Line** | |

*(Source: Official HYROX 25/26 Singles Rulebook, Section 4.1)*

section: 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.3 Complete Station Weights, Distances, and Reps by Division
content:
The following table contains the **exact** specifications from the official 2025/26 HYROX Rulebook. Note that Women's Pro and Men's Open share identical weights across all stations.

| Station | Distance / Reps | Women's Open | Women's Pro | Men's Open | Men's Pro |
|---------|----------------|-------------|------------|-----------|----------|
| **1. SkiErg** | 1,000 m | 1,000 m | 1,000 m | 1,000 m | 1,000 m |
| **2. Sled Push** | 4 Ã— 12.5 m (50 m) | **102 kg** incl. sled (~50 kg added) | **152 kg** incl. sled (~100 kg added) | **152 kg** incl. sled (~100 kg added) | **202 kg** incl. sled (~150 kg added) |
| **3. Sled Pull** | 4 Ã— 12.5 m (50 m) | **78 kg** incl. sled (~25 kg added) | **103 kg** incl. sled (~50 kg added) | **103 kg** incl. sled (~50 kg added) | **153 kg** incl. sled (~100 kg added) |
| **4. Burpee Broad Jump** | 80 m | 80 m | 80 m | 80 m | 80 m |
| **5. Rowing** | 1,000 m | 1,000 m | 1,000 m | 1,000 m | 1,000 m |
| **6. Farmers Carry** | 200 m | **2 Ã— 16 kg** (white) | **2 Ã— 24 kg** (grey) | **2 Ã— 24 kg** (grey) | **2 Ã— 32 kg** (black) |
| **7. Sandbag Lunges** | 100 m | **10 kg** (white) | **20 kg** (grey) | **20 kg** (grey) | **30 kg** (black) |
| **8. Wall Balls** | 100 reps | **4 kg / 9 lbs** (white) | **6 kg / 14 lbs** (grey) | **6 kg / 14 lbs** (grey) | **9 kg / 20 lbs** (black) |
| Wall Ball Target Height | â€” | **2.70 m** (9 ft) | **2.70 m** (9 ft) | **3.00 m** (10 ft) | **3.00 m** (10 ft) |

*(Source: Official HYROX 25/26 Singles Rulebook, Section 4.1 and Sections 9.1â€“9.8; confirmed by pace-club.com and roxlyfe.com)*

**Key note:** At the World Championships, all individual qualifiers in age groups U24â€“59 (regardless of whether they qualified in Open) must race with **Pro weights**. Only athletes aged 60+ retain Open weights at Worlds.

section: 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.4 Equipment Specifications + 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.5 Course Layout
content:
| Equipment | Brand/Model | Details |
|-----------|------------|---------|
| **SkiErg** | Concept2 SkiErg (with floor stand) | Damper preset to **Resistance 6** (racer may adjust). Weight ~21 kg (machine) + 16 kg (floor stand). |
| **Rowing Machine** | Concept2 RowErg (standard model) | Damper preset to **Resistance 6** (racer may adjust). Foot plates preset to **Position 4** (racer may adjust). Length 244 cm, weight 26 kg. |
| **Sleds** | HYROX-branded competition sleds | Sled base weight is approximately 52 kg (varies slightly). All stated weights are **inclusive of sled**. Lanes are 12.5 m long. Sled pull uses a rope. |
| **Kettlebells** | Competition kettlebells | Colour-coded: White = 16 kg, Grey = 24 kg, Black = 32 kg. |
| **Sandbags** | HYROX-branded sandbags | Colour-coded: White = 10 kg, Grey = 20 kg, Black = 30 kg. Carried on both shoulders. |
| **Wall Balls** | Medicine balls / Wall balls | Colour-coded: White = 4 kg (9 lbs), Grey = 6 kg (14 lbs), Black = 9 kg (20 lbs). Targets are mounted on a purpose-built wall ball rig. Some venues now use **digital wall ball targets** that auto-count reps. |
| **Warm-Up Area** | Concept2 BikeErg available | Plus other equipment for pre-race preparation. |

*(Sources: Concept2.com/hyrox, Official HYROX Rulebook 25/26, pace-club.com)*

HYROX events are held in **large indoor venues** (convention centres, exhibition halls, arenas). The course layout follows a consistent template across all global events:

- **Running Track:** An approximately 1 km loop laid out **around the perimeter** (outside edge) of the venue. Depending on venue size, each 1 km run may consist of 1â€“5 laps. A dividing line splits the track into a **Fast Lane** (inside, for racers at â‰¤4:00/km pace) and a **Running Lane** (outside, for all others).
- **Roxzone (Transition Zone):** The central area **inside** the running track. Athletes enter and exit the Roxzone through clearly marked **IN and OUT arches** along one side of the running track. The Roxzone typically adds approximately **800 m to 1 km** of additional movement distance across the full race (jogging/walking between the running track and the workout stations).
- **Workout Stations:** All 8 stations are set up **inside** the Roxzone, in the centre of the venue. They are arranged sequentially so athletes proceed through them in order.
- **Start Tunnel:** A designated tunnel/chute where athletes assemble before their wave start.
- **Finish Line:** Positioned after the Wall Ball station (Station 8). Athletes proceed from Wall Balls to a "Finisher Stage" and cross the finish line.
- **Spectator Areas:** Marked zones adjacent to the Roxzone where spectators can watch the workout stations.

*(Sources: Official HYROX Rulebook, fitnessexperiment.co course layout analysis, rox-coach.com Roxzone guide)*

section: 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.6 Wave Start System and Timing + 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.7 Transition Zone (Roxzone) Rules and Penalties
content:
HYROX uses a **wave start system** with waves departing at regular intervals, typically **every 10 minutes**. Key timing details:

- Each racer is assigned a specific start time communicated before race day and confirmed at check-in.
- The start time must be **written visibly on the racer's arm**.
- Starting in any wave other than the assigned one (without prior approval) results in **disqualification**.
- Racers within the same wave are always from the **same division** (e.g., all Men's Pro start together).
- A **timing chip** worn on the ankle records splits for each run, each Roxzone entry/exit, and each station completion. Doubles teams carry 2 chips; Relay teams carry 4.
- Racers must assemble in the **Start Zone Area** 10 minutes before their wave time.
- Wristband colour indicates division: White (Women's Open), Grey (Women's Pro / Men's Open), Black (Men's Pro), and/or Green (for specific identifiers).

*(Source: Official HYROX 25/26 Rulebook, Sections 8 and 12)*

| Rule | Detail | Penalty |
|------|--------|---------|
| Enter Roxzone via **IN arch** | Must use correct arch when coming off the running track | **2 min penalty** per infringement for using OUT arch to enter |
| Exit Roxzone via **OUT arch** | Must use correct arch when returning to running track | **2 min penalty** per infringement for using IN arch to exit |
| No outside assistance | No food, drink, or help from spectators/coaches in Roxzone | **3 min penalty** per infringement (classified as outside assistance) |
| Water provided at aid stations only | Fluids available at designated aid stations within Roxzone | Water is for **drinking only** â€” not for active cooling (pouring over body). 2 min penalty. |
| No littering | Paper cups and gel wrappers must be placed in bins | **2 min penalty** per infringement |
| No spitting / nose clearing on floor | Hygiene rule | **2 min penalty** per infringement |
| Chalk usage | Only event-provided chalk may be used, and **only at Sled Pull and Farmers Carry** | **2 min penalty** for using chalk at any other station |
| Shoes | Must be worn at all times except at Wall Balls, where they may be removed and placed under the rig. Must be carried to finisher stage after Wall Balls. | â€” |

*(Source: Official HYROX 25/26 Rulebook, Sections 8.1, 11, 13)*

section: 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.8 Doubles Format Differences
content:
HYROX Doubles is a **two-person team** format available in the following divisions:
- **Men's Doubles** (Open or Pro)
- **Women's Doubles** (Open or Pro)
- **Mixed Doubles** (Open only at regular events)

Key differences from Singles:

| Aspect | Singles | Doubles |
|--------|---------|---------|
| Running | Individual runs all 8 km | **Both partners run together** for all 8 Ã— 1 km. Must stay together (penalty for separation: 1 min per run/station, DQ after 3rd infringement). |
| Stations | Individual completes every station | Partners **split each station** however they choose (e.g., one does 60 wall balls, the other does 40). Only one partner works at a time; the other waits. |
| Sled distances | 4 Ã— 12.5 m | **8 Ã— 12.5 m** (doubled distance for most stations) |
| Burpee Broad Jump | 80 m | **160 m total** (split between partners) |
| Farmers Carry | 200 m | **400 m total** (split between partners) |
| Sandbag Lunges | 100 m | **200 m total** (split between partners) |
| SkiErg | 1,000 m | **2,000 m total** |
| Rowing | 1,000 m | **2,000 m total** |
| Wall Balls | 100 reps | **200 reps total** |
| Weights (Open) | As per Open singles table | Same Open weights |
| Weights (Pro) | As per Pro singles table | Same Pro weights |
| Mixed Doubles | N/A | Uses **Men's Open weights** for all stations (which equals Women's Pro weights). Women's target height (2.70 m) for wall balls. |

*(Sources: Official HYROX 25/26 Doubles Rulebook, warriorperformancelab.com, fitnessexperiment.co)*

section: 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.9 Relay Format + 1. HYROX Event Format â€” Complete Reference > 1.10 Recent Rule Changes for the 2025/26 Season
content:
The **Team Relay** is a 4-person event. Each team member completes **2 running segments and 2 workout stations**:
- Person 1: Run 1 â†’ SkiErg â†’ Run 2 â†’ Sled Push
- Person 2: Run 3 â†’ Sled Pull â†’ Run 4 â†’ Burpee Broad Jump
- Person 3: Run 5 â†’ Rowing â†’ Run 6 â†’ Farmers Carry
- Person 4: Run 7 â†’ Sandbag Lunges â†’ Run 8 â†’ Wall Balls

Available as Men's Relay, Women's Relay, and Mixed Relay. Uses Open weights.

| Change | Detail | Effective |
|--------|--------|-----------|
| **Women's Open Wall Balls: 75 â†’ 100 reps** | Women's Open and Women's Open Doubles now do **100 wall balls** (previously 75). All divisions now perform 100 reps uniformly. | September 2024 (Cape Town event onward) |
| **SkiErg / Rower damper preset** | Damper is now preset to **Resistance 6** for all divisions. Racers may still adjust it. Previously this was not standardised. | 2025/26 season |
| **Rower foot plates preset** | Foot plates preset to **Position 4**. Racers may adjust. | 2025/26 season |
| **Sled Pull: no stepping on front line** | Athletes must **not step on the solid white line** at the front of the Racer's Box while holding the rope. | 2025/26 season |
| **Burpee Broad Jump clarification** | Athletes are now explicitly **permitted to use a knee** when stepping up from the bottom burpee position. | 2025/26 season |
| **Distance penalties removed** | For sleds, BBJ, and sandbag lunges, there are **no more distance-based penalties**. Instead: 1 warning, then **15-second time penalty** per subsequent infringement. | 2025/26 season |
| **Farmers Carry wrong weight** | Must **redo the entire station** with correct weight. Failure to do so = DQ. | 2025/26 season |
| **Sandbag cannot be put down** | Sandbag must remain on both shoulders throughout. First infringement = **15-second penalty** (no warning). Second infringement = **DQ**. | 2025/26 season |
| **Spitting / nose clearing** | Now explicitly penalised: **2 min per infringement**. | 2025/26 season |
| **Active cooling prohibited** | Water at aid stations is **for drinking only**. Pouring over body = **2 min penalty**. | 2025/26 season |
| **Wave start DQ** | Starting in an incorrect wave = **automatic DQ** (previously unclear). | 2025/26 season |
| **Doubles separation limit** | If a doubles team receives more than **3 infringements** for being too far apart, they are **DQ'd** (previously unlimited warnings). | 2025/26 season |
| **Doubles age groups realigned** | Now structured in **5-year increments** to match Singles age groups. | June 2025 onward |
| **Pro divisions extended to 60-69** | 60-64 and 65-69 age groups now get official Pro rankings. However, WC qualification for 60+ remains in Open only. | 2025/26 season |
| **Digital wall ball targets** | Some venues now use **automatic digital rep counters** on wall ball rigs. | Rolling deployment |
| **Shoes rule** | Shoes can be removed only at Wall Balls. Must be placed under rig and carried to finisher stage. | 2025/26 season |

*(Sources: Official HYROX 25/26 Rulebook; roxlyfe.com 2025/26 rulebook analysis; roxlyfe.com world records page notation)*

---

section: 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.3 Race Time Breakdown: Where Is Time Spent?
content:
#### Scientific Data (Brandt et al., 2025 â€” Frontiers in Physiology)

A peer-reviewed study of 11 recreational HYROX athletes (median finish time 86.5 min, Individual Open Division) found:

| Component | Median Time | % of Total Race |
|-----------|-------------|-----------------|
| **Total Running (8 km)** | 51.2 min | **~59%** |
| **Total Stations (8 stations)** | 32.8 min | **~38%** |
| **Roxzone / Transitions** | ~3â€“7 min (included in above) | **~3â€“7%** |
| **Full Race** | 86.5 min | 100% |

**Key finding:** Running time was **significantly longer** than station time (p = 0.003). Running accounts for approximately **50â€“60%** of total race time across all ability levels, with the percentage being slightly higher for slower athletes (who degrade more on later runs).

#### Elite vs. Average Breakdown (Roxlyfe.com Analysis â€” Pro Division)

| Component | Elite Men (~59 min) | Average Men (~90 min) | Elite Women (~66 min) | Average Women (~90 min) |
|-----------|--------------------|-----------------------|----------------------|-----------------------|
| **Total Running** | 30:46 (52%) | 42:26 (48%) | 34:27 (52%) | 44:09 (49%) |
| **Total Stations** | 25:10 (43%) | 39:50 (45%) | 28:48 (43%) | 39:49 (44%) |
| **Roxzone** | 2:54 (5%) | 6:58 (8%) | 3:47 (6%) | 6:12 (7%) |
| **Total** | 58:50 | 89:14 | 66:22 | 90:11 |

*(Source: roxlyfe.com "From Average to Elite" analysis)*

**Critical insight:** Running takes roughly **50â€“55%** of total time for elites and **48â€“50%** for average athletes (since slower athletes lose proportionally more time at stations). The Roxzone is **5â€“6% for elites** but balloons to **7â€“8%** for average athletes.

#### Station Time Rankings (Which Stations Take Longest)

Based on data from hyroxdatalab.com (200,000+ results) and the roxlyfe.com elite analysis:

**For recreational athletes (finishing ~1:30â€“1:40), from longest to shortest station time:**

| Rank | Station | Typical Time (Men, ~1:40 bracket) | Typical Time (Women, ~1:40 bracket) |
|------|---------|----------------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| 1 | **Wall Balls** | 8:02 | 6:30 |
| 2 | **Sled Pull** | 6:31 | 6:36 |
| 3 | **Burpee Broad Jump** | 5:15 | 6:00+ |
| 4 | **Sandbag Lunges** | 5:22 | 5:25 |
| 5 | **Rowing** | 4:35 | 5:12 |
| 6 | **SkiErg** | 4:17 | 4:51 |
| 7 | **Sled Push** | 3:40 | 3:48 |
| 8 | **Farmers Carry** | 2:32 | 2:45 |

**For elite athletes (finishing ~55â€“60 min):**

| Rank | Station | Typical Time (Elite Men) | Typical Time (Elite Women) |
|------|---------|--------------------------|---------------------------|
| 1 | **Wall Balls** | 4:25 | 3:50 |
| 2 | **Rowing** | 3:58 | 4:29 |
| 3 | **SkiErg** | 3:47 | 4:12 |
| 4 | **Sled Pull** | 3:14 | 3:54 |
| 5 | **Sandbag Lunges** | 3:03 | 3:35 |
| 6 | **Sled Push** | 2:45 | 3:00 |
| 7 | **Burpee Broad Jump** | 2:21 | 3:11 |
| 8 | **Farmers Carry** | 1:37 | 1:57 |

*(Sources: roxlyfe.com "From Average to Elite"; hyroxdatalab.com station analysis)*

section: 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.4 The Biggest "Time Sinks" â€” Recreational vs. Elite
content:
The **variance analysis** from hyroxdatalab.com (comparing 1:20 "advanced" to 1:40 "recreational" brackets) reveals which stations create the largest time gaps:

| Station | Time Variance (Men) | Time Variance (Women) | Priority Level |
|---------|--------------------|-----------------------|----------------|
| **Wall Balls** | **2:26** | **2:02** | ðŸ”´ **HIGH** |
| **Roxzone (Total Transitions)** | **2:24** | **1:48** | ðŸ”´ **HIGH** |
| **Burpee Broad Jump** | **1:47** | **2:08** | ðŸ”´ **HIGH** |
| **Sandbag Lunges** | 1:27 | ~1:20 | ðŸŸ¡ MEDIUM |
| **Sled Pull** | 1:16 | ~1:10 | ðŸŸ¡ MEDIUM |
| **Sled Push** | 1:04 | ~0:50 | ðŸŸ¡ MEDIUM |
| **Rowing** | 0:28 | ~0:30 | ðŸŸ¢ LOW |
| **Farmers Carry** | 0:27 | ~0:25 | ðŸŸ¢ LOW |
| **SkiErg** | 0:23 | ~0:25 | ðŸŸ¢ LOW |

**Interpretation for coaches:**

- **Wall Balls** are the single biggest differentiator. A recreational male athlete averaging 8:02 vs. an advanced athlete at 5:36 â€” that's nearly **2.5 minutes** on one station alone. This is because wall balls demand sustained muscular endurance across 100 reps, and technique degrades rapidly under fatigue. A modest 20% improvement saves ~90 seconds.
- **Roxzone efficiency** is the "hidden" time sink. Elite athletes average **~28 seconds per transition** vs. ~52 seconds for recreational athletes. Over 8 transitions, that's **3:12 wasted** â€” with zero fitness required to improve it, just urgency and efficiency.
- **Burpee Broad Jumps** are the third-largest separator. They demand a unique combination of power, coordination, and cardio endurance that disproportionately punishes less fit athletes.
- **SkiErg, Rowing, and Farmers Carry** show the **smallest** variance. These are more "democratic" stations where technique and equipment constraints limit how much faster anyone can go. Focusing training time here yields diminishing returns.

The roxlyfe.com elite analysis shows an even more dramatic picture for the Sled Pull: elite men take 3:14 while average men take **6:31** â€” a ratio of 1:2, compared to a 1:1.3 ratio on Sled Push. The Sled Pull is disproportionately punishing for less-prepared athletes.

*(Sources: hyroxdatalab.com "Station Performance Analysis"; roxlyfe.com "From Average to Elite")*

section: 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.5 Performance Tiers â€” Detailed Breakdown (part 1/2)
content:
Based on data from hyroxdatalab.com (700,000+ results), roxlyfe.com, Men's Health UK, and the scientific literature.

#### Tier Overview Table (Men's Open / Women's Open)

| Tier | Men's Time | Women's Time | Percentile | Running Pace (avg/km) | Typical Profile |
|------|-----------|-------------|------------|----------------------|-----------------|
| **World Class** | < 55 min | < 58 min | Top 0.1% | 3:30â€“3:50/km | Full-time HYROX athletes, Elite 15 competitors |
| **Elite** | 55â€“75 min | 58â€“84 min | Top 10% | 4:00â€“4:50/km | Competitive hybrid athletes, age group podiums |
| **Advanced** | 1:15â€“1:25 | 1:26â€“1:38 | Top 10â€“25% | 4:50â€“5:15/km | Dedicated training 5â€“6Ã—/week, 2+ years HYROX experience |
| **Intermediate** | 1:25â€“1:40 | 1:38â€“1:54 | 25â€“50th % | 5:15â€“5:45/km | Consistent training 4â€“5Ã—/week, knows all stations |
| **Beginner** | 1:40â€“1:54 | 1:54â€“2:10 | 50â€“75th % | 5:45â€“6:30/km | First or second race, general fitness background |
| **Finisher** | 1:54+ | 2:10+ | 75th+ % | 6:30+/km | New to fitness racing, completion-focused |

*(Source: hyroxdatalab.com "What is a Good HYROX Time?")*

#### Tier 1: Sub-60 Minutes (World Class / Elite Pro)

- **Who:** Full-time HYROX athletes competing in the Elite 15 series. Names like Alexander Roncevic (53:15 Men's Pro), Joanna Wietrzyk (56:03 Women's Pro), Lauren Weeks, Hunter McIntyre.
- **Running pace:** 3:30â€“4:00/km average across all 8 runs. Remarkably consistent pacing â€” first km at ~3:24, last km at ~4:15 (men's elite). The pace degradation is minimal (~50 seconds from first to last km).
- **Station characteristics:**
  - SkiErg: 3:40â€“4:00
  - Sled Push: 2:30â€“3:00
  - Sled Pull: 3:00â€“3:30
  - Burpee Broad Jumps: 2:15â€“3:00
  - Rowing: 3:45â€“4:10
  - Farmers Carry: 1:30â€“1:50
  - Sandbag Lunges: 2:50â€“3:20
  - Wall Balls: 3:45â€“4:30
- **Roxzone:** Total ~2:30â€“3:30. Average per transition: **~20â€“25 seconds**. They treat Roxzone as running â€” zero standing still.
- **Fitness characteristics:** VOâ‚‚max likely 55â€“70+ mL/kg/min. Sub-35 min 10K runners. Capable of 150+ kg deadlift. 100 wall balls unbroken in under 4:30 in training. Compromised running ability is exceptional â€” can maintain 4:00/km pace immediately after heavy sled work.
- **Training:** 8â€“12 sessions/week. Periodised with specific HYROX simulation blocks. Race-specific pacing work. 60â€“80 km running per week.

#### Tier 2: 60â€“75 Minutes (Competitive / Strong Recreational)

- **Who:** Experienced HYROX racers (3+ races), competitive age group athletes, former runners or CrossFitters who've adapted well.
- **Running pace:** 4:15â€“5:00/km. Moderate pace degradation â€” typically lose ~1:00â€“1:30 from first to last km.
- **Station characteristics:**
  - SkiErg: 4:00â€“4:30
  - Sled Push: 3:00â€“3:30
  - Sled Pull: 3:30â€“4:45
  - Burpee Broad Jumps: 3:00â€“4:45
  - Rowing: 4:00â€“4:40
  - Farmers Carry: 1:45â€“2:10
  - Sandbag Lunges: 3:20â€“4:30
  - Wall Balls: 5:00â€“6:15
- **Roxzone:** Total ~4:00â€“5:30. Average per transition: ~30â€“40 seconds.
- **Fitness characteristics:** VOâ‚‚max approximately 48â€“58 mL/kg/min. 5K time of 19â€“22 min. Solid general strength (bodyweight back squat, 1.5Ã— bodyweight deadlift). Can complete 100 wall balls in 5â€“6 min fresh. Good but not elite compromised running.
- **Training:** 5â€“6 sessions/week. Blend of running (40â€“60 km/week), HYROX-specific station work 2â€“3Ã—/week, and strength training 2â€“3Ã—/week.

#### Tier 3: 75â€“90 Minutes (Solid Recreational)

section: 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.5 Performance Tiers â€” Detailed Breakdown (part 2/2)
content:
#### Tier 3: 75â€“90 Minutes (Solid Recreational)

- **Who:** Athletes with general fitness backgrounds. Often 2ndâ€“4th HYROX race. May have a running OR strength bias but not both.
- **Running pace:** 5:00â€“5:45/km. Significant pace degradation â€” runs 6, 7, and 8 are often 60â€“90 seconds slower than runs 1â€“2.
- **Station characteristics:**
  - SkiErg: 4:15â€“4:50
  - Sled Push: 3:20â€“4:00
  - Sled Pull: 4:30â€“6:00 (sled pull is often where strength-deficient athletes struggle badly)
  - Burpee Broad Jumps: 4:30â€“6:00
  - Rowing: 4:30â€“5:15
  - Farmers Carry: 2:00â€“2:30
  - Sandbag Lunges: 4:00â€“5:30
  - Wall Balls: 6:00â€“7:30
- **Roxzone:** Total ~5:30â€“7:30. Average per transition: ~40â€“55 seconds. Often includes conscious "rest" pauses, water stops, and mental resets.
- **Fitness characteristics:** VOâ‚‚max approximately 40â€“50 mL/kg/min. 5K time of 22â€“26 min. Moderate strength levels. Wall balls may require 3â€“5 rest breaks during the set. Compromised running is a weakness â€” HR doesn't settle between stations.
- **Training:** 3â€“5 sessions/week. General fitness with some HYROX-specific prep. Running 20â€“40 km/week.

#### Tier 4: 90+ Minutes (Beginner / Completion-Focused)

- **Who:** First-time HYROX racers, general fitness enthusiasts, those training for completion not competition.
- **Running pace:** 5:45â€“7:00+/km. Massive pace degradation is common. Run 1 may be 5:00/km but Run 8 can exceed 7:00/km. Walking intervals common in later runs.
- **Station characteristics:**
  - SkiErg: 4:45â€“5:30+
  - Sled Push: 3:45â€“5:00+ (may need to rest mid-push on heavy sleds)
  - Sled Pull: 5:30â€“8:00+ (this station can become a major bottleneck; athletes may need 7+ minutes)
  - Burpee Broad Jumps: 5:30â€“8:00+
  - Rowing: 4:45â€“5:45
  - Farmers Carry: 2:20â€“3:15+ (grip failures, need to put down kettlebells multiple times)
  - Sandbag Lunges: 5:00â€“7:00+
  - Wall Balls: 7:00â€“10:00+ (frequent rest breaks, technique deterioration, no-reps)
- **Roxzone:** Total ~7:00â€“12:00+. Average per transition: ~52â€“90 seconds. Extended rest periods, deliberate water breaks, mental regrouping.
- **Fitness characteristics:** VOâ‚‚max approximately 35â€“45 mL/kg/min. 5K time of 26â€“32+ min. Strength may be limited â€” sled push/pull and wall balls feel genuinely heavy. Heart rate remains very elevated (>85% HRmax for most of race). Blood lactate peaks at wall balls (the final station) â€” research shows RPE reaches 18/20 (Borg scale) during wall balls for recreational athletes.
- **Training:** 2â€“4 sessions/week of general fitness. Limited HYROX-specific preparation. First-timers often improve **15â€“25%** from first to second race simply through experience, pacing knowledge, and station familiarity.

*(Sources: hyroxdatalab.com tier analysis; roxlyfe.com pace breakdowns; Brandt et al. 2025 Frontiers in Physiology; Men's Health UK station time analysis)*

section: 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.6 Typical Progression Timeline + 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.7 Average Finish Times by Division + 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.8 Station Benchmark Times by Performance Level (Men / Women)
content:
Based on hyroxdatalab.com's progression data for a typical male athlete aged 30â€“34:

| Stage | Finish Time | Timeframe |
|-------|-------------|-----------|
| First race | ~1:55:00 (beginner) | Day 1 |
| 6 months later | ~1:40:00 (intermediate) | +6 months (~13% improvement) |
| 1 year later | ~1:25:00 (advanced) | +1 year (~15% improvement) |
| 2 years later | ~1:15:00 (elite) | +2 years (~12% improvement) |
| 3+ years | 1:10â€“1:14 | Peak elite performance, marginal gains |

Most athletes plateau after **3â€“5 years** unless they significantly alter their training approach.

| Division | Average Finish Time |
|----------|-------------------|
| Men's Pro | 1:22:24 |
| Men's Open | 1:26:42 |
| Women's Open | ~1:38:02 |
| All finishers (both genders) | ~1:35â€“1:40 (men), ~1:47â€“1:54 (women) |
| Median (50th percentile) Men | 1:33â€“1:38 |
| Median (50th percentile) Women | 1:47â€“1:52 |

*(Sources: Men's Health UK citing RoxHype data 2025; hyroxdatalab.com; roxlyfe.com)*

| Station | Elite (M / W) | Advanced (M / W) | Intermediate (M / W) | Recreational (M / W) |
|---------|---------------|-------------------|----------------------|-----------------------|
| SkiErg | 3:50 / 4:30 | 4:20 / 5:00 | 4:27 / 5:11 | 4:50+ / 5:30+ |
| Sled Push | 2:50 / 2:50 | 3:26 / 3:25 | 3:41 / 3:42 | 4:00+ / 4:00+ |
| Sled Pull | 3:50 / 4:15 | 4:37 / 4:59 | 5:06 / 5:34 | 6:00+ / 6:00+ |
| Burpee Broad Jump | 4:00 / 5:15 | 4:37 / 5:57 | 5:19 / 6:50 | 6:00+ / 7:30+ |
| Rowing | 4:00 / 4:45 | 4:33 / 5:11 | 4:44 / 5:24 | 5:00+ / 5:45+ |
| Farmers Carry | 1:45 / 2:00 | 1:59 / 2:15 | 2:10 / 2:25 | 2:30+ / 2:45+ |
| Lunges | 3:50 / 4:00 | 4:24 / 4:30 | 4:56 / 5:01 | 5:30+ / 5:30+ |
| Wall Balls | 5:30 / 5:20 | 6:04 / 5:53 | 7:01 / 6:51 | 8:00+ / 7:30+ |

*(Source: hyroxdatalab.com "What Is a Good HYROX Time?" benchmark tables)*

section: 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.9 Physiological Demands Summary
content:
From Brandt et al. (2025), the first peer-reviewed HYROX study:

| Metric | Value | Context |
|--------|-------|---------|
| HR max during race | 185 bpm (median) | Significantly higher during stations than runs |
| HR average during race | 170.9 bpm | Consistently hard to very hard intensity |
| % of race at "very hard" intensity (>90% HRmax) | 79.5% | Dominant intensity zone |
| % of race at "hard" intensity (70-90% HRmax) | 19.6% | â€” |
| Blood lactate max | 8.5 mmol/L | Peaked during wall balls (final station) |
| Blood lactate avg | 6.3 mmol/L | Sustained moderate-high lactate throughout |
| RPE max (Borg scale) | 18 / 20 | Highest at wall balls |
| Strongest performance predictor | VOâ‚‚max (Ï = -0.71) | Aerobic capacity is king |
| Second predictor | Body fat % (Ï = 0.67) | Lower body fat = faster time |
| Third predictor | Endurance training volume (Ï = -0.68) | More endurance training = better |
| Strength correlation | **Not significant** (p > 0.05) | HGS, muscle mass % did not correlate with total time |

**Key coaching implication:** HYROX is fundamentally an **endurance event** with strength components, not a strength event with running. The scientific data shows that once athletes have sufficient strength to handle the competition loads, further aerobic capacity development is the primary path to faster times. However, station-specific work remains critical for the high-variance stations (wall balls, burpee broad jumps, sled pull).

section: 2. Competitive Benchmarking > 2.10 Training Time Allocation Recommendation (Based on Data)
content:
The hyroxdatalab.com "70/30 Strategy" and roxlyfe.com analysis converge on the following evidence-based training allocation:

| Training Focus | Allocation | Rationale |
|---------------|------------|-----------|
| **Aerobic Base / Running** | 40â€“50% of total training | Running is 50â€“55% of race time. VOâ‚‚max is the #1 predictor. |
| **High-Variance Station Work** (Wall Balls, Burpee Broad Jumps, Sled Pull) | 25â€“30% of total training | These 3 stations + Roxzone account for **6â€“8 minutes** of potential time savings. |
| **Medium-Variance Station Work** (Sled Push, Sandbag Lunges) | 10â€“15% of total training | Moderate improvement opportunity (3â€“4 min savings). |
| **Low-Variance Station Work** (SkiErg, Rowing, Farmers Carry) | 5â€“10% of total training | Important for technique but limited time-saving leverage (1â€“2 min). |
| **Compromised Running Practice** | Embedded in above | Running immediately after station work is a critical HYROX-specific skill. |
| **Roxzone / Transition Practice** | Mental + habitual | "Free" time savings â€” requires urgency and efficiency, not fitness. Target <6.5% of total race time. |

*(Sources: hyroxdatalab.com "Station Performance Analysis" 70/30 strategy; roxlyfe.com coaching recommendations; Brandt et al. 2025 training implications)*

---

*This document was compiled from the Official HYROX 25/26 Season Rulebook (Singles and Doubles), roxlyfe.com world records and analysis articles, hyroxdatalab.com (200,000+ and 700,000+ result datasets), hybridfitnessmedia.com, pace-club.com weight references, Concept2.com equipment specifications, fitnessexperiment.co course layout analysis, warriorperformancelab.com doubles guide, Men's Health UK station time reporting, and Brandt et al. (2025) "Acute physiological responses and performance determinants in HyroxÂ©" published in Frontiers in Physiology (PMC11994925). All data current as of February 2026.*

---

section: 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.1 Optimal Pacing for the 1 km Run Segments (part 1/2)
content:
#### Should Athletes Negative Split, Even Split, or Positive Split?

The evidence overwhelmingly favours **even pacing** as the gold-standard approach for HYROX. Analysis from the 2022 HYROX World Championships in Las Vegas shows that the **top 5 Elite finishers ran significantly more consistent splits** than the rest of the Elite field, and far more consistent than average Pro division competitors finishing around the 85-minute mark (Rox Lyfe, "How to Pace Your Running at HYROX"). The top performers also showed a **6-second or less difference** between their fastest and slowest 1 km run times across runs 2â€“7 (HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

The three core strategies break down as follows:

| Strategy | Best For | Risk Level | Time Efficiency |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Negative Split** (start slow, finish fast) | First-time racers, cautious athletes | Low | Good â€” but leaves 1â€“3 min on the table |
| **Even Pacing** (consistent effort throughout) | Experienced athletes targeting a specific time | Moderate (requires discipline) | Optimal for most athletes |
| **Controlled Fast Start** (bank time early) | Elite/sub-1:15 men, sub-1:24 women | High | Fastest potential, but highest blow-up risk |

**Recommendation for most athletes:** Even pacing. Athletes who pace evenly (within 10% variance across runs) finish **5â€“10% faster** than those who sprint early and fade late (HyroxDataLab). The data is unambiguous: consistent pacing isn't about holding back â€” it's about distributing effort optimally.

#### How Does Pacing Change Across the 8 Runs?

A subtle adjustment is expected even in "even pacing" strategies because of **cumulative fatigue**. Expect runs 5â€“8 to be **10â€“20 seconds/km slower** than runs 1â€“2, which is physiologically normal and should be planned for rather than fought against (HyroxDataLab Pacing Calculator Guide).

Key nuances about specific run segments:

- **Run 1:** The first run is often shorter or longer than 1 km due to the start line being in a different place from the RoxZone exit. At the 2022 World Championships, **the top 5 Elite finishers went out relatively slower** on the first run compared to the rest of the Elite field, who in turn went out slower than the average Pro competitor. The athletes with the slowest overall times tended to go out the fastest on Run 1 (Rox Lyfe). Start 5â€“10 seconds/km slower than your target pace on Run 1.
- **Runs 2â€“4:** Settle into target pace. This is the "find your rhythm" zone. Resist the urge to speed up because you feel good â€” this is glycogen you'll desperately need later.
- **Runs 5â€“7:** The grind. Allow a natural 10â€“15 sec/km slowdown. Don't panic if your pace drops slightly â€” this is expected. What matters is **consistent effort**, not consistent pace.
- **Run 8:** The final run often feels longer because it includes extra distance to reach the wall ball station. Manage expectations accordingly. If you've paced well, you may have enough to push slightly harder here, but the priority is arriving at wall balls with enough in the tank for 75â€“100 reps.

#### Target Run Paces by Goal Finish Time

| Goal Finish Time | Avg Run Pace (per km) | Avg Station Time Budget (all 8) | Total RoxZone Budget |
|---|---|---|---|
| **2:00:00** (Beginner) | 6:15â€“6:30/km | ~52:00 (avg ~6:30/station) | ~11:00 |
| **1:45:00** (Intermediate-) | 5:30â€“5:45/km | ~44:00 (avg ~5:30/station) | ~10:00 |
| **1:30:00** (Intermediate+) | 5:00â€“5:25/km | ~37:00 (avg ~4:40/station) | ~9:00 |
| **1:15:00** (Advanced) | 4:30â€“4:45/km | ~29:00 (avg ~3:40/station) | ~7:00 |
| **1:10:00** (Elite) | 4:15â€“4:30/km | ~27:30 (avg ~3:25/station) | ~5:00 |

*Sources: HyroxDataLab Pacing Calculator, HyroxTrainingPlans.com, Rox Lyfe*

section: 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.1 Optimal Pacing for the 1 km Run Segments (part 2/2) + 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.2 Heart Rate Zone Management Across the Entire Race
content:
*Sources: HyroxDataLab Pacing Calculator, HyroxTrainingPlans.com, Rox Lyfe*

**How to determine your individual pace:** Run 1 km at approximately 85% of your max heart rate on a track. The time you record is a rough proxy for your per-km target at HYROX. Alternatively, your HYROX run pace will typically align with your **half-marathon or marathon pace** â€” not your 5K pace. Most athletes' HYROX run splits are significantly slower than their 10K race pace due to the accumulated fatigue from stations (Rox Lyfe).

---

#### Target HR Zones: Runs vs Stations vs Transitions

Heart rate management is critical because HYROX forces constant toggling between aerobic (running) and anaerobic (station) efforts over 60â€“150 minutes. One data point from Precision Hydration: an athlete completing HYROX in 70 minutes had an **average heart rate of 154 bpm â€” 96% of max HR**. That's the equivalent sustained effort of a half marathon.

| Race Phase | Target HR Zone | % Max HR | Perceived Effort |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Runs 1â€“3** | Zone 3 (High Aerobic) | 70â€“78% | Conversational to moderately hard; can speak in short sentences |
| **Runs 4â€“6** | Zone 3â€“4 (Tempo/Threshold) | 75â€“85% | Uncomfortable but controlled; sentences become difficult |
| **Runs 7â€“8** | Zone 4 (Threshold) | 80â€“88% | Hard; racing effort, fuelled by remaining reserves |
| **Stations (SkiErg, Row)** | Zone 4 (Threshold) | 80â€“88% | Controlled intensity, not maximal |
| **Stations (Sled Push/Pull)** | Zone 4â€“5 (Thresholdâ€“VO2max) | 85â€“92% | Near-max leg effort; expect HR spike |
| **Stations (Burpees, Lunges, Wall Balls)** | Zone 4 (Threshold) | 80â€“90% | Sustained muscular endurance |
| **Farmers Carry** | Zone 3â€“4 | 78â€“85% | Brisk walk; grip and posture challenge more than cardiovascular |
| **RoxZone Transitions** | Zone 2â€“3 (Recovery/Aerobic) | 65â€“75% | Active recovery; jog lightly, don't walk or stand still |

*Sources: HyroxTrainingPlans.com, Box Nutrition, Bend and Mend Physiotherapy*

#### How HR Drift Affects Pacing in the Second Half

**Cardiac drift** â€” the gradual upward creep of heart rate at the same pace â€” is inevitable over 60â€“150 minutes of sustained effort. As core temperature rises, plasma volume decreases (from sweating), and glycogen stores deplete, the heart must beat faster to deliver the same cardiac output.

Practical implications:
- **By run 5â€“6**, the same pace that kept you at 75% max HR in run 1 may now produce 82â€“85% max HR. This is normal.
- **Don't chase the same HR numbers** in the second half. Instead, shift to monitoring **perceived effort** and **pace**. If your pace is within 10â€“20 sec/km of your early splits and you feel "controlled hard," you're on track.
- **If HR exceeds 90â€“92% max for sustained periods** during runs in the second half, you need to slow down. Continuing at that intensity will cause a dramatic fade and potentially compromise your ability to complete stations.
- **Dehydration accelerates drift.** Every 1% loss in bodyweight from sweat can increase HR by 5â€“8 bpm. This is why hydration strategy matters enormously (see Section 2.4).

#### HR Ceiling to Avoid Early in the Race

The single most important HR rule for HYROX: **do not exceed 85% of max HR during the first three run segments**. Going above this threshold in the early stages depletes glycogen disproportionately fast, spikes lactate accumulation, and accelerates core temperature rise â€” all of which compound exponentially in the second half (HyroxTrainingPlans.com, Bend and Mend Physiotherapy).

Think of it as a **"spending budget."** The aerobic energy you save in runs 1â€“3 by staying at 70â€“78% max HR is the exact energy you'll need to maintain technique during wall balls and push through runs 7â€“8.

---

section: 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.3 Station-Specific Pacing (part 1/4)
content:
#### SkiErg (1,000 m)

The SkiErg is Station 1 â€” the very first functional exercise after Run 1. The temptation to blast it (fresh legs, adrenaline) is real, but the risk/reward is poor. Analysis shows the SkiErg has one of the **lowest time variances** across finish-time brackets â€” only about 22 seconds separating a 1:20 finisher from a 1:40 finisher (HyroxDataLab). Meaning: going 15 seconds faster here by redlining your effort costs far more energy than the time it saves.

| Metric | Beginner (2:00 goal) | Intermediate (1:30 goal) | Elite (1:10 goal) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Target /500m split | 2:45â€“3:00 | 2:05â€“2:15 | 1:50â€“1:55 |
| Stroke rate | 35â€“40 spm | 40â€“50 spm | 48â€“55 spm |
| Total station time | ~6:00 | ~4:30 | ~3:50 |

**Pacing breakdown:**
- **First 200 m:** 60â€“70% effort. Establish rhythm and breathing pattern. Do not sprint (RMR Training, Centr/Meg Jacobi).
- **Middle 600 m:** Lock into target pace. Maintain stroke rate at 45â€“55 spm. This should feel like your **5K running effort** â€” strong but controlled (RMR Training, James Hall).
- **Final 200 m:** Increase effort only if sustainable. Prepare mentally for the transition to Run 2.

**Key coaching cue:** "Sacrificing a few seconds on your overall ski time will yield a better run afterward â€” where there is more to gain. Risk to reward!" â€” Meg Jacobi, HYROX athlete (Centr).

**Technique note:** Drive power from the legs and core, not just the arms. Hinge at the hips, engage the lats, and pull through with full extension. Arm-dominant athletes will burn out their shoulders â€” which they need for sled pull, rowing, and wall balls later.

#### Sled Push (4 Ã— 12.5 m lengths)

The sled push is Station 2, and it is **where more races are lost than any other station**. At the 2023 North American Championships, many elite male competitors reportedly destroyed their race by going too fast on the sled push (Rox Lyfe). The problem is physics: once you stop the sled, static friction is **3â€“5 times greater** than kinetic friction, meaning restarting costs enormously more energy than keeping the sled crawling forward (HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

| Metric | Beginner (2:00 goal) | Intermediate (1:30 goal) | Elite (1:10 goal) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Total station time | ~5:00 | ~3:30 | ~2:30 |
| Strategy | Stop-and-go with 3â€“5 sec rests | Continuous with minor slow-downs | Continuous, aggressive |

**Continuous vs stop-and-go:**
- **Continuous (recommended for intermediate+):** Never let the sled fully stop. If you need to "rest," slow to a crawl but keep the sled moving. Even 1â€“2 inches per second of movement is better than zero. This avoids the massive energy cost of breaking static friction every time you restart.
- **Stop-and-go (acceptable for beginners):** If you must stop, keep rests to **3â€“5 seconds maximum** (Rezerv.co). Stop approximately **5 steps before your legs start burning** â€” lactic acid clearance is exponential, so the more you accumulate, the longer recovery takes (Women's Health/HYROX coach advice).

**Technique essentials:**
- Keep body low â€” 45-degree angle between torso and ground.
- Use short, choppy steps: **6â€“8 inch steps, 120+ steps per minute cadence** (HyroxTrainingPlans.com). Long strides create a stop-start pattern.
- First 3 steps of each length: MAX effort to break static friction.
- Breathe rhythmically: exhale every 2â€“3 steps.
- Arms: extended (for leverage) or slightly bent â€” experiment in training.

**Post-sled recovery:** Take 5 deep breaths with hands on knees. Shake out quads before transitioning. The run immediately after sled push (Run 3) is where you'll feel the worst. Expect it. Accept a 10â€“15 sec/km pace drop.

#### Sled Pull (Hand-Over-Hand)

section: 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.3 Station-Specific Pacing (part 2/4)
content:
#### Sled Pull (Hand-Over-Hand)

The sled pull is Station 3. It's less about brute strength and more about **minimising dead time between pulls**.

**Pacing strategy:**
- Run (don't walk) to the far end of the lane to set up.
- Sit or brace your feet, lean back, and begin pulling hand-over-hand with steady, rhythmic pulls.
- **Minimise rest between rope grabs.** Most time lost at sled pull is from athletes taking long pauses between pulls of the rope and walking slowly between lengths (Rox Lyfe).
- Keep a consistent rhythm: think of it like climbing a rope â€” one hand immediately follows the other.
- Once the sled reaches you, stand up quickly, run (don't walk) back to the start, and begin again.

| Metric | Beginner (2:00 goal) | Intermediate (1:30 goal) | Elite (1:10 goal) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Total station time | ~6:00 | ~4:00 | ~3:00 |

**Key coaching cue:** "Hustle on sled pull. You can push yourself a little more here without compromising yourself for the rest of the race" (Rox Lyfe). Chalk your hands beforehand â€” grip failure means dropped ropes and wasted time.

#### Burpee Broad Jumps (80 m)

Station 4. This is the most metabolically brutal station â€” it combines a full-body power movement (burpee) with explosive horizontal displacement (broad jump). The station typically takes **3â€“6 minutes** depending on fitness level (HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

**Rep tempo and pacing:**
- **Conservative pacing (recommended):** Start at 70â€“80% max intensity. Find a rhythm and maintain **consistent jump distance** throughout. Do NOT sprint the first 20m and limp the last 60m.
- **Target rep tempo:** Aim for one complete burpee broad jump every **3.5â€“5 seconds** depending on your level.
- **When to slow down vs push:** If your jump distance drops below ~1.2m (indicating muscular failure), slow your tempo slightly rather than attempting explosive jumps that cover no distance. Maintaining consistent distance per jump is more efficient than variable bursts.
- **Break strategy:** Unlike wall balls, burpee broad jumps don't lend themselves well to formal "break sets." Instead, maintain a steady rhythm. If you must pause, take **2â€“3 breaths standing** then resume â€” do NOT sit or lie down (George Anderson's "Get Out of the Chair" principle from Rox Lyfe).

**Key coaching cue:** "Avoid the burst-and-pause approach. Instead, find a steady pace you can maintain" (Women's Health).

#### Rowing (1,000 m)

Station 5. The row comes at the midpoint of the race, after the devastating burpee broad jumps. Your heart rate will be elevated; your goal is to use the rower as a **controlled reset**, not another sprint.

| Metric | Beginner (2:00 goal) | Intermediate (1:30 goal) | Elite (1:10 goal) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Target /500m split | 2:30â€“2:45 | 2:05â€“2:20 | 1:50â€“1:55 |
| Stroke rate | 22â€“26 spm | 24â€“28 spm | 26â€“30 spm |
| Total station time | ~6:00 | ~4:45 | ~3:50 |

**Pacing formula:** Your HYROX row pace should be approximately **your 2K rowing time trial pace + 10 seconds per 500m** (RMR Training/James Hall). This feels "strong but controlled" â€” not like you're hunting a PR.

**Technical emphasis:**
- **Power through the legs** (70% leg drive, 20% back, 10% arms). Arm-dominant rowing is inefficient and will fatigue your biceps and grip for farmers carry later.
- **Keep stroke rate steady at 24â€“28 spm.** Avoid fluctuations â€” each surge and recovery wastes energy.
- **Monitor the /500m split display** and aim for consistency from the first stroke to the last.

The rowing station, like the SkiErg, has **very low time variance** across finish-time brackets (~28 seconds; HyroxDataLab). Going 10 seconds faster by sprinting is not worth the energy it costs.

#### Farmers Carry (200 m)

section: 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.3 Station-Specific Pacing (part 3/4)
content:
#### Farmers Carry (200 m)

Station 6. This station is unique in that **you should go as fast as humanly possible** (Rox Lyfe, "Full Send Farmers"). Here's why: grip endurance is the limiting factor, and the longer you hold the kettlebells, the worse it gets. Speed reduces total time under load.

| Metric | Beginner (2:00 goal) | Intermediate (1:30 goal) | Elite (1:10 goal) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Total station time | ~4:00 | ~2:30 | ~1:10â€“1:30 |
| Pace | Brisk walk, 1â€“2 stops | Fast walk, 0â€“1 stops | Near-jog, unbroken |

**Walk pace:** Move at the fastest sustainable walk (or light jog) you can manage. Think "power walk" â€” upright posture, arms locked, short quick steps.

**Grip management:**
- **Chalk your hands** before starting â€” sweaty palms are the #1 cause of dropped kettlebells (Rox Lyfe).
- Maintain **tall posture**: shoulders packed, chest up, core braced. Dr. Adam Storey (HYROX Sports Science Advisory Council) classifies the farmers carry as a **"postural endurance test"** â€” the athlete who maintains upright posture the longest maintains their speed the longest (Rox Lyfe Farmers Carry Guide).
- **When to set down:** Only if you physically cannot hold on. Every stop costs ~5â€“10 seconds (setting down + shaking out + picking up + re-gripping). Aim for 0 stops if targeting sub-1:30, 0â€“1 stops if targeting sub-2:00.
- There is **no penalty for setting the kettlebells down** (unlike the sandbag in lunges), but every stop kills your time.

**Coaching cue:** "You don't really need much grip strength for the rest of the race. So going all out on the farmers is worthwhile." (Rox Lyfe).

#### Sandbag Lunges (100 m)

Station 7. Data from HyroxDataLab's analysis of HYROX Utrecht shows that sandbag lunges are a **high-leverage station** with massive time variance (87â€“88 seconds across finish-time brackets) but **near-zero correlation with Run 8 performance** (r = -0.084 for men, -0.072 for women). This demolishes the common "save legs for the final run" myth.

**Step tempo:**
- Target **0.9â€“1.1 m step length** (100â€“110 total steps for men, 110â€“120 for women).
- Longer steps shift load from quads â†’ glutes/hamstrings, which **preserves quads for wall balls** (the very next station, where correlation is strong: r = 0.738).
- **Constant movement** â€” touch-and-go on the back knee. Do not pause at the bottom of each rep.
- Step cadence: approximately one lunge every 2.5â€“3.5 seconds.

**Breathing pattern:** Exhale forcefully on the drive up (concentric phase), inhale at the bottom (eccentric phase). Keep breathing rhythmic and tied to movement.

| Metric | Beginner (2:00 goal) | Intermediate (1:30 goal) | Elite (1:10 goal) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Total station time | ~8:00 | ~5:00â€“5:30 | ~3:30â€“4:15 |
| Step count target | 130â€“150 | 100â€“120 | 90â€“105 |

**Coaching cue:** "Attack the sandbag lunges aggressively. The time you lose going slow hurts your finish time directly, while the theoretical fatigue you're avoiding doesn't materially impact your final run." (HyroxDataLab).

#### Wall Balls (75 reps women / 100 reps men)

Station 8 â€” the final functional station. You're exhausted, your quads are wrecked from lunges, and you have 75â€“100 reps between you and the finish line. **A break strategy is essential.**

**Break strategies:**

| Strategy | Reps Pattern | Rest Between Sets | Best For |
|---|---|---|---|
| Aggressive (Unbroken) | 100 straight | None | Elite athletes with exceptional fitness |
| Semi-Aggressive | 25-25-25-25 or 30-30-25-15 | 3â€“5 sec | Strong intermediate athletes |
| Conservative | 20-20-20-20-20 | 3â€“5 sec | Most athletes â€” **recommended** |
| Very Conservative | 15-15-15-15-15-10-15 | 5â€“8 sec | Beginners or athletes with poor upper body endurance |

section: 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.3 Station-Specific Pacing (part 4/4) + 1. Pacing Strategy for HYROX > 1.4 When to Push vs Conserve: Station Reward Analysis
content:
**Rep tempo:** Each wall ball rep should take approximately **2.5â€“3.5 seconds** (catch â†’ squat â†’ drive â†’ release â†’ catch). Find a metronome-like rhythm and lock in.

**Key coaching cue:** "If you start off by doing as many as you can (say you manage 40 unbroken) but that leaves your shoulders completely fried and massively slows you down for the remainder, then you didn't pace appropriately. It's possible you should have just done 25 and had a very short pause before carrying on." (Rox Lyfe).

**Technique under fatigue:** Keep feet planted, use **legs** (not arms/shoulders) to generate upward force. If the ball starts hitting below the target line, you're burning out â€” take a micro-break rather than accumulating no-reps from the judge.

---

Not all stations reward aggressive pacing equally. Based on data analysis from HyroxDataLab and coaching literature:

| Station | Variance Across Finish Brackets | Push or Conserve? | Reasoning |
|---|---|---|---|
| **SkiErg** | Low (22 sec) | **Conserve** â€” controlled, 70â€“80% effort | Minimal time gain from going harder; high energy cost |
| **Sled Push** | Moderate-High | **Conserve** â€” steady, never stop | Lactic acid from over-pushing destroys subsequent runs |
| **Sled Pull** | Moderate | **Moderate push** â€” hustle between pulls | Dead time (walking, resting) is the biggest time sink |
| **Burpee Broad Jumps** | High (107 sec) | **Steady push** â€” consistent tempo | Burst-and-pause approach is worse than sustained rhythm |
| **Rowing** | Low (28 sec) | **Conserve** â€” strong but controlled | Same as SkiErg; diminishing returns from extra effort |
| **Farmers Carry** | Low (26 sec) | **Full send** â€” go as fast as possible | Speed reduces time under load; grip doesn't matter after |
| **Sandbag Lunges** | High (87â€“88 sec) | **Attack aggressively** | Near-zero correlation with Run 8; huge time-gain opportunity |
| **Wall Balls** | Highest (146 sec) | **Controlled push** â€” smart break strategy | Highest variance = biggest training/execution payoff |

**Summary principle:** Conserve on the machines (SkiErg, Row) where extra effort yields minimal time savings but massive energy cost. Attack the high-variance bodyweight/loaded stations (lunges, wall balls, burpees) where execution and fitness translate directly into large time gains.

---

section: 2. Common Mistakes & Race Execution > 2.1 Most Common Training Mistakes in HYROX Preparation
content:
#### Neglecting Running Volume

HYROX is **50% running** (8 km total), yet many gym-goers disproportionately focus on station work. As Gymshark's HYROX training guide bluntly states: "Train like you are training for a half marathon, and as long as you can do the movements, you can't go wrong." If you can't comfortably run 8 km, no amount of sled push strength will save you (Gymshark, Connect the Watts).

**The fix:** Run 2â€“3 days per week minimum. Include one long easy run (Zone 2, 45â€“60 min), one tempo/threshold run (Zone 4, 20â€“30 min), and one interval session. Build to ~25â€“35 km/week if targeting sub-1:30 (Rox Lyfe, Connect the Watts).

#### Over-Focusing on Strength at the Expense of Endurance

HYROX is not a 1-rep max test. The sled weighs 152 kg (men) or 102 kg (women) and must be pushed repeatedly, not once. A massive squat won't help if you can't push the sled for 50 m without extended breaks (Connect the Watts).

**The fix:** Train **strength-endurance**: moderate loads, higher reps (12â€“20), shorter rest periods (60â€“90 sec). Use race-weight loads in training regularly. If you can deadlift 200 kg but can't push the race sled without stopping 6 times, your training is misaligned.

#### Not Practicing Transitions

The RoxZone (transition area) can account for **5â€“11 minutes** of total race time. Every second wasted walking, standing, or lingering at water stations adds up across 8 transitions. Many athletes unknowingly add 2â€“4 minutes by treating transitions as rest periods (Rox Lyfe, Connect the Watts).

**The fix:** In training, set up stations so you must run/walk briskly into them. Practice flowing from a run directly into station work without hesitation. Aim for RoxZone times of **under 1:00â€“1:15 per transition** for intermediate athletes and **under 45 seconds** for advanced (HyroxDataLab).

#### Not Doing Full Simulations

The standardised format of HYROX makes it tempting to simulate the full race frequently â€” but doing full simulations too often risks overtraining and injury. Conversely, **never** doing one means you won't know how station-to-station fatigue compounds (Rox Lyfe, 3in1Sports).

**The fix:** Complete **1â€“2 full HYROX simulations** (or scaled half-simulations) in the 6â€“8 weeks before your race. These should be at race pace. "A realistic HYROX plan is not just a thought experiment â€” it's a plan you *test*" (3in1Sports). Beyond that, train station-specific work in smaller, targeted blocks with progressive overload.

---

section: 2. Common Mistakes & Race Execution > 2.2 Most Common Race-Day Execution Errors
content:
#### Going Out Too Fast on Run 1

This is the **single most common mistake** in HYROX. Adrenaline, crowd energy, and 50 other athletes sprinting beside you create an irresistible urge to hammer the first kilometre. The data from the 2022 World Championships shows that **slower overall finishers went out relatively faster on Run 1**, while the fastest finishers were deliberately conservative at the start (Rox Lyfe).

**The fix:** Write your target Run 1 split on your wrist. Use a GPS watch with a lap timer. Trust the data, not the feeling. "Consistent pacing will almost certainly mean deliberately slowing yourself towards the start of the race. You will likely feel like you could be going faster â€” and many athletes around you *will* be going faster. This can be mentally challenging." (Rox Lyfe).

#### Poor Sled Technique Wasting Energy

Bad technique â€” high body angle, long strides, and full stops between lengths â€” can cost **60â€“120 seconds** and leave your quads destroyed for subsequent runs. Many athletes treat the sled push like a sprint rather than a sustained grind (Connect the Watts, HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

**The fix:** Keep body at a 45-degree angle, use short choppy steps (120+ cadence), and **never let the sled fully stop**. Static friction requires 3â€“5x more force to overcome than kinetic friction. Slow to a crawl if you must, but keep the sled moving (HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

#### Not Having a Wall Ball Break Strategy

Going for an unbroken set of 75â€“100 wall balls when you haven't trained for it leads to complete muscular failure around rep 35â€“45, followed by agonisingly long rests and a total time that's **worse** than if you'd planned breaks from the start (Rox Lyfe).

**The fix:** Determine your break strategy in training. For most athletes, **sets of 20â€“25 with 3â€“5 second rests** is optimal. Commit to this plan regardless of how you feel at the start of the station.

#### Ignoring Nutrition and Hydration

HYROX typically lasts 60â€“150 minutes at near-maximal sustained effort. Studies show that 40â€“50% of recreational athletes begin exercise in a **mildly dehydrated state** (Precision Hydration). Starting under-fuelled means glycogen depletion kicks in around Station 4â€“5, causing dramatic power output drops and cognitive decline.

**The fix:** See Section 2.4 below for a complete fuelling protocol.

---

section: 2. Common Mistakes & Race Execution > 2.3 Race-Day Nutrition and Hydration
content:
#### Pre-Race Meal Timing and Composition

| Timing | What to Eat | Quantity |
|---|---|---|
| **Day before** | Carb-loading: aim for 8 g carbs/kg bodyweight | E.g., 640 g carbs for an 80 kg athlete |
| **Night before** | Preload hydration: strong electrolyte drink (1500 mg sodium) + 500 ml water | 1 serving |
| **2â€“3 hours before** | High-carb, low-fibre, low-fat meal (toast, rice, porridge, bagel) | ~100â€“150 g carbs |
| **1â€“2 hours before** | Carb-rich snack (energy bar, rice cake, banana) | ~30â€“50 g carbs |
| **90 minutes before** | Electrolyte preload: 1500 mg sodium + 500 ml water | 1 serving |
| **20â€“30 minutes before** | Caffeine gel or chew (if tolerated; 3â€“6 mg/kg caffeine) | 1 gel (~30 g carbs) |

*Sources: Precision Hydration, AidStation/Ash Miller (Dietitian), StartHyrox*

**Critical rule:** Never try new nutrition on race day. Test everything â€” gels, electrolytes, pre-race meals â€” during training sessions first. Energy gels cause GI distress in some people, and discovering this mid-race is catastrophic (Rox Lyfe).

#### During-Race Fuelling

| Race Duration | Fuelling Protocol |
|---|---|
| **Under 75 min** | Pre-race fuelling should carry you through. Carry 1 gel for a mid-race boost if needed. Sip water at RoxZone stations. |
| **75 min â€“ 2 hours** | Aim for **30â€“60 g carbs per hour** via gels or chews. Take them during RoxZone transitions or less intense moments (e.g., after farmers carry). Carry a 500 ml soft flask with electrolytes. |
| **Over 2 hours** | Aim for **30â€“60 g carbs per hour.** Plan 2â€“3 gels across the race. Carry electrolyte flask. Take additional fluid at every water station. |

**Timing tip:** A good moment for a mid-race gel is **after Station 4 (burpee broad jumps), just before Run 5** â€” you're at the halfway point, and the carbohydrates will take ~20â€“30 minutes to hit your bloodstream, providing a boost precisely when the second-half grind begins (AidStation).

#### What to Consume at Water Stations

The RoxZone water stations are your only opportunity for mid-race hydration. Take **small sips** â€” 100â€“200 ml maximum â€” to manage thirst without causing sloshing or GI discomfort. If carrying a soft flask with electrolytes, take a larger sip from that. Do not stop moving while drinking. Walk briskly or jog while sipping (Precision Hydration, Rox Lyfe).

---

section: 2. Common Mistakes & Race Execution > 2.4 Warm-Up Protocols
content:
#### Timing

| Event | Timing |
|---|---|
| Arrive at venue | 60â€“90 minutes before wave start |
| Begin warm-up | 30â€“45 minutes before wave start |
| Complete warm-up | 5â€“10 minutes before wave start |
| Total warm-up duration | 12â€“20 minutes of active work |

*Sources: RMR Training, BLDRSports, DocLyss Fitness*

#### Specific Warm-Up Routine

**Phase 1: Aerobic Activation (7â€“10 minutes, starting ~45 min out)**
- Light jog, bike, or row at easy effort (Zone 1â€“2)
- Goal: raise core temperature, activate aerobic system
- Don't worry if you feel sluggish â€” pre-race jitters are normal (RMR Training)

**Phase 2: Intensity Ramp (5â€“8 minutes, starting ~30 min out)**
- Run 3 minutes at marathon pace
- 500 m SkiErg at target race pace (your 2K pace + 5â€“7 seconds)
- Or 3â€“4 rounds of: 1 min run + 1 min SkiErg/Row + 1 min bike (RMR Training)
- Goal: elevate HR to race-ready levels without depleting energy

**Phase 3: Mobility and Station-Specific Drills (5â€“10 minutes, starting ~15 min out)**
- Hip flexors and quads (running, lunges)
- Shoulders and lats (SkiErg, rowing, wall balls)
- Ankles and calves (running, jumping)
- Practice light reps: push sled 10 m, 3â€“5 burpee broad jumps, carry farmer handles 10â€“15 m, 5â€“10 wall balls
- Goal: coordination and confidence, not fatigue (RMR Training, BLDRSports)

**Phase 4: Final Priming (3â€“5 minutes, starting ~10 min out)**
- 2â€“3 Ã— 20â€“30 second race-pace pickups with walking recovery
- 4â€“6 Ã— 100 m strides at ~800 m pace (RMR Training)
- This primes the nervous system and makes Run 1 feel familiar
- Put on race shoes and test with a few strides

**Phase 5: Mental Reset (final 2â€“3 minutes)**
- Deep breathing exercises
- Visualise your first 3 stations
- Review pacing plan (written on wrist or arm)
- Find your mantra or focus word

*Sources: RMR Training, BLDRSports, DocLyss Fitness*

#### Common Warm-Up Mistakes

- **Skipping it entirely** â€” leaves you sluggish through Run 1 and SkiErg
- **Overdoing it** â€” a 30-minute high-intensity warm-up depletes energy you need for the race
- **Trying new movements** â€” the warm-up is for activation, not experimentation
- **Letting the warm-up dictate expectations** â€” how you feel warming up often does not predict race performance (RMR Training)

---

section: 2. Common Mistakes & Race Execution > 2.5 Mental Models Used by Top Competitors (part 1/2)
content:
#### "Station + Next Run = One Unit" Mindset

Rather than thinking of HYROX as 16 individual segments (8 runs + 8 stations), elite competitors chunk the race into **8 units**, each consisting of one station and the subsequent run. This reframing reduces the cognitive load of "16 things to get through" to "8 blocks, one at a time."

Within each unit, the station is the work and the run is the recovery. This prevents the demoralising feeling of finishing a brutal station only to face "another run." Instead, the run is part of the same block â€” your body's chance to flush lactate and reset before the next block begins.

#### Process Goals vs Outcome Goals

Top competitors focus on **process goals** during the race rather than outcome goals:

- âŒ Outcome goal: "I need to finish in 1:28"
- âœ… Process goal: "Hit 5:15 on this kilometre" or "Do 25 wall balls, then break"

Process goals keep you focused on the controllable present moment. Outcome goals create anxiety about the future and tempt you to make irrational mid-race decisions (like sprinting Run 3 to "bank time").

**Framework for setting race-day process goals:**
1. Write target splits for each segment on your wrist band
2. At the start of each segment, state your goal: "This run is 5:20"
3. At the end of each segment, assess: "Did I hit it? If not, what's the adjustment?"
4. Move on. Don't carry frustration from one segment to the next.

#### Self-Talk Strategies

George Anderson (well-being and performance coach featured on Rox Lyfe) recommends several self-talk frameworks:

- **"Get Out of the Chair":** When overwhelmed by what's ahead (80 m of burpee broad jumps, for example), don't think about the full distance. Just focus on doing the first rep. Then the next. "Get that first burpee done rather than dwelling on 80 metres of them." This short-term focus keeps you present and moving (Rox Lyfe/George Anderson).

- **"Embrace the Suck":** Reframe pain as a signal that you're giving 5â€“10% more, not that something is wrong. "Those feelings of pain and exertion can be quite unnerving if you aren't used to it. When you instead see them as signals that you're giving another 5â€“10%, and that it's not going to get any worse, and you just need to sustain this for a short period of time, that does something quite fundamental to your motivation." (George Anderson, Rox Lyfe).

- **"Through the Line":** Never ease up before a segment is complete. Always push through the finish of each station and each run. "Don't lose that last little bit of performance which could make it or break it." (George Anderson, Rox Lyfe).

- **Aggressive vs Passive Self-Talk:** Research on self-talk in endurance sport suggests that **instructional** ("Drive your knees") and **motivational** ("Let's go!") cues are more effective than reassuring cues ("I can do this"). Use commanding, action-oriented language.

#### Managing the Pain Cave in Runs 5â€“8

Runs 5 through 8 are where HYROX becomes a mental battle. Cumulative fatigue, glycogen depletion, and HR drift converge to make every step feel harder. Here's the mental framework used by top competitors:

1. **Break the remaining race into shrinking chunks:** After Run 5, you have "only 3 stations left." After Run 6, "only 2." This creates a sense of acceleration even as your body is decelerating.

2. **Use external focus:** Count laps, watch other athletes, engage with the crowd. Internal focus ("my legs hurt") amplifies perceived effort. External focus ("I need to pass that person ahead") reduces it.

section: 2. Common Mistakes & Race Execution > 2.5 Mental Models Used by Top Competitors (part 2/2) + Quick-Reference Race Day Checklist
content:
2. **Use external focus:** Count laps, watch other athletes, engage with the crowd. Internal focus ("my legs hurt") amplifies perceived effort. External focus ("I need to pass that person ahead") reduces it.

3. **Reframe the suffering:** As Liz Yelling (world-class distance runner) explained to George Anderson: "What sets the top performers apart is their willingness to suffer â€” their ability to embrace discomfort and simply endure more pain than others." The athletes around you are suffering equally. The question is: who keeps moving?

4. **Nutritional intervention:** If you haven't already taken your mid-race gel, Run 5 is the time. The psychological effect of "I just took fuel, I'll feel better in 10 minutes" is almost as powerful as the actual carbohydrate boost.

5. **Station countdown:** After every station in the second half, mentally cross it off. "Rowing is done. I will never row again today. Three to go." This is especially powerful after the farmers carry (Station 6), where you can remind yourself: "Only lunges and wall balls stand between me and the finish."

6. **Mantras:** Simple, repeatable phrases work best under extreme fatigue when complex thought breaks down. Examples used by competitors:
   - "Smooth is fast"
   - "One more"
   - "This is what I trained for"
   - "I don't stop"

---

### One Week Out
- [ ] Finalise goal time based on training simulations
- [ ] Build pacing plan with target splits for every segment
- [ ] Write splits on wrist band or race card
- [ ] Test all race-day nutrition (gels, electrolytes, pre-race meal)
- [ ] Begin taper â€” reduce training volume 30â€“40%

### Race Morning
- [ ] Consume high-carb, low-fibre meal 2â€“3 hours before start
- [ ] Preload with electrolytes (1500 mg sodium + 500 ml water) 90 min before
- [ ] Arrive 60â€“90 minutes early; check in, scout venue, locate bathrooms
- [ ] Begin warm-up 30â€“45 min before wave
- [ ] Consume caffeine gel 20â€“30 minutes before start
- [ ] Write target splits on arm/wrist

### During Race
- [ ] Run 1: Start 5â€“10 sec/km SLOWER than target pace
- [ ] Check pace every 500m on GPS watch
- [ ] Stay under 85% max HR for first 3 runs
- [ ] Conserve on SkiErg and Row â€” controlled effort
- [ ] Never let sled stop completely
- [ ] Chalk hands before sled pull and farmers carry
- [ ] Take gel after Station 4, before Run 5
- [ ] Full send on farmers carry â€” go as fast as possible
- [ ] Attack lunges with long steps (0.9â€“1.1 m)
- [ ] Execute wall ball break strategy â€” don't go unbroken unless trained for it
- [ ] Sprint through the finish line

### Post-Race
- [ ] High-carb + protein meal within 30â€“60 min (60â€“80 g carbs, 20â€“30 g protein)
- [ ] Rehydrate with electrolytes (not just water)
- [ ] Review splits: identify slowest 2 segments for future training focus
- [ ] Celebrate â€” you executed a plan

---

*Sources cited throughout this document: HyroxDataLab.com (Pacing Calculator Guide, Sandbag Lunges Strategy), RoxLyfe.com (multiple articles by the Rox Lyfe coaching team), HyroxTrainingPlans.com (5 Essential Pacing Tips), Precision Hydration (HYROX Fueling Guide), RMR Training (Warm-Up Guide), AidStation/Ash Miller (Nutrition Guide), Connect the Watts (10 Big Mistakes), George Anderson/Rox Lyfe (Mental Game), Centr/Meg Jacobi (SkiErg strategy), Rezerv.co (Beginner's Guide), Women's Health (HYROX Mistakes), 3in1Sports (Race Plan Tips), BLDRSports (Warm-Up Routine), Dr. Adam Storey/HYROX Sports Science Advisory Council (Farmers Carry), Gymshark (Training Guide), Bend and Mend Physiotherapy (HR Zones), Box Nutrition (Heart Rate Training), DocLyss Fitness (Warm-Up Reference), Ballinfit (Mental Toughness Strategies).*

---

section: + Station 1: SkiErg (1000m) + Station 1: SkiErg (1000m) > Optimal Technique
content:
Now I have comprehensive data. Let me compile the full document.

---

# HYROX Workout Stations: Complete Tactical Breakdown for AI Coach Knowledge Base

> **Purpose:** This document serves as the definitive tactical reference for an AI-powered Hyrox coach. It covers optimal technique, common mistakes, target times, muscle group impact, and training progressions for all eight workout stations. Data is sourced from Hyrox race analytics (700,000+ results via HyroxDataLab), coaching platforms (Rox Lyfe, TheProgrm, Hybrid Athlete Club, OnlyGains.ai), Centr (official Hyrox equipment provider), and elite athlete insights.

---

The SkiErg is the first functional station you encounter after your opening 1km run. It sets the tone for the entire race. Because it's Station 1, many athletes make the critical error of going out too hardâ€”burning through glycogen and spiking heart rate before seven more stations and seven more 1km runs remain.

The SkiErg stroke consists of two phases: **the pull** and **the recovery**.

**The Pull Phase:**
- **Initiate with your lats**, not your arms. Think about pulling your elbows down toward your hips rather than yanking the handles with your biceps (OnlyGains.ai).
- Simultaneously **hinge at the hips**, driving your weight slightly back. The hip hinge generates the majority of your powerâ€”your arms are merely transmitting force.
- Pull the handles down past your thighs in a smooth arc.
- Keep your core braced throughout to maintain power transfer from upper body to handles.

**The Recovery Phase:**
- Allow arms to rise naturally with the handles.
- Return to a standing position with controlled momentum.
- Don't rushâ€”let the flywheel do some work on the return.
- Reset at the top before initiating the next stroke.

**Breathing Rhythm:**
Adopt one breath cycle per stroke. Exhale forcefully on the pull (as you hinge down), inhale on the recovery (as you stand back up). Establish this pattern within the first 10 strokes and maintain it throughout. Holding your breath is one of the fastest ways to spike heart rate unnecessarily (OnlyGains.ai).

**Stroke Rate:**
Target approximately **30â€“35 strokes per minute** at race pace. Long, powerful strokes beat short, frantic ones. Quality over quantityâ€”each stroke should feel like a controlled, powerful movement rather than rapid arm-flailing.

section: Station 1: SkiErg (1000m) > Common Efficiency Mistakes and How to Fix Them + Station 1: SkiErg (1000m) > Target Times by Performance Level
content:
1. **Arms-first pulling:** Athletes yank the handles with biceps/shoulders instead of engaging lats and hip hinge. **Fix:** Cue "elbows to hips" and think of a deadlift motion. The arms connect; the hips power.

2. **Starting too fast:** Sprinting the first 200m at max effort and dying by 500m. **Fix:** Remember this is Station 1 of 8. Start at 70â€“75% effort and build. Target a negative splitâ€”faster second half than first (OnlyGains.ai).

3. **Standing too tall:** Not hinging at the hips, losing power from the core and posterior chain. **Fix:** Exaggerate the hip hinge. Your torso should reach roughly 45Â° of forward lean at the bottom of each stroke.

4. **Choppy, short strokes:** Rapid abbreviated pulls generating minimal power per stroke. **Fix:** Slow down, extend the range of motion, and aim for 30â€“35 SPM, not 45+.

5. **Holding your breath:** Causes early fatigue and heart rate spikes. **Fix:** Conscious, rhythmic breathingâ€”one breath cycle per stroke, established in the first few reps.

| Level | 1000m Time (Isolated) | Pace/500m | In-Race Estimate (+10â€“20%) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Elite (Pro Division) | Under 3:00 | Under 1:30 | 3:30â€“4:20 |
| Advanced | 3:00â€“3:30 | 1:30â€“1:45 | 3:30â€“4:15 |
| Intermediate | 3:30â€“4:15 | 1:45â€“2:07 | 4:15â€“5:00 |
| Beginner | 4:15â€“5:00 | 2:07â€“2:30 | 5:00â€“6:00 |
| First-Timer | 5:00+ | 2:30+ | 6:00+ |

*Data from OnlyGains.ai and competitive.fit. Elite male race averages: ~4:25; average male HYROX finisher: ~6:19 (competitive.fit). Elite Pro men have recorded sub-3:50 in race conditions. Rox Lyfe elite Pro data shows median of 3:47 for top-15 men.*

section: Station 1: SkiErg (1000m) > Pacing Strategy + Station 1: SkiErg (1000m) > Muscle Groups Taxed and Impact on Subsequent Run + Station 1: SkiErg (1000m) > Training Benchmarks and Drills + Station 2: Sled Push (4 Ã— 12.5m = 50m Total)
content:
- **0â€“300m (70â€“75% effort):** Let heart rate settle from the run. Splits around 1:55â€“2:05/500m.
- **300â€“700m (80â€“85% effort):** Find sustainable race rhythm. Splits around 1:50â€“2:00/500m.
- **700â€“1000m (90%+ effort):** Push knowing you're finishing soon. Splits around 1:45â€“1:55/500m.

Don't stare at the monitor constantlyâ€”check every 250m (OnlyGains.ai).

**Primary:** Latissimus dorsi, posterior deltoids, triceps, core (rectus abdominis, obliques), hip extensors (glutes, hamstrings).
**Secondary:** Forearm flexors (grip on handles), erector spinae.

**Carryover to Run 2:** The SkiErg primarily taxes the upper body and core, with moderate hip flexor/extensor fatigue from the hinge pattern. Most athletes find their legs relatively fresh for Run 2, but their heart rate and breathing can be elevated. The key is managing effort so cardiovascular stress doesn't tank your second run pace.

- **Pacing Practice:** 4 Ã— 500m SkiErg, 2 min rest. Goal: hit the same split (within 3 sec) on all four rounds.
- **Race Simulation:** 1km run â†’ 1000m SkiErg â†’ 1km run. Track transition times.
- **Endurance Builder:** 2000m SkiErg at conversational pace, every 500m do 10 push-ups.
- **Interval Power:** 8 Ã— 250m SkiErg, 1:1 work:rest, build speed each round (OnlyGains.ai).

---

The sled push is the first truly heavy strength station. Weights are significant: **Women Open 102kg, Men Open/Women Pro 152kg, Men Pro 202kg** (all including sled weight). The Hyrox competition carpet creates substantially more friction than typical gym floors, meaning the sled feels heavier than athletes expect. This station has one of the highest time variabilities and can easily cost several minutes if technique is poor.

section: Station 2: Sled Push (4 Ã— 12.5m = 50m Total) > Optimal Body Angle, Arm Position, Foot Placement, and Driving Technique + Station 2: Sled Push (4 Ã— 12.5m = 50m Total) > Continuous Push vs. Reset Between Lengths
content:
**Body Angle:** Achieve a **45-degree lean** with hips below shoulders. This creates a horizontal force vector, pushing the sled forward rather than down into the carpet. When you stand too tall, gravity works against youâ€”you push down into the floor, creating more friction (HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

**Arm Position:** Elbows bent at **90â€“120 degrees**. Arms act as connectors, not pushers. Your legs generate 4Ã— more power than your shoulders. Straight, locked-out arms force deltoids and triceps to engage heavilyâ€”they fatigue fast. Bent arms transmit leg power to the sled (HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

**Hand Position:** Hands shoulder-width apart, firm grip but not a death grip (save forearm energy for sled pull and later stations).

**Foot Placement:** Take **rapid 6â€“8 inch steps** maintaining 120+ steps per minute cadence. Long strides create a stop-start patternâ€”you decelerate between steps. Short, rapid steps maintain constant forward pressure (HyroxTrainingPlans.com).

**Starting Position:** Set your position BEFORE the first pushâ€”already at 45Â° angle, hands placed, core braced. The first 3 steps are the hardest (breaking static friction). Starting from standing wastes the crucial first push.

**Head Position:** Neutral, eyes 6 feet ahead on the ground. Don't look upâ€”it pulls you into an upright position.

The 50m is split into 4 Ã— 12.5m legs with turns. At the turn, you must reposition. **Elite athletes minimize time at turns** by maintaining sled contact and immediately resetting body angle. The sled stops at each turn regardless, so the key is minimizing the time between the sled stopping and your next push beginning. Pre-set your body angle before driving again. Don't stand up fully at the turnsâ€”stay low, reposition your feet, and go.

section: Station 2: Sled Push (4 Ã— 12.5m = 50m Total) > Common Mistakes + Station 2: Sled Push (4 Ã— 12.5m = 50m Total) > Target Times by Performance Level + Station 2: Sled Push (4 Ã— 12.5m = 50m Total) > Muscle Groups Taxed and Carryover to Next Run
content:
