Times should be treated as rangesâ€”individual performance varies by age, body composition, training history, venue conditions (carpet friction, temperature, altitude), and race-day factors. Always train at race-specific weights and conditions where possible.*

---

section: Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" + Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" > 1. Training Philosophy & Identity
content:
**Bio snapshot:** 6'2", ~205 lb (93 kg). Three-time Hyrox World Champion. Six-time OCR World Champion. Murph world record holder (34:13). Former Broken Skull Challenge winner. CrossFit Games wildcard competitor (61st place, 2019). Hyrox world record of 53:22. Founder of HAOS Training (Hunter's Academy of Strength). Based between Malibu, CA and Boulder, CO.

---

Hunter McIntyre's core training philosophy is rooted in **consistency, progressive overload, and brutally high volume.** He has described himself as someone who treats competition "like war" with "tactics, strategy, mental warfare, physical warfare, guerrilla tactics" (*The Fastest Man in Fitness Podcast, EP.02*). His approach is unapologetically old-school and contrarian.

McIntyre's three foundational principles of training progression:
1. **Increase strength and position** â€” progressive overload with heavier loads.
2. **Increase speed and position** â€” faster reps at higher resistance.
3. **Increase endurance and position** â€” add more volume over time.

*(Source: BarBend interview, 2023)*

He writes his own programming and has done so for most of his career, though he has periodically hired coaches when his schedule becomes too busy: "I recently hired a coach because I'm so busy I don't want to think" (*Men's Health UK, 2022*). He also programs for his HAOS Training app, which serves athletes across all Hyrox tiers.

What makes McIntyre unique is his **hybrid lumberjack-athlete identity.** His foundation was literally built chopping trees during a substance-abuse rehab program after high school: "The necessity of the job turned me from a boy into a man, physically, mentally, and emotionally" (*Hook and Barrel*). He still incorporates wood chopping, stone lifting, and tire flipping into his training regimen.

He has stated: "Just get used to running an hour straight. It's an endurance event. I hold the world record, and I'm fucking running my ass off the whole time" (*Men's Health UK*). He believes Hyrox is "almost all legs" and recommends heavy squatting, wall balls, box step-ups, and lunges at least three days per week.

---

section: Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" > 2. Weekly Training Structure
content:
McIntyre describes a "great week" (when not traveling) as **six hours in the gym and 10â€“14 hours of cardio** (*Men's Health UK, 2022*). His HAOS HYROX PRO program prescribes:

| Parameter | Details |
|---|---|
| **Training days/week** | 6 |
| **Sessions per day** | 1â€“2 |
| **Session duration** | 45â€“180 minutes |
| **Weekly time commitment** | 5â€“10 hours (program); up to 16â€“20 hours (his personal training) |
| **Cycle structure** | 3 weeks intensity build â†’ 1 week recovery/deload |
| **Endurance sessions** | Can last up to 3 hours |

**Sample HAOS PRO Weekly Split:**

| Day | Focus |
|---|---|
| Monday | Heavy Strength + Short Conditioning (deadlift variations, pull-up progressions, 20-minute EMOM) |
| Tuesday | Running Focus + Accessories (interval running, sled work, core strengthening) |
| Wednesday | Full Body Power (Olympic lift variations, plyometric training, conditioning circuit) |
| Thursday | Hyrox Simulation (race-specific workout, transition practice, time trials) |
| Friday | Strength Endurance (high-rep strength work, muscular endurance, fatigue management) |
| Saturday | Long Conditioning (extended aerobic work, movement quality, recovery focus) |

*(Source: HAOS Training / hyroxtrainingplans.com)*

His personal training always includes **at least one upper body intensity day, one lower body intensity day, and one dedicated track day** every week (*BarBend interview*). He splits training between Boulder, CO (altitude training near the Flat Irons) and Malibu/Big Bear, CA.

---

section: Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" > 3. Session Design Patterns
content:
McIntyre favors **EMOMs, AMRAPs, and interval-based formats** for conditioning work. He combines these with traditional heavy lifting.

**Documented workout examples:**

**Hyrox Simulation Workout (filmed in NYC, 2025):**
- 18-minute EMOM: Sled push + TRX rows, alternating between 2-minute hard efforts with 1-minute rest or continuous flow.
- Then: 5 rounds of 20-calorie row + 20 burpees, aiming for each round to fit within ~1 minute of work.

*(Source: "HYROX Training with 3X World Champion Hunter McIntyre in NYC," YouTube, 2025)*

**Training Camp Workout (Episode 6, YouTube, 2024):**
- 20â€“25 minute AMRAP: 25 TRX rows â†’ sled pull â†’ 30 shoulder presses, with 10â€“15 minute active recovery on the bike between sets. Athletes choose shoulder press weight where they can hit 20 unbroken.

**The "Lumberjack Workout" (Hook and Barrel):**
- 10 minutes of wood chopping
- 5 minutes of heavy stump moving (pushing and pulling stumps)
- 5 rounds of max-effort tire slam intervals: 30 seconds work / 30 seconds rest
- 3â€“5 Ã— 200-foot steep hill climbs carrying a 50â€“100 lb log

**The 20-Rep Squat Protocol:**
McIntyre sells an 8-week "20 Rep Squat Strength Guide" through HAOS Training, described as "formulated by Hunter McIntyre on his mission to win world titles." The protocol: pick a weight you think you'd be lucky to get 10 reps with, then don't stop until you've done 20 (*Men's Health UK*). This full-body plan is designed to "boost your strength and stamina through a 20-rep cycle."

**Cold Bar Technique for Grip Strength:**
McIntyre performs feats of athleticism and strength **without warming up** â€” a deliberately shocking stimulus. Examples include:
- "He-Man Challenge": 15 pull-ups cold with a 50 lb weight vest
- 17 pull-ups on a fingerboard (fingers in grip holes)
- 120-meter sandbag sprint in under 20 seconds

*(Source: BarBend interview)*

**Cycling Endurance:**
He rides "Magnus the Mountain Slayer," a single-speed bike, for 2+ hours. Because it's single-speed, if he stops pedaling he falls off, building what he calls "almost unstoppable physical and mental capacity" (*Men's Health UK*).

---

section: Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" > 4. Hyrox-Specific Preparation + Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" > 5. Periodization & Peaking
content:
McIntyre approaches Hyrox station training through his HAOS PRO program which includes specific skill blocks for:
- **Sled push/pull mechanics** â€” drilled on Tuesday sessions with interval-based sled work
- **Burpee broad jump efficiency** â€” practiced for movement economy
- **Wall ball technique** â€” endurance protocols (e.g., 100 wall balls for time, then building 5-minute leg endurance sets to match)
- **Sandbag carry variations** â€” including the 120-meter sandbag sprint

His advice for station preparation is practical: "Test one of the workouts, like 100 wall balls for time: if it takes you five minutes, you should be doing something on your legs that's five minutes straight. It's not rocket science" (*Men's Health UK*).

Thursday in his HAOS PRO program is dedicated to **Hyrox Simulation** â€” race-specific workouts with transition practice and time trials. The program explicitly includes "race simulation" phases in weeks 5â€“8 of each training block.

---

McIntyre's periodization philosophy is blunt: "Just periodisation, man" (*Men's Health UK*). He alternates **endurance blocks with strength blocks**, fully focusing on each in turn rather than trying to train everything simultaneously.

**HAOS PRO Periodization:**

| Phase | Weeks | Focus |
|---|---|---|
| Phase 1: Base Building | 1â€“4 | Aerobic capacity, strength foundation, movement quality, work capacity |
| Phase 2: Intensity Development | 5â€“8 | Lactate threshold, power development, skill refinement, race simulation |
| Phase 3: Peak Performance | 9â€“12 | Competition preparation, tapering protocols, mental preparation, performance optimization |

Within each phase, the micro-cycle follows a **3 weeks on / 1 week deload** pattern.

His diet is also periodized: "My diet is periodised, so I just got off a week of drinking as much as I could and eating ice cream" (post-season). As he gets further into competition season, "I start cutting out the rib-eye steak. You go towards the leaner cut of meat, or you go to fish and chicken" (*Men's Health UK, 2025*).

---

section: Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" > 6. Recovery & Lifestyle + Hunter McIntyre â€” "The Sheriff," "King of Hyrox" > 7. Unique/Differentiating Methods
content:
**Sleep:** McIntyre is notably unconventional here. He describes himself as "not much of a sleeper," routinely waking at 4 AM regardless of bedtime â€” whether he goes to bed at 8 PM or midnight (*BarBend interview*). This is an outlier among elite athletes.

**Nutrition:** McIntyre's diet is perhaps the most controversial aspect of his regimen:
- **Daily calorie intake:** 4,500â€“5,500 calories
- **Macros:** ~90g fat, 400â€“600g carbs, 180â€“250g protein
- **Staple foods:** Steak (2â€“3 per day), chicken, yogurt, maple syrup, honey, fruit, bread, pasta, oatmeal, sweet potatoes, Honey Nut Cheerios, ramen noodles, sticky buns
- **No vegetables.** He has stated: "You can't pay me to eat vegetablesâ€¦ Superheroes aren't made of vegetables, they're made of calories" (*Men's Health UK*). He claims this view was reinforced by sports nutritionist Dr. John Ivey.
- **300â€“500g of sugar per day:** "Sugar's the shit, I love that stuff" (*BarBend*)
- **Morning ritual:** Strong Coffee (with collagen), BLDR aminos, 3 tablespoons of honey

**Supplements:** He owns his own supplement company, **BLDR Sports**, and takes amino acids daily. He also takes collagen via his coffee brand.

**Post-season recovery:** He takes a deliberate period of debauchery: "I just got off a week of drinking as much as I could and eating ice cream" before ramping strength training back up (*Men's Health UK, 2025*).

---

**The Alter Ego / "The Sheriff":** McIntyre uses an alter ego in competition â€” "The Sheriff." He explains: "You need an alter ego that comes out when necessary" (*Men's Health UK*). He self-talks by "relentlessly bad-mouthing himself, repeating only two or three words so he doesn't get distracted." This deliberate mental warfare extends to intimidating opponents: "I treat this like war. I have tactics, I have strategy, I have mental warfare, I have physical warfare, I'll use guerrilla tactics" (*HYROX podcast appearance, 2021*).

**The Cold Bar Technique:** Performing heavy strength feats without any warm-up â€” lifting 250 lb stones cold, weighted pull-ups cold â€” as a grip and neural preparedness tool. No other Hyrox athletes publicly train this way.

**The Lumberjack Workout:** No other elite Hyrox competitor integrates wood chopping, stump moving, and log carries as formal training modalities.

**Single-Speed Cycling:** The "Magnus the Mountain Slayer" bike forces continuous pedaling with no ability to coast, building mental toughness and sustained power output for hours at a time.

**Anti-Vegetable, Pro-Sugar Diet:** At 300â€“500g of sugar per day with zero vegetable intake, McIntyre's nutrition is arguably the most extreme departure from conventional sports nutrition in elite fitness.

**Pull-Up Contests with Naked Penalties:** He describes having athletes in his training group compete in pull-up contests where "the loser has to run around the neighborhood naked" â€” a psychological intensity tool (*BarBend interview*).

---

---

section: Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist + Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist > 1. Training Philosophy & Identity
content:
**Bio snapshot:** Age 26. Hyrox Men's Doubles World Champion (2024, with Marc Dean). Hyrox Master Trainer. Red Bullâ€“sponsored athlete. Former ultramarathon runner (100 km at age 19, 7 marathons in 7 days, 10 marathons in 5 days). Age group world record holder (57:09). Recovered from two slipped discs. Currently pursuing solo Elite 15 World Championship qualification. Sub-2:30 marathon goal.

---

Jake Dearden's core philosophy can be distilled into one quote: **"Train as much as you can recover from."** He told *Men's Health*: "My job at the moment is to train and become the best at Hyrox. If you're looking at my training and thinking, 'I need to do that amount,' but you've got a full-time job, you've got family and you're only sleeping four hours a night because you've got little kids, it's just not going to work."

Dearden describes himself as "quite boring" with his training. He favors **repeating the same movements week in, week out** so he can track progress objectively. He's deeply analytical and has sought expertise outside of Hyrox â€” strength coaches, movement coaches, running coaches, physios, and elite ultrarunners like Tom Evans â€” because he believes "there are no Hyrox experts. You've got to look to other sports, where they've been doing it 40, 50 years" (*Men's Health UK, 2025*).

His approach to Hyrox has evolved significantly. Initially, he focused heavily on running because "there were a lot of professional runners or close-to-professional runners, triathletes and so on, who were coming into the sport and doing really well." After that block, he realized he'd "neglected the strength work," so he pivoted to balance both domains.

He views each Hyrox station **in combination with the subsequent run**: "I always look at the [workout station] and the run as one exercise, so if you're a strength athlete and you're amazing at the sled push, look at your sled push and your running time after as one exercise" (*Men's Health UK*).

---

section: Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist > 2. Weekly Training Structure
content:
Based on Jake Dearden's Myprotein feature ("Full Week of Training as a HYROX Athlete") and his various interviews, his typical weekly structure is:

| Day | AM Session | PM Session |
|---|---|---|
| **Monday** | 5K progression run | Strength workout |
| **Tuesday** | Strength workout | HYROX session (40â€“60 min engine-based workout incorporating Hyrox exercises) |
| **Wednesday** | Row intervals (e.g., 10 Ã— 500m with 2 min rest) | â€” |
| **Thursday** | 10K progression run | Strength workout |
| **Friday** | Rest or active recovery (easy 15K exercise bike, Zone 2) | â€” |
| **Saturday** | Strength workout + team sweat session | â€” |
| **Sunday** | HYROX session: 50-minute AMRAP with running and exercises | â€” |

*(Source: Myprotein article)*

From his YouTube content with Built For Athletes, his training involves approximately **30â€“40 minutes of intense running** with warm-up and cool-down on either side in morning sessions, with evening sessions focused more on "erg work and practice but still at an intensity where I'm getting my heart rate up" (*"How A 26yr Old RedBull Athlete Is Dominating Fitness," YouTube, 2024*).

Key notes from Dearden himself:
- "Some of these sessions take no more than 30 minutes. I rarely, almost never, spend three hours in the gym in one day."
- He has a flexible schedule allowing AM/PM splits, which he acknowledges isn't possible for most people.
- He emphasizes that his plan is **specific to him** and shouldn't be seen as prescriptive for all athletes.

---

section: Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist > 3. Session Design Patterns + Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist > 4. Hyrox-Specific Preparation
content:
Dearden uses a mix of **progression runs, interval work, strength sessions, and HYROX-specific AMRAPs.**

His HYROX sessions are 40â€“60 minute engine-based workouts incorporating Hyrox movements. On Sundays, he does 50-minute AMRAPs that combine running with functional movements.

His rowing intervals follow a classic structure: **10 Ã— 500m with 2 minutes rest** â€” a bread-and-butter erg conditioning protocol.

He favors **threshold running** as a key training modality, with an emphasis on power-to-weight ratio. From the RMR Training Podcast appearance: his threshold training sessions are structured around sustained efforts at specific paces, with the goal of improving lactate threshold and VO2 max.

He uses **accumulation and intensification phases** within his strength training: "This intensification phase which often happens where the reps start to come down, you start to push it a little bit, because you've been on a leash during the accumulation phase" (*YouTube: "Training With 26yr Old RedBull Athlete Jake Dearden," 2025*).

---

Dearden prioritizes Hyrox stations **in order of race importance.** His hierarchy: "Starting off with your SkiErg â€“ that's the most important exercise. If your heart rate skyrockets at the ski and you struggle, that's going to fatigue you for the rest of the race. But if you get fatigued at the burpees [the fourth station], you've had a good first half of the race" (*Men's Health UK*).

He integrates running with station work **only in the final 5â€“6 weeks** before a race. Before that, he separates running and strength: "I usually split up my running and my strength until about five to six weeks out from a race. Then I might swap out a couple of sessions so I'm doing some weights and then going straight into running, to practise running under fatigue. That prepares my body. But I think working on your running separately is going to be much more beneficial than trying to do everything fatigued all the time" (*Men's Health UK*).

---

section: Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist > 5. Periodization & Peaking + Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist > 6. Recovery & Lifestyle
content:
Dearden follows a clear **block periodization model** with three phases, as outlined in his Built For Athletes article:

| Timeframe Before Race | Focus |
|---|---|
| **12+ weeks out** | Building a solid base of fitness (running & ergs), building overall strength, progressing all fitness elements |
| **12â€“6 weeks out** | Add Hyrox-specific exercises, progress to race-day weights, at least 1 Hyrox session per week, focus on muscular endurance and running speed |
| **6â€“1 weeks out** | Very specific Hyrox exercises and quantities mimicking race day, replicate race-day scenarios, practice technique/tactics, increase Hyrox sessions, trial race-day nutrition |
| **Race week** | Deload: reduced intensity and frequency, rest days approaching race day, ensure nutrition/sleep are optimal |

He learned from ultrarunner Tom Evans that "it was all about what you do in the month prior and how that affects your race" (*Men's Health UK*).

---

**Recovery as #1 Rule:** Dearden's biggest lesson came from injury â€” two slipped discs caused by neglecting recovery during his ultramarathon days. "Not prioritising recovery is probably the thing that I regret most" (*Men's Health UK*). He now states that **mobility training is "non-negotiable"** and has called it a "game-changer" in his return to competition (*Wellworthy*).

**Biometric Tracking:** He uses heart rate variability (HRV) and sleep quality data to dictate daily training load. "If the numbers are down, the intensity drops" (*Wellworthy*).

**Nutrition:** Dearden follows a high-protein approach:
- Protein target: **1.7â€“2.2g per kg of bodyweight per day**
- Prioritizes carbohydrates before training (bagels, porridge oats, rice, bananas)
- 80/20 rule: 80% whole foods, 20% flexible
- Includes healthy fats from animal fats and nuts
- Carb-loads the day before a race

**Supplements:** Caffeine (only before midday during training; unrestricted on race day), creatine daily, electrolytes ("non-negotiable"), and has been testing bicarbonate of soda gels as a lactate buffer.

**Post-race:** Always has a protein shake ready immediately after finishing for recovery advantage. Celebrates with a "nice meal" rather than drinking.

---

section: Jake Dearden â€” Elite UK Hyrox Specialist > 7. Unique/Differentiating Methods + Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator
content:
**Station-Run Coupling Framework:** Dearden's perspective of treating each station + the following run as a single exercise unit is a distinctive analytical framework that informs both his training and race pacing.

**Expert Aggregation Model:** Rather than following a single Hyrox coach, he deliberately consults specialists from disparate sports (ultrarunning, strength and conditioning, movement science, physiotherapy) and synthesizes their advice for Hyrox application. He's stated: "Hyrox hasn't been around for very long. Even though there are Hyrox coaches out there, there are no Hyrox experts" (*Men's Health UK*).

**Late-Stage Integration:** His unique periodization approach of keeping running and strength completely separate until the final 5â€“6 weeks before a race, then introducing combined "run under fatigue" sessions, contrasts with many Hyrox coaches who advocate mixed-modal training year-round.

**Mental Performance:** Dearden has worked on managing race-day nerves that previously consumed him for two weeks pre-race. After speaking with a sports psychologist, he adopted the principle: "The race is going to happen no matter what, so there's no point thinking about it two weeks beforehand" (*Men's Health UK*). He now focuses on enjoying the lead-up and only "switching on" on race day.

---

---

**Bio snapshot:** Australian-born, NYC-based professional chef and hybrid athlete. Master's degree in Exercise Science. Former strength and conditioning coach for rugby and AFL athletes. Executive chef at The Osprey (1 Hotel Brooklyn). Author of *Eat Like a Legend*. Partner with Centr (Chris Hemsworth's fitness app). Leadville 100 finisher. Currently chasing a sub-60 Hyrox finish. YouTube series documenting his Hyrox journey (@danchurchillcooks).

---

section: Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator > 1. Training Philosophy & Identity + Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator > 2. Weekly Training Structure
content:
Dan Churchill represents a uniquely **nutrition-first, multisport hybrid** approach to Hyrox. His background bridges exercise science and professional cooking, giving him a perspective that most Hyrox athletes lack.

His core philosophy: "I grew up playing rugby, and our training was intenseâ€”weights, sprints, long efforts, skills. I loved it. Honestly, I loved the training even more than the game. It gave me a solid foundation in programming, which became part of my role as a strength and conditioning coach. I took that philosophy and applied it to the way I now train for Hyrox. It's the same methodology, just refined" (*The Hybrid Letter, 2025*).

Churchill is transparent about **not being a natural speedster:** "I've never seen myself as an elite athlete. I wasn't born with top-end speed, but I've got a great engineâ€”my heart rate and recovery are excellent. Speed, though? Not my strength" (*The Hybrid Letter*). This honesty is central to his content â€” he documents both "the highs and lows of his journey" (*RXR Sports bio*).

His training philosophy prioritizes three pillars in order: **Sleep, nutrition, and hydration â€” "those are my big three"** (*The Hybrid Letter*).

---

Churchill trains **4â€“12 sessions per week** depending on the phase, balancing his training with his career as a chef and content creator. His YouTube series provides windows into his actual training days.

Based on his content and interviews, his typical structure during a Hyrox block includes:
- **AM track workouts** (speed sessions, interval running)
- **Midday weight training sessions**
- **HYROX-specific simulation efforts** focused on maintaining Zone 4 heart rate

From his YouTube series (Episode 8, Italy/NYC, 2025): he describes "incorporating simulation efforts to stay in Zone 4, geared towards Hyrox prep" and "crushing a workout session with the team at Meatpacking Athletic."

Churchill's **7-week training block** for the Chicago Hyrox 2024 was documented in Episode 5 of his YouTube series, where he was chasing a sub-60 Hyrox finish. His entry time started at 1:11, improved to 1:08, and his target for Chicago was between 1:07â€“1:08.

---

section: Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator > 3. Session Design Patterns + Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator > 4. Hyrox-Specific Preparation + Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator > 5. Periodization & Peaking
content:
Churchill uses **performance testing as a training design tool.** In Episode 10 of his YouTube series (February 2025), he underwent: blood work to understand his internal state, a heart rate zone test, and a VO2 max assessment. "The day starts with a speed session, followed by a blood test, weight training, a heart rate & VO2 Max test."

He structures workouts around **heart rate zones**, particularly:
- **Zone 2** for aerobic base building
- **Zone 4** for Hyrox-specific simulation work (threshold intensity)

His approach differs from pure Hyrox athletes because he also trains for other endurance events (Leadville 100, Sydney Marathon), requiring periodization across modalities.

---

Churchill's biggest Hyrox lesson was underestimating the running: "I underestimated the running. It's 70% of the event, and I didn't fully factor in how much it would affect fatigue. Going from a run into burpee broad jumps is a different beast. Even though I'm solid at burpees, that transition was brutal" (*The Hybrid Letter*).

He focuses on **learning to "ride out Zone 4 and get back into rhythm"** â€” the ability to sustain threshold-level effort through station transitions and back into running.

His content with Hunter McIntyre (YouTube Episode 2: "Day In The Life Of A Professional Chef and Hybrid Athlete | Hyrox Training W/ McIntyre") shows him training directly alongside McIntyre, absorbing elite-level Hyrox session design.

---

Churchill structures his Hyrox prep in training blocks. His Chicago 2024 prep was a focused **7-week training block**. For his World Championships qualification (YouTube Episode 1, November 2025), he documented the beginning of a new dedicated prep block.

He has stated that "Leadville last year taught me the value of preparation. It's about putting in the reps and improving 1% every day" (*The Hybrid Letter*). His long-term trajectory shows a deliberate, multi-year build toward his sub-60 goal rather than a single peak cycle.

---

section: Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator > 6. Recovery & Lifestyle + Dan Churchill â€” Chef, Hybrid Athlete, Hyrox Content Creator > 7. Unique/Differentiating Methods
content:
**Nutrition â€” Churchill's Superpower:** As a professional chef with a Master's in Exercise Science, his nutrition approach is arguably the most sophisticated of any Hyrox athlete:
- He focuses on **meal timing** â€” the right macros at the right time relative to training
- Has increased caloric intake after realizing "I used to just eat a banana before trainingâ€”maybe 30 grams of carbsâ€”but I didn't account for how much I was burning, even in Zone 2" (*The Hybrid Letter*)
- Added **fish oil regularly** for omega-3s
- Uses **Complex G1 from BPN** for additional carbs
- Increased **Vitamin D3** (through AG1)
- Reduces dietary fat around workouts for quicker energy access
- Avoids dense protein and high-fat meals within 2 hours of sleep

**Sleep:** Churchill uses a **Whoop strap** and has noted that three months of poor sleep visibly impacted his hormones, Zone 2 heart rate, and recovery. He emphasizes the importance of **REM and deep sleep** specifically, not just time in bed. He recommends finishing eating at least 2 hours before sleep and avoiding insulin-spiking carbs before bed.

**Hydration:** Listed as one of his "big three" alongside sleep and nutrition.

**Supplement Protocol:**
- AG1 (for Vitamin D3 and micronutrients)
- Fish oil (omega-3)
- Complex G1 from BPN (carbohydrate supplement)
- Whoop strap for biometric recovery tracking

---

**Chef-Athlete Dual Identity:** Churchill is the only elite-level Hyrox content creator who is simultaneously a professional chef. His recipe-creation for athletes â€” bridging the gap between nutritionist recommendations and practical cooking â€” is genuinely unique. He created athlete-friendly recipes for rugby players early in his career and applies the same approach to hybrid athletes.

**Micronutrient Focus:** He refers to micronutrients as "the fifth macronutrient" â€” an unusual level of attention to vitamins and minerals among Hyrox athletes who typically focus only on protein, carbs, and fats.

**Science-Backed Content:** His Master's in Exercise Science gives his training and nutrition advice a research foundation that most Hyrox athlete-influencers lack. He writes the *Legendary* newsletter sharing "science-backed, actionable insights on nutrition, performance, and recovery."

**Multi-Endurance Background:** Having completed the Leadville 100 ultramarathon, a Sydney Marathon, and pursuing sub-60 Hyrox simultaneously, Churchill brings a cross-endurance perspective. His aerobic engine is built from ultra-distance work, which he applies to Hyrox's shorter but more intense demands.

**Transparency in the Process:** Churchill documents his blood work, VO2 max testing, and performance metrics publicly. This data-driven transparency â€” including sharing actual numbers and setbacks â€” is more granular than what most Hyrox athletes reveal.

---

---

section: Jason Khalipa â€” CrossFit Games Champion Crossing Into Hyrox
content:
**Bio snapshot:** 2008 CrossFit Games Individual Champion. 3Ã— Team USA CrossFit member. Founder and CEO of NCFIT gyms and TRAIN HARD online training. Author of *As Many Reps As Possible*. Host of the Jason Khalipa Podcast (formerly "Effort Over Everything"). Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu brown belt. Pediatric cancer advocate. Competed in HYROX Dallas Pro Doubles (2024) with partner Gabe Yanez.

---

### 1. Training Philosophy & Identity

Jason Khalipa's training philosophy is defined by what he calls the **AMRAP Mentality** â€” extended beyond the gym into a life philosophy. In his book *As Many Reps As Possible*, he outlines five core principles:

1. **Know your WHY** â€” use your purpose to fuel your effort
2. **Focus on what you can control**
3. **Work hard**
4. **Switch gears** â€” be fully present in each task
5. **Re-evaluate** â€” adjust priorities as life changes

*(Source: Goodreads / Mark Bell's PowerCast #200)*

He's described the AMRAP mentality as: "Taking as many 'reps' as possible of the task in front of you, giving it your best, and then moving on to the next task, and repeat" (*Mark Bell's PowerCast*).

Khalipa's approach to fitness is **pragmatic and time-efficient.** Having transitioned from elite-level CrossFit competition to running businesses, raising a family, and training BJJ, he now prioritizes "protectors and providers" â€” people with limited training hours who need maximum fitness return on investment. His TRAIN HARD platform is built around this ethos.

His first experience with Hyrox was documented in a three-part YouTube series ("Training for HYROX," Novemberâ€“December 2024) where he and Gabe Yanez competed in the Pro Doubles division at HYROX Dallas. The first episode was titled "CrossFit Games Champion **Humbled** By HYROX" â€” indicating the learning curve even for a CrossFit legend.

---

### 2. Weekly Training Structure

Khalipa's current weekly structure (outside of specific Hyrox prep) includes:

| Time Slot | Activity |
|---|---|
| Early AM | Cardio and/or ruck walks |
| Midday | NCFIT workout (NCX track â€” includes strength + WOD) |
| Various (3Ã—/week) | Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu |
| Active recovery | Long walks (daily minimum) |

*(Source: T-Nation AMA, 2024)*

He describes his approach: "I train BJJ 3Ã— a week and do our NCFIT workouts daily. I also typically do early AM cardio and/or ruck walks to start the day. If I feel super fatigued, I'll try and reduce the volume. However, doing nothing isn't something I really ever do. I'll at a minimum go for a long walk" (*T-Nation AMA*).

**During his professional CrossFit career,** his daily structure was more intensive and divided into three distinct blocks:
- **AM:** Cardio
- **Midday:** CrossFit (couplets, triplets, and for-time workouts)
- **Evening:** Stamina building on gymnastic movements (e.g., 10-minute EMOM of 10 strict pull-ups)

*(Source: T-Nation AMA)*

For Hyrox-specific preparation, he worked with legendary endurance coach **Chris

---

section: 1. Rich Froning â€” CrossFit Legend Entering Hyrox > Background & Legacy + 1. Rich Froning â€” CrossFit Legend Entering Hyrox > Hyrox Race Results & Times + 1. Rich Froning â€” CrossFit Legend Entering Hyrox > Rich Froning's "Going Hybrid" Philosophy
content:
Rich Froning Jr. is the most decorated athlete in CrossFit history: 4x individual CrossFit Games champion (2011â€“2014) and 6x team champion with CrossFit Mayhem Freedom. He operates CrossFit Mayhem in Cookeville, Tennessee, runs the Mayhem Athlete online programming platform, and hosts *The Rich Froning Podcast*. His mantraâ€”"Faith. Family. Fitness. Service."â€”frames everything he does.

**Based on all available research data, there is no evidence that Rich Froning has competed in an official Hyrox race as of February 2026.** No Hyrox race results, finish times, or event registrations were found bearing his name. The search results consistently return "Rich Ryan" (an Elite 15 Hyrox athlete and host of the RMR Training Podcast) rather than "Rich Froning."

It is critical for the knowledge base to distinguish between these two athletes:

| Athlete | Sport | Notable Achievement |
|---------|-------|-------------------|
| **Rich Froning** | CrossFit | 4x Individual CrossFit Games Champion |
| **Rich Ryan** | Hyrox | Elite 15 qualifier, Pro PR 54:28, Men's Pro Doubles WR holder (48:31 with Pelayo Menendez) |

While Froning has not competed in Hyrox, his podcast episode **"Going Hybrid & Doing Hard Things" (Episode 069, January 14, 2026)** reveals his current training trajectory and mindset toward hybrid/endurance events:

- **Iron Man Training**: Froning confirmed he has registered for an **Iron Man triathlon in Panama City, FL (November 7, 2026)**. He stated: *"The reason I'm doing this is because it is so far out of my comfort zone of what I want to do or what I want to be, and I need to do that every once in a while."*
- **Running Background**: He admitted he has never officially completed a marathon, though he once ran 26 miles in training approximately 15 years ago and abandoned marathon preparation because *"I was getting really slowâ€¦ I don't want to be that type of athlete."*
- **21-Mile Trail Run**: He and a crew member ran approximately 21 miles on trails with zero training, zero sleep, and in 19Â°F weatherâ€”demonstrating his raw endurance capacity.
- **Training Plan for Iron Man**: He outlined his approach:
  - Swim twice per week (~2,000m each session), ramping up with one longer open-water session
  - Mountain bike through spring (Amarillo race prep), transitioning to road cycling by July/August
  - One metcon per week with running intervals (5â€“8K)
  - One long slow Sunday session
  - Brick workouts (bike-to-run transitions)

*(Source: The Rich Froning Podcast, Episode 069, CrossFit Mayhem YouTube, Jan 14, 2026)*

section: 1. Rich Froning â€” CrossFit Legend Entering Hyrox > Training Philosophy: General Physical Preparedness (GPP) + 1. Rich Froning â€” CrossFit Legend Entering Hyrox > Sample Training Days (Documented)
content:
Froning's training philosophy is rooted in **GPPâ€”General Physical Preparedness**â€”which aligns philosophically (though not specifically) with hybrid/Hyrox training:

| Training Principle | Froning's Approach |
|---|---|
| **Daily Structure** | 3-hour AM session + 2-hour PM session (during competition season) |
| **Weekly Template** | Mon: Squat / Tue: Press / Wed: Deadlift / Thu: Press / Fri: Squat; Cleans and snatches heavy 2x/week each |
| **Programming Style** | "By the seat of my pants"â€”adjusts daily based on feel, intuitive autoregulation |
| **Conditioning Formats** | AMRAPs, EMOMs, For Time, Interval Training |
| **Periodization** | Base Phase (GPP) â†’ Power Phase (Olympic lifts, plyometrics) â†’ Competition/Peaking Phase |
| **Separation of Modalities** | Keeps strength and conditioning workouts separate; does not mix within a session |

*(Sources: allthingsgym.com, hoylesfitness.com, WHOOP interview, Rich Froning Training Program analysis)*

**Day 1:**
- 20 min AirDyne: 30s on / 30s off
- Row 4,500m
- 15 sets EMOM: 3 muscle-ups w/ 20lb vest
- EMOM bench press + power clean ladder to 205lb (reached round 10)
- 3 rounds: handstand walk, double-unders, strict pull-ups, air squats (1 min rest between)
- Power cleans for 25 min: 3 every 30s at 225lb for 5 min

**Day 2:**
- 7 rounds: 7 deadlifts at 275lb + 14 push-ups
- Partner workout: 100 cal Bike Erg / 1,400m Run / 100 cal Bike Erg / 1,400m Run
- 3 rounds (rest 1:1): 3 rope climbs + 21 bench press / 2 rope climbs + 15 bench press / 1 rope climb + 9 bench press (155lb barbell, 30lb backpack rope climb)

*(Source: YouTube "Rich Froning Full Day of Training," allthingsgym.com)*

section: 1. Rich Froning â€” CrossFit Legend Entering Hyrox > Key Insights for the Knowledge Base
content:
1. **Froning has NOT competed in Hyrox**â€”any references to "Rich" in Hyrox contexts likely refer to Rich Ryan.
2. **His GPP background would theoretically translate well** to Hyrox, but he has expressed more interest in Iron Man triathlon and mountain bike racing as his next competitive endeavors.
3. **His training volume (5+ hours/day)** far exceeds what most Hyrox athletes do, but much of it is CrossFit-specific (Olympic lifting, gymnastics).
4. **His self-awareness about running limitations** is instructive: *"I would prefer to do something like Amarillo that sucks still but it's more power output, 30-40 minutes rest for an hour or two."*

---

section: 2. Station-Specific Training Methods (All Elite Athletes) > 2.1 Sled Work (Push & Pull)
content:
#### Rich Ryan â€” The Sled Transformation Blueprint

Rich Ryan went from being "scared of the sleds" to posting the **fastest sled push time at the 2025 Hyrox World Championships**. His protocol is the most comprehensively documented:

**Three Pillars of Sled Training:**

| Pillar | Focus | Example Session |
|--------|-------|-----------------|
| **Strength** | Heavy load, short distance | Heavy sled Ã— 3-4 sets of 25m, 4-6 min rest between |
| **Speed** | Lighter load, fast turnover | Lighter sled Ã— 50m unbroken, focus on foot speed |
| **Lactate Tolerance** | Race-weight load, unbroken efforts | Race-weight sled Ã— 37-50m unbroken at all costs, long rest (4-6 min), repeat |

**Key Programming Details:**
- **Frequency**: 2x per week (previously tried 4x/week, caused lower leg/foot pain)
- **Progression**: Undulated (not linear)â€”rotates between heavy/short, light/fast, and long/grindy
- **Compromised Work**: One session includes sleds loaded at the FRONT of a compromised running workout (e.g., sled push â†’ tempo run), not after long fatigue accumulation
- **Concentric Advantage**: Sled work is almost entirely concentric (no eccentric loading), meaning faster recovery than squats/deadliftsâ€”a major advantage for frequent training

*(Source: John Get Strong podcast interview with Rich Ryan, "No One's Figured Hyrox Out Yet")*

#### Hunter McIntyre â€” EMOM Sled Protocol

Hunter's signature sled approach uses **time-based EMOM formats** rather than set/rep schemes:

- **18-minute EMOM**: Alternating sled push and TRX rows, flowing continuously (no prescribed restâ€”just maintain sustained lactate threshold effort)
- **Sled weight in training**: 425lb (vs. 340lb race weight for men's pro), deliberately overloading
- **Technique**: High-arm position, lean into sled like a rugby scrum, drive through legs
- **Key principle**: *"As soon as lactate starts to formâ€¦ push a little further and stay there. Don't push so far that performance starts to drop. Sustained burning."*

*(Source: Dan Churchill YouTube, "HYROX Training with 3X World Champion Hunter McIntyre in NYC")*

#### Jake Dearden â€” Structured Week-by-Week Sled Progression

Jake Dearden's published 3-week plan provides the most structured sled periodization:

| Week | Sled Push | Sled Pull |
|------|-----------|-----------|
| **Week 1** | 3 Ã— 25m @ Hyrox weight, 1 min rest | 3 Ã— 25m @ Hyrox weight, 1 min rest |
| **Week 2** | 3 rounds: 25m push + 500m run + 25m push, 90s rest | 3 rounds: 25m pull + 500m run + 25m pull, 90s rest |
| **Week 3** | Full 50m sled push in 5-min window (race simulation) | Full 50m sled pull in 5-min window (race simulation) |

*(Source: Tom's Guide / inkl.com, Jake Dearden 3-week Hyrox plan)*

#### Jason Khalipa â€” CrossFitter's Sled Assessment

Khalipa noted from his Pro Doubles experience (1:07:13 finish):
- The sled was *"surprisingly heavyâ€¦ especially on the pull"*
- The **sled pull is the biggest skill** CrossFitters need to practiceâ€”it's not a movement pattern familiar from CrossFit
- His partner Gabe Yanez had to compensate on burpees because Khalipa took on more sled work

*(Source: Hybrid Fitness Media podcast, "Can HYROX and CrossFit Co-Exist?")*

#### Dan Churchill â€” Learning From Hunter

Dan Churchill trained under Hunter's guidance and noted:
- Hunter's sled push cadence was significantly faster
- Hunter's row stroke rate was ~52 RPM vs. Dan's low 40s, with more power per stroke
- Key takeaway: *"Get faster, stronger, and a better engine"*

*(Source: Dan Churchill YouTube, training session with Hunter McIntyre)*

---

section: 2. Station-Specific Training Methods (All Elite Athletes) > 2.2 SkiErg & Rowing
content:
#### Jake Dearden â€” SkiErg Interval Protocol

**Week 1 SkiErg Session:**
- 12 Ã— 250m with 45 seconds rest
- Goal: *"Consistent across all 12 efforts at a tough but repeatable pace"*
- Scale to 8 rounds if accumulated volume is too high

**Week 2 Integration:**
- 3 rounds: 500m Ski Erg + 20m sled push @ Hyrox weight, 90s rest

**Week 3 Race Simulation:**
- 1,000m Ski Erg in a 5-minute window, rest remainder

*(Source: Tom's Guide, Jake Dearden 3-week plan)*

#### Rich Ryan â€” Threshold-Based Erg Training

Rich Ryan's erg approach is driven by his threshold training philosophy:
- SkiErg and RowErg are integrated into **30-minute EMOM sequences** alternating stations every 5 minutes
- Pacing calibrated via **5K erg test** as a threshold baseline
- Key insight: *"The SkiErg matters more than the RowErg on race day"*â€”because heart rate response differs by body position (seated rowing = lower HR due to horizontal leg positioning)
- Common form mistakes addressed on the RMR podcast (damper settings, stroke rate optimization)

*(Source: RMR Training Podcast, "Erg Training for HYROX" episode)*

#### Hunter McIntyre â€” Row/Ski EMOM

**14-Minute EMOM Protocol:**
- 14-minute block on Ski Erg, higher intensity than the 18-min sled block
- "Shorter efforts, higher intensity"â€”fewer total reps, increased power per rep
- Followed by **5 rounds of 20 cal row + 20 burpees in 2-minute windows**

*(Source: Dan Churchill YouTube)*

#### Jason Khalipa / Dan Churchill

No specific SkiErg or rowing protocols were documented for these athletes beyond general race observations. Khalipa acknowledged the erg machines were less of a concern for CrossFit athletes given their familiarity with the equipment.

---

section: 2. Station-Specific Training Methods (All Elite Athletes) > 2.3 Wall Balls
content:
#### Rich Ryan â€” The Definitive Wall Ball Strategy

Rich Ryan produced the most comprehensive wall ball guide in the Hyrox space:

**Set/Rep Strategy:**
- If capable of 50+ unbroken: do the big set first, then manage the remainder
- If not: pick a sustainable number (25, 15, or even 5) and maintain consistent rest intervals throughout all 100 reps
- *"Stay just under your threshold for your high-end ability"*

**Breathing Protocol (Counter-Intuitive):**
- **Exhale on release** (throwing the ball up)
- **Inhale on catch/descent**
- This flips the traditional Valsalva squat breathing patternâ€”allows continuous breathing through the full ROM, improves Oâ‚‚ intake, reduces ventilation rate spikes

**Arm Recovery Technique:**
- After throwing the ball, **drop arms down to sides or swing out** to promote blood flow to shoulders
- Do NOT hold arms overhead waiting for the ball to return
- Catch position: under the chin, not above the head

**Cadence Training:**
- Practice **fast descent** into the squatâ€”drop before the ball arrives
- Build "gears"â€”different speeds you can select during the race

**Mental Visualization:**
- Treats every 10 reps as 100m on a running track
- At 60 reps: *"I just have 40 left, which is like 400m. I will never stop in my last 400."*

**Race Pacing Context:**
- Wall balls are the LAST stationâ€”treat the entire race as setup for a "kick" into wall balls
- *"Give back two minutes on the course of your effort so you can come into wall balls and gain two and a half"*

*(Source: Rich Ryan YouTube, "Proven Wall Ball Strategies for HYROX")*

#### Jake Dearden â€” Volume Progression

| Week | Wall Ball Protocol |
|------|-------------------|
| **Week 1** | 4 sets: 30 wall balls @ Hyrox weight in 3-min windows, max farmers carry in remaining time, 2 min rest |
| **Week 2** | 3 rounds: 50 wall balls + 500m run + 50 wall balls, 90s rest Ã— 3 |
| **Week 3** | 100 wall balls in a 5-minute window (race simulation) |

*(Source: Tom's Guide, Jake Dearden 3-week plan)*

#### Hunter McIntyre â€” Training Overload

Hunter uses **20lb wall balls in training** versus the 14lb competition standard (men's pro uses 9kg/~20lb, open uses 6kg/~14lb), creating an overload effect:
- 15 wall balls per minute in EMOM format combined with toes-to-bar
- Emphasis on not "slogging through slow repetitions" but taking **micro breaks, collecting yourself, then attacking again**

*(Source: YouTube, "HYROX Training: Conditioning")*

#### General Wall Ball Endurance Protocols (From Training Literature)

| Protocol | Structure | Focus |
|----------|-----------|-------|
| **Pyramid** | 10-20-30-20-10 reps, 60s rest between | Variable rep schemes |
| **EMOM** | 15 reps every minute Ã— 10 min | Consistent output under time pressure |
| **Tabata Plus** | 8 Ã— 40s on / 20s off, then 2 min rest, repeat 2-3x | Power endurance |
| **Race Simulation** | 100 for time with planned breaks every 20-25 reps | Race-day pacing |

*(Source: hyroxtrainingplans.com)*

---

section: 2. Station-Specific Training Methods (All Elite Athletes) > 2.4 Burpee Broad Jumps
content:
#### General Elite Protocols

No athlete in the research dataset provided a detailed, proprietary burpee broad jump training protocol. However, structured approaches from training literature include:

**Technique Optimization:**
- **Drop down**: Controlled fall (not slow descent)
- **Push-up**: Chest to floor, explosive push-off
- **Jump**: Arms back for momentum, triple extension, forward lean
- **Landing**: Bent knees, controlled absorption, quick reset

**Training Progressions:**

| Phase | Protocol |
|-------|----------|
| **Week 1-2** | 5Ã—5 burpees + 5Ã—5 broad jumps separately; 3Ã—10 combined at comfortable pace |
| **Week 3-4** | 4 rounds: 10 BBJ + 90s rest; 3Ã—2 min continuous BBJ |
| **Race-Specific** | Distance pyramids: 20mâ†’40mâ†’60mâ†’80mâ†’60mâ†’40mâ†’20m, 60-90s rest |
| **Sprint Intervals** | 8 Ã— 20m BBJ at high intensity, 45s rest |

**Pacing Strategy:**
- Start at 70-80% maximum intensity
- Focus on rhythm and consistent jump distance
- Build intensity in final 20-30% of distance

*(Source: hyroxtrainingplans.com)*

#### Jason Khalipa â€” Race Lesson

Gabe Yanez (Khalipa's doubles partner) went too hard on burpees to compensate for sled fatigue, then paid for it on the subsequent run: *"I did so many burpees and so fast that we came out of that run and I thought our race was overâ€¦ Jason was actually pulling away from me in the run."* The takeaway: going 10-15 seconds faster on a station costs 2+ minutes on the subsequent run.

*(Source: Hybrid Fitness Media podcast)*

---

section: 2. Station-Specific Training Methods (All Elite Athletes) > 2.5 Farmers Carry & Sandbag Lunges + 3. CrossFit-to-Hyrox Translation Guide > 3.1 What CrossFit Skills Transfer Directly
content:
#### Jake Dearden â€” Integrated Carry Training

- **Week 1**: 4 sets of 30 wall balls in 3-min windows, then max distance farmers carry @ Hyrox weight in remaining time (2 min rest)
- **Week 2**: Walking lunges: 3 Ã— 50m @ 1.5Ã— Hyrox weight, 2 min rest (overloaded)
- **Week 3**: Full 200m farmers carry and 100m walking lunge in 5-minute windows

*(Source: Tom's Guide, Jake Dearden 3-week plan)*

#### Rich Ryan â€” Lunge Pain Management

Rich Ryan has acknowledged lunges as his biggest pain point, particularly knee-related discomfort. His approach:
- Extended warm-ups before lunge-heavy sessions
- Knees Over Toes Guy (Ben Patrick) programming for joint resilience
- Work with movement specialist Lawrence Van Lingen in Boulder, CO
- Open-minded exploration of non-traditional rehab/prehab methods

*(Source: John Get Strong podcast interview)*

#### Hunter McIntyre & Others

No detailed farmers carry or sandbag lunge protocols were documented for Hunter McIntyre, Jason Khalipa, or Dan Churchill beyond general race execution observations. Hunter's Men's Health profile confirms the standard distances (200m farmers carry, 100m sandbag lunges) but no specific training protocols were published.

---

Based on insights from Jason Khalipa, Rich Ryan, and Gabe Yanez:

| CrossFit Skill | Hyrox Transfer |
|----------------|----------------|
| **Wall balls** | Direct transferâ€”identical movement (though rep count is higher: 100 in Hyrox) |
| **Sled push** | Partial transferâ€”CrossFit athletes familiar with sled but rarely at Hyrox distances |
| **SkiErg / RowErg** | Direct transferâ€”standard CrossFit equipment |
| **Burpees** | Partial transferâ€”Hyrox adds broad jump component |
| **Mental toughness** | Strong transferâ€”*"Doing hard s*** together"* is CrossFit's DNA |
| **Work capacity** | Strong transferâ€”CrossFitters can sustain high output |
| **Strength base** | Strong transferâ€”generally overqualified for Hyrox loads |

section: 3. CrossFit-to-Hyrox Translation Guide > 3.2 Gaps a Typical CrossFit Athlete Has + 3. CrossFit-to-Hyrox Translation Guide > 3.3 Training Modification Framework
content:
| Gap | Why It Matters |
|-----|---------------|
| **Running volume & aerobic base** | Hyrox involves 8km of running; CrossFit rarely programs runs >1 mile. Khalipa: *"It's a lot of running."* |
| **Pacing discipline** | CrossFit rewards going all-out; Hyrox punishes it. *"You're gonna pay two minutes on the run if you bake yourself on the stations."* (Gabe Yanez) |
| **Sled pull technique** | Not a standard CrossFit movement. Khalipa identified this as the biggest skill gap. |
| **Sustained threshold effort** | CrossFit metcons are 8-20 min; Hyrox races are 55-75+ min. Rich Ryan: *"I was a middle-distance athleteâ€¦ races between 4 and 15 minutes. Moving into a 60+ minute race is a different style of training."* |
| **Transition management** | Running â†’ immediate station work under high HR is a specific skill. *"Transitions are where races are won or lost."* |

**Phase 1: Base Building (Weeks 1-8)**
- Add 3-4 runs per week (2 easy, 1 tempo, 1 interval)
- Build running volume to 25-35km/week
- Introduce sled pull technique work 2x/week
- Maintain 1-2 strength sessions (reduce Olympic lifting volume)

**Phase 2: Hyrox-Specific (Weeks 9-16)**
- 2x threshold sessions per week (40-55 min at low Zone 4)
- 2x station-specific training (sled circuits, wall ball volume, erg intervals)
- 1x compromised running workout (run + station combos)
- 1x long easy run (10-15km)
- Reduce CrossFit metcons to 1x/week

**Phase 3: Race Peak (Weeks 17-20)**
- Race simulations (partial or full)
- Taper volume 20% in final 2 weeks
- Focus on pacing, transitions, and nutrition strategy

section: 3. CrossFit-to-Hyrox Translation Guide > 3.4 Common Mistakes CrossFit Athletes Make in First Hyrox + 3. CrossFit-to-Hyrox Translation Guide > 3.5 Key Quotes for the Knowledge Base
content:
| Mistake | Consequence | Fix |
|---------|-------------|-----|
| **Going out too fast** | Blow up by station 5-6; walk the final runs | Start 10-15s/km slower than threshold pace |
| **Sprinting the sleds** | Legs destroyed for remaining 4-5 runs | Short powerful pushes with quick resets; avoid sprinting |
| **Ignoring running training** | Stations feel manageable but total time balloons | Running is ~45% of total race time; train it proportionally |
| **No transition practice** | 10-20 seconds wasted per transition (80-160s total) | Practice runâ†’station combos weekly: 800m run â†’ sled push â†’ 400m run |
| **Treating it like a metcon** | Unsustainable intensity; catastrophic fade | Hyrox is an endurance event with strength elements, not vice versa |
| **Over-relying on strength** | Wasted energy on stations that don't benefit from maximal effort | Efficiency > intensity on stations; save energy for consistent running |
| **Skipping SkiErg/Row practice** | Poor technique costs 60-90s per station | A skilled rower: ~4:00 for 1,000m; beginner with bad form: ~5:30 |

*(Sources: hyroxdatalab.com, Hybrid Fitness Media podcast, RMR Training Podcast, hyroxtrainingplans.com)*

> **Jason Khalipa**: *"If you come from a CrossFit background, you're not gonna have a problem with any of this stuffâ€¦ the sled's not that heavy. It's the running. It's a lot of running."*

> **Gabe Yanez**: *"If you're a CrossFitter going into it, the stations are not going to be a problem for youâ€”make sure you're pacing the running."*

> **Rich Ryan**: *"If you take a triathlete straight off a triathlon and a CrossFit athlete straight off a competition and make them do a Hyrox, the CrossFitter's probably going to win the first one. But if you train for Hyrox for a year, the triathlete is going to win the next one."*

> **Rich Froning** (on doing hard things outside his comfort zone): *"Nobody does CrossFit anymore. They just run."* (said jokingly about the trend at Mayhem)

> **Hunter McIntyre** (on lactate threshold training): *"When you get to the point where you feel that lactate is starting to form and your muscles are starting to overload, push a little bit further and stay there. Don't push so far that performance starts to drop. Sustained burning."*

---
