section: + 1. RPE-Based Session Modification Rules > 1.1 Pre-Session Readiness Check
content:
Now I have comprehensive research data. Let me compile the complete framework.

---

# HYROX AI Coach: Autoregulation & Adaptive Programming Framework

> **Version:** 2.0 Â· **Effective:** February 2026
> **Purpose:** This document defines every decision rule, threshold, and communication template the AI coach uses to modify the 16-week Hyrox periodization plan in real time. It is the system's adaptive intelligence layerâ€”no rule may output vague language such as "adjust accordingly."

---

Before every session, the AI coach asks the athlete five standardized questions, each scored 1â€“10. The composite **Readiness Score** is the equally weighted average of all five sub-scores, rounded to one decimal place. Research supports multi-dimensional subjective wellness questionnaires as superior predictors of training tolerance compared with objective measures alone (Saw, Main & Gastin, 2016, *BJSM*; Thorpe et al., 2017, *IJSPP*).

| # | Readiness Question | Anchors (1 = worst, 10 = best) |
|---|---|---|
| 1 | **Sleep Quality** â€” "Rate your sleep last night." | 1 = â‰¤4 hrs or constantly waking; 5 = ~6 hrs, average quality; 10 = 8+ hrs, deep, uninterrupted |
| 2 | **Muscle Soreness** â€” "How sore are you right now?" | 1 = severe pain / cannot move freely; 5 = moderate tightness; 10 = no soreness at all |
| 3 | **Motivation** â€” "How eager are you to train today?" | 1 = dreading it; 5 = neutral; 10 = fired up |
| 4 | **Life Stress** â€” "Rate your mental/emotional stress." | 1 = extreme stress/crisis; 5 = manageable; 10 = totally calm |
| 5 | **Nutrition / Hydration** â€” "How well did you eat and hydrate in the past 24 hours?" | 1 = missed meals, dehydrated; 5 = okay; 10 = dialed in |

**Readiness Score = (Q1 + Q2 + Q3 + Q4 + Q5) / 5**

section: 1. RPE-Based Session Modification Rules > 1.2 Readiness Tier Decision Table
content:
| Readiness Score | Tier Label | Session Modification |
|---|---|---|
| **8.0â€“10.0** | ðŸŸ¢ **Green â€” Execute** | Run session exactly as programmed. If athlete has been in Green for 5+ consecutive sessions and RPE stays â‰¤6, flag for potential under-programming (see Rule CR-2). |
| **6.0â€“7.9** | ðŸŸ¡ **Yellow â€” Modify** | Reduce **total volume by 20%** (cut lowest-priority sets/intervals first). Maintain programmed intensity. If the session is HIIT, remove the final 1â€“2 rounds. If the session is strength, drop the last accessory exercise and reduce main-lift sets by 1. If the session is running, shorten distance by 20% but keep target pace. |
| **4.0â€“5.9** | ðŸŸ  **Orange â€” Significant Modification** | Reduce **volume by 40%** AND reduce **intensity by 10â€“15%** (drop pace targets by 10â€“15 sec/km; drop strength loads by 10â€“15%). Convert any HIIT session to a moderate-intensity continuous session (Zone 2 run + bodyweight movement flow for 25â€“35 min). Cap session duration at 40 minutes. |
| **1.0â€“3.9** | ðŸ”´ **Red â€” Recovery Session** | Replace planned session with one of the following: (a) 20-min walk + 15-min mobility/foam rolling, (b) 20-min easy swim or bike at HR <120 bpm + 10-min breathwork/meditation, (c) Full rest day with guided stretching video (15 min). Log as "recovery replacement." Re-assess readiness next day. If athlete scores Red 2+ consecutive days, trigger Overtraining Investigation Protocol (see Rule CR-13). |

section: 1. RPE-Based Session Modification Rules > 1.3 During-Session RPE Monitoring
content:
The AI coach requests RPE checks at three points within each session. RPE is collected on the standard Borg CR-10 scale, validated for both resistance training (Zourdos et al., 2016, *JSCR*) and endurance exercise (Foster et al., 2001, *JSCR*).

#### 1.3.1 Post-Warm-Up Check (after first 8â€“10 minutes)

| Warm-Up RPE | Expected RPE | Action |
|---|---|---|
| â‰¤5 | 3â€“5 | âœ… Proceed as planned. |
| 6 | 3â€“5 | âš ï¸ Note elevated effort. Extend warm-up by 5 min of easy movement. Re-check. If RPE drops to â‰¤5 â†’ proceed. If RPE stays â‰¥6 â†’ downgrade session by one tier (e.g., Green â†’ Yellow modifications). |
| 7+ | 3â€“5 | ðŸ›‘ Downgrade session by **two tiers** (e.g., Green â†’ Orange). If warm-up RPE â‰¥ 8 â†’ convert entire session to recovery (Red tier). Log event and flag for pattern tracking. |

#### 1.3.2 Mid-Session Check (at session midpoint)

| Mid-Session RPE vs. Target | Action |
|---|---|
| Within Â±1 of target | âœ… Continue as planned. |
| 1.5â€“2 points above target | Reduce remaining volume by 25%. Extend rest periods by 30 seconds between sets/intervals. |
| >2 points above target | **End high-intensity work immediately.** Complete 5-min cool-down at RPE â‰¤3. Log as "session cut short â€” elevated RPE." Attribute remaining volume as missed and apply Missed Session Logic (Section 2) at the 1-session level. |
| 2+ points below target | Add 1â€“2 additional rounds/sets (up to 15% extra volume) OR increase pace/load by 5% for remaining work. |

#### 1.3.3 Post-Session RPE (sRPE â€” Session RPE)

Collected 15â€“30 minutes after session completion per Foster et al. (2001) methodology. **sRPE Ã— session duration (min) = session load (AU).**

| Data Point | How It's Used |
|---|---|
| sRPE logged | Stored in 7-day rolling average. Compared to programmed target RPE. |
| sRPE Ã— duration = load (AU) | Acute load (7-day sum) and chronic load (28-day average) tracked. Acute:Chronic Workload Ratio (ACWR) calculated weekly. |
| ACWR 0.8â€“1.3 | âœ… Training load in safe zone (Gabbett, 2016, *BJSM*). |
| ACWR >1.5 | ðŸ›‘ Spike detected â€” reduce next 3 sessions by 20% volume. |
| ACWR <0.7 | âš ï¸ Detraining risk â€” increase next week's volume by 10â€“15%. |

section: 1. RPE-Based Session Modification Rules > 1.4 Cross-Session Adaptation Rules (CR Rules) (part 1/2)
content:
These 18 if/then rules fire automatically based on accumulated session data. Each rule references specific thresholds, session types, and corrective actions.

#### Fatigue & Overload Rules

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-1** | RPE > 8 on 2 consecutive HIIT sessions | Reduce next HIIT session volume by 25% (remove final 2 rounds). Insert 1 additional Zone 2 run (30â€“40 min, RPE 3â€“4) before the next HIIT session. |
| **CR-2** | RPE < 5 on 3 consecutive sessions of any type | Increase intensity by 5â€“10% (add 5â€“10 sec/km to pace targets, or 5â€“10% to strength loads) OR add 1 additional set/round to the next 2 sessions. |
| **CR-3** | RPE â‰¥ 9 on any "easy" session (programmed target RPE â‰¤5) | Flag **overtraining investigation**: prompt athlete for illness symptoms, check 7-day sleep average, review preceding 14-day training load. If sleep avg < 6 hrs â†’ trigger lifestyle intervention (Section 5). If no lifestyle explanation â†’ insert 2 consecutive rest days and reduce following week volume by 30%. |
| **CR-4** | RPE > 8 on 3 out of 4 strength sessions within a 2-week block | Reduce strength training loads by 10% for the next mesocycle. Add 1 extra rest day between strength sessions. If within 4 weeks of competition, convert one strength session per week to strength-endurance (lighter load, higher rep, circuit format). |
| **CR-5** | RPE < 4 on 2 consecutive strength sessions | Increase working loads by 5â€“7.5% on main lifts (squat, deadlift, bench press, overhead press). Keep accessory volumes unchanged. |

#### Running-Specific Rules

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-6** | Running RPE > planned RPE by â‰¥2 points on 2 out of 3 runs in a week | Reduce next week's total running volume by 15â€“20%. Convert 1 interval/tempo run to a Zone 2 easy run. Review shoe condition and check for injury signs. |
| **CR-7** | Running RPE consistently 1â€“2 points below target for â‰¥2 weeks | Advance running pace targets by 5 sec/km. If the athlete is in General Prep, consider moving to Specific Prep running intensities early. |
| **CR-8** | Athlete reports RPE â‰¥ 8 on â‰¥3 of the 8 running segments during a simulation | Identify which running segments (early vs. late) are most affected. If segments 5â€“8 are elevated â†’ increase long-run volume by 10% and add a second Zone 2 run per week. If segments 1â€“3 are elevated â†’ athlete is starting too fast; prescribe pacing drill with negative-split structure. |

#### HIIT & Simulation-Specific Rules

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-9** | Average HIIT sRPE over 4-week block exceeds programmed target by >1 point | Reduce HIIT density: increase work:rest ratio from 1:1 to 1:1.5, or from 1:0.5 to 1:1 for the next 2-week block. Maintain total session duration. |
| **CR-10** | Simulation sRPE â‰¥ 9 AND total sim time is >10% slower than goal pace | Add 1 half-simulation per week (4 stations + 4 Ã— 1 km) at race pace for 3 weeks, focusing on the 4 weakest stations. Reduce full-simulation frequency to every 14 days instead of every 10 days. |
| **CR-11** | Simulation sRPE â‰¤ 6 AND total sim time is within 5% of goal pace | Athlete is ready for progression. Increase simulation specificity: add transition drills (Roxzone efficiency practice), and in the next full sim, attempt a 2â€“3% negative split in running segments. |

#### Deload & Recovery Triggers

section: 1. RPE-Based Session Modification Rules > 1.4 Cross-Session Adaptation Rules (CR Rules) (part 2/2)
content:
#### Deload & Recovery Triggers

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-12** | Average weekly Readiness Score drops below 6.0 for 2 consecutive weeks | Insert an **unscheduled deload week**: reduce all volumes by 40%, reduce all intensities by 15%, replace 1 HIIT session with Zone 2 cardio, add 1 full rest day. Resume normal programming after 7 days if Readiness returns to â‰¥7.0. |
| **CR-13** | Readiness Score â‰¤ 3.9 for 3+ consecutive days | Trigger **Overtraining Investigation Protocol**: (1) Suspend all training for 48 hours. (2) Request physician clearance if illness suspected. (3) On return, apply the "Miss a Full Week" protocol (Section 2.4). (4) Log incident for macro-cycle review. |
| **CR-14** | HRV 7-day rolling average drops >1 SD below personal baseline for â‰¥5 consecutive days (if wearable data available) | Reduce high-intensity sessions by 50% for the following week. Replace with Zone 1â€“2 aerobic work. This aligns with Plews et al. (2013) findings and Kiviniemi et al. (2007, 2010) HRV-guided training research showing improved adaptation when training is reduced during periods of attenuated vagal tone. |

#### Progressive Overload Guards

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **CR-15** | Athlete completes all sessions in a week at programmed volume/intensity with average sRPE â‰¤ programmed target for 3 consecutive weeks | Auto-progress: increase running volume by 5â€“8%, HIIT rounds by 1, or strength loads by 2.5â€“5% in the following week. This aligns with DeLorme's (1946) original progressive overload principles and modern autoregulation research (Greig et al., 2020, *Sports Med*). |
| **CR-16** | Athlete's ACWR exceeds 1.3 for 2 consecutive weeks | Cap the following week's acute load to â‰¤1.2 Ã— chronic load. Achieve this by removing the lowest-priority session of the week. |
| **CR-17** | Readiness Score â‰¥ 8 for 10+ consecutive sessions AND sRPE consistently â‰¤ 5 | Possible under-training. Increase weekly training frequency by 1 session (add a station-specific supplemental session) OR increase session density by 10%. Monitor for 2 weeks. |
| **CR-18** | Post-session RPE deviates from target RPE by >2 points (in either direction) on â‰¥50% of sessions in a 2-week block | Recalibrate athlete's RPE anchoring: provide RPE education refresher, re-assess training zones with a benchmark test. If calibration seems accurate, adjust the entire plan's target RPEs to match athlete's actual response curve. |

---

section: 2. Missed Session Recovery Logic
content:
### 2.1 Session Priority Hierarchy by Training Phase

Every session type carries a priority rank that dictates which sessions to protect when time is limited or sessions are missed.

| Priority | General Prep (Wk 1â€“4) | Specific Prep (Wk 5â€“8) | Competition Prep (Wk 9â€“14) | Taper (Wk 15â€“16) |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| 1 (Must-Do) | Long Run / Zone 2 Run | HIIT (Hyrox-style intervals) | Full/Half Simulation | Short High-Intensity Intervals (â‰¤20 min) |
| 2 | HIIT (general conditioning) | Tempo/Threshold Run | HIIT (race-specific) | Easy Run (20â€“30 min) |
| 3 | Strength (full body) | Strength (functional) | Threshold Running | Mobility / Active Recovery |
| 4 | Mobility / Recovery | Mobility / Recovery | Strength (maintenance) | Everything else is optional |

### 2.2 Missed Session Decision Matrix

| Scenario | Decision Logic |
|---|---|
| **Miss 1 session in a week** | **Do NOT reschedule if it was Priority 3 or 4.** If Priority 1 or 2: compress into an adjacent day by combining it as a reduced-volume add-on (50% of original volume appended as a "bonus block" to the next session, adding â‰¤15 min). Never stack 2 full sessions on the same day. |
| **Miss 2 sessions in a week** | Protect the **top 2 priority sessions** for the current phase. Remove the lowest-priority remaining session. Redistribute: take the most important missed session and insert it at 75% volume on the nearest available day. Accept the second missed session as lost volume â€” do NOT chase it. |
| **Miss 3+ sessions (illness/travel)** | Stop chasing missed volume entirely. Re-enter training using the **Graduated Return Protocol** (Section 2.4). Assess Readiness Score on the first day back. If Readiness â‰¥ 7: resume at 70% of planned volume for 3 days, then 85% for 3 days, then 100%. If Readiness 5â€“6: resume at 50% volume for 4 days, then 70% for 3 days, then 85% for 3 days. |
| **Miss a full week** | Apply the **50/30/20/10 Return Rule** adapted from NSCA/CSCCa consensus guidelines: **Day 1â€“2:** 50% of normal session volume, RPE cap of 5. **Day 3â€“4:** 70% volume, RPE cap of 6. **Day 5â€“7:** 85% volume, RPE cap of 7. **Week 2:** 100% volume. No benchmark testing for â‰¥10 days post-return. This is supported by the graduated return-to-play protocols (Elliott et al., 2020, *BJSM*; NSCA/CSCCa Joint Guidelines). |
| **Miss 2+ weeks (injury/illness)** | Require medical clearance before resuming. On clearance: restart training at the **beginning of the previous mesocycle** at 50% volume. Progress per the 50/30/20/10 rule over 2 weeks. Reassess goal time and potentially extend the 16-week plan by the number of weeks missed. Retest all benchmarks at the 2-week post-return mark. |

### 2.3 "Which Sessions Can I Skip?" Quick Reference

| Session Type | Skip-able? | Consequence of Skipping |
|---|---|---|
| Full Simulation (Competition Prep) | âŒ Never skip | Reschedule within 3 days, even at reduced volume (half-sim) |
| HIIT â€” Race-Specific | âŒ Rarely skip | If must skip, replace with a 30-min threshold run to preserve metabolic stimulus |
| Long Run (>45 min) | âš ï¸ Conditional | Can skip 1 per 3-week block; replace with 2 shorter Zone 2 runs |
| Strength â€” Main Lifts | âš ï¸ Conditional | Can skip if already completed 1 strength session that week |
| Strength â€” Accessories | âœ… Yes | Lowest consequence; absorb into warm-up of next session as activation work |
| Easy Run / Recovery | âœ… Yes | Replace with walking or rest with zero guilt |

---

section: 3. Time-Constrained Session Modifications
content:
When an athlete reports they have less time than the planned session requires, the AI compresses the session according to the **"protect intensity, sacrifice volume"** principle (Helms et al., 2018, *JSCR*; Graham & Cleather, 2019).

### 3.1 Universal Compression Matrix

| Planned Duration | Available Time | Compression Level | General Rule |
|---|---|---|---|
| 60 min | **45 min** (75%) | Moderate | Cut warm-up to 5 min (from 10), cut cool-down to 3 min (from 7â€“10). Remove the lowest-priority element. Keep main set at full intensity and â‰¥75% of prescribed volume. |
| 60 min | **30 min** (50%) | Aggressive | Warm-up = 3 min only (dynamic). Cool-down = walk for 2 min. Execute **only the main set** at full intensity with 60% of prescribed volume. All accessories/supplementary work removed. |
| 60 min | **15 min** (25%) | Emergency Minimum | No formal warm-up (begin at 50% effort, ramp over 2 min). Execute the single highest-priority element at full intensity for the maximum possible work in 10 min. 3-min cool-down walk. Log as "emergency session." |

### 3.2 Compression Rules by Session Type

#### Running Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | Keep main interval/tempo set unchanged. Cut warm-up jog from 10 min to 5 min. Cut cool-down from 10 min to 5 min. Remove any strides/drills. |
| 30 min | 3-min warm-up jog â†’ Execute main set at prescribed intensity (e.g., tempo or intervals) for 22 min â†’ 5-min easy jog cool-down. If tempo run: maintain pace, shorten distance proportionally. |
| 15 min | 2-min build-up jog â†’ 10 min at threshold pace (RPE 7â€“8) â†’ 3-min walk. Preserves top-end aerobic stimulus. |

#### HIIT Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | Keep all prescribed movements. Reduce total rounds by 2 (e.g., 6 rounds â†’ 4 rounds). Maintain prescribed work:rest ratio and intensity. |
| 30 min | Keep the 4 most Hyrox-relevant movements, remove any supplemental/accessory exercises. Perform 3 rounds at prescribed intensity. Rest periods shortened by 15 sec each. |
| 15 min | **"Hyrox Essentials" EMOM:** 10-min EMOM alternating between sled push simulation (30 sec max effort) and wall balls (20 reps) + 5-min cool-down. |

#### Strength Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | Keep all main compound lifts (squat, deadlift, press). Remove all accessories (curls, lateral raises, etc.). Keep programmed sets, reps, and loads for main lifts. |
| 30 min | Select the 2 most relevant main lifts (lower body + upper body). Perform programmed sets and loads. Superset where possible to save time. |
| 15 min | Perform 1 compound lift only (prioritize the weakest pattern). 3 working sets at programmed intensity. Example: 3 Ã— 5 back squat at prescribed load. Done in <12 min. |

#### Simulation Sessions

| Available Time | Modification |
|---|---|
| 45 min (from 60) | **Half-simulation:** 4 Ã— 1 km run + 4 stations. Select the 4 weakest stations based on most recent benchmark data. Execute at full race pace. |
| 30 min | **Quarter-simulation:** 2 Ã— 1 km run + 2 stations (the 2 weakest). Full race effort. Plus 5-min cool-down jog. |
| 15 min | **Single-station drill:** 1 km run at race pace â†’ 1 full station at race effort â†’ 1 km run at race pace. Choose the single weakest station. |

---

section: 4. Performance-Based Plan Adjustments > 4.1 Benchmark Test Schedule + 4. Performance-Based Plan Adjustments > 4.2 Performance-Based Adjustment Rules
content:
The AI coach schedules benchmark tests at the end of every 4-week block (Weeks 4, 8, 12, and 15 for final check).

| Benchmark Test | What It Measures | Protocol |
|---|---|---|
| 5 km Time Trial | Aerobic running fitness | Outdoor or treadmill, best effort, record time and average pace |
| Individual Station Tests | Station-specific performance | Each Hyrox station performed in isolation: SkiErg 1,000 m, Row 1,000 m, Sled Push 50 m, Sled Pull 50 m, Burpee Broad Jumps 80 m, Farmer's Carry 200 m, Lunges 100 m, Wall Balls 100 reps (men) / 100 reps (women). Record time for each. |
| Half Simulation | Race-day readiness | 4 Ã— 1 km run + 4 stations, timed. |
| Full Simulation | Goal pace validation | All 8 Ã— 1 km + 8 stations, timed (every 6â€“8 weeks max). |

| Rule ID | Condition (IF) | Action (THEN) |
|---|---|---|
| **PB-1** | 5 km running pace improves >5% at monthly benchmark | Advance to next phase's running intensity targets immediately. E.g., if in General Prep, adopt Specific Prep pace zones. Recalculate all interval paces based on new benchmark. |
| **PB-2** | 5 km running pace regresses >3% at monthly benchmark | Investigate: check ACWR for overtraining spike, review sleep/stress data. If ACWR >1.4 â†’ insert a deload week. If ACWR normal â†’ add 1 additional easy run per week to build aerobic base. Retest in 2 weeks. |
| **PB-3** | Any individual station time stagnates (â‰¤1% improvement) for 4+ weeks | Add a **targeted station intervention block**: 2 additional station-specific sessions per week for 3 weeks (15â€“20 min each), placed on existing training days as add-ons. Example: if SkiErg stagnates â†’ add 2 Ã— SkiErg-focused sessions (5 Ã— 200 m intervals at RPE 8 with 90-sec rest). |
| **PB-4** | Full simulation time is >15% slower than goal pace | Reassess goal pace â€” it may be unrealistic. If goal remains valid, shift training emphasis: increase simulation frequency to every 10 days, add 1 half-sim per week, and reduce general strength to maintenance (1Ã—/week). |
| **PB-5** | Full simulation time is within 5% of goal pace with 6+ weeks remaining | Athlete is ahead of schedule. Maintain current approach; do not increase training load unnecessarily. Focus remaining weeks on race-day tactics: pacing, transitions, nutrition strategy. Consider targeting a faster goal if athlete is motivated. |
| **PB-6** | One station time is >20% slower than the athlete's tier-adjusted average | Trigger **Station-Specific Intervention** (see Weakness Identification Matrix below). Dedicate 3 supplemental sessions/week to that station for a 3-week block. |
| **PB-7** | Athlete improves by >10% on a previously weak station after intervention | Return station to normal training frequency. Reallocate supplemental time to the next-weakest station or general conditioning. |

section: 4. Performance-Based Plan Adjustments > 4.3 Weakness Identification Matrix
content:
This matrix compares the athlete's individual station times against tier-normative data to compute a **Station Performance Index (SPI)** for each station. SPI = (Athlete's Station Time / Tier Average Station Time) Ã— 100. An SPI of 100 = exactly average for their tier. SPI > 115 = significantly weak. SPI < 90 = relative strength.

**Tier norms** are based on published Hyrox results data and categorized by goal finish time:

| Station | Elite (<70 min) | Competitive (70â€“85 min) | Intermediate (85â€“100 min) | Beginner (100â€“120 min) |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| SkiErg 1,000 m | 3:15 | 3:50 | 4:30 | 5:30 |
| Sled Push 50 m | 1:30 | 2:15 | 3:15 | 4:30 |
| Sled Pull 50 m | 1:20 | 2:00 | 3:00 | 4:15 |
| Burpee Broad Jumps 80 m | 3:00 | 4:00 | 5:30 | 7:00 |
| Row 1,000 m | 3:20 | 3:55 | 4:30 | 5:30 |
| Farmer's Carry 200 m | 1:30 | 2:00 | 2:45 | 3:30 |
| Lunges 100 m | 3:00 | 4:15 | 5:45 | 7:30 |
| Wall Balls 100 reps | 4:00 | 5:30 | 7:00 | 9:00 |

**Interpretation Rules:**

| SPI Range | Classification | AI Coach Action |
|---|---|---|
| SPI < 90 | ðŸŸ¢ Relative Strength | Maintain current training. No extra work needed. |
| SPI 90â€“105 | âšª On Track | Standard programming. |
| SPI 106â€“115 | ðŸŸ¡ Developing Weakness | Add 1 supplemental station drill per week (10â€“15 min). |
| SPI 116â€“130 | ðŸŸ  Significant Weakness | Add 2 supplemental station drills per week. Investigate root cause: is it a strength issue (sled), endurance issue (SkiErg/row), or technique issue (burpee broad jumps, wall balls)? |
| SPI > 130 | ðŸ”´ Critical Weakness | Dedicate 3 sessions/week to this station for 3 weeks. Reduce general strength to maintenance. This station becomes the #1 training priority regardless of phase. |

---

section: 5. Environmental & Lifestyle Adaptation > 5.1 High Stress Week (Work, Life Events) + 5. Environmental & Lifestyle Adaptation > 5.2 Poor Sleep (<6 Hours)
content:
The AI detects this when the "Life Stress" sub-score in the Readiness Check averages â‰¤ 4 over 3+ consecutive days.

| Action | Specification |
|---|---|
| Reduce weekly training volume by **25â€“30%** | Remove the lowest-priority session entirely. Shorten remaining sessions by 15â€“20%. |
| Reduce high-intensity work by **40%** | Convert 1 HIIT session to Zone 2 cardio. Keep 1 quality session (the most important for current phase). |
| Add recovery modalities | Prescribe 10-min post-session breathwork (box breathing: 4-4-4-4 cadence). Recommend magnesium supplementation and sleep hygiene review. |
| Duration | Maintain modifications until Life Stress score returns to â‰¥6 for 2+ consecutive days. |

Detected via Sleep Quality sub-score â‰¤ 4, or direct athlete report.

| Sleep Duration | Session Modification |
|---|---|
| 5â€“6 hours (1 night) | Reduce session intensity by 5â€“10%. Extend warm-up by 5 min. Proceed with caution; monitor mid-session RPE. |
| <5 hours (1 night) | Downgrade session by one Readiness Tier (e.g., Green â†’ Yellow). Cap session RPE at 7. |
| <6 hours for 3+ consecutive nights | Apply Orange-tier modifications to ALL sessions until sleep normalizes. Add 1 rest day. Provide sleep hygiene education: consistent bedtime, no screens 1 hr before bed, cool bedroom (18â€“20Â°C), caffeine cutoff by 1:00 PM. |
| <5 hours for 3+ consecutive nights | Red-tier: recovery sessions only until sleep improves. Investigate underlying cause (stress, medical, schedule). |

section: 5. Environmental & Lifestyle Adaptation > 5.3 Traveling (Limited Equipment)
content:
When the athlete flags travel status, the AI serves one of three **travel workout templates** based on available equipment:

#### Hotel Gym (Treadmill + Dumbbells + Cable Machine)

| Day | Session (30â€“40 min) |
|---|---|
| 1 | Treadmill intervals: 6 Ã— 3 min at threshold pace / 2 min easy. DB lunges 3 Ã— 12/leg. DB farmer's carry 3 Ã— 40 m. |
| 2 | Recovery: 20-min easy treadmill jog + 15-min mobility routine. |
| 3 | DB circuit: 4 rounds of 10 goblet squats, 10 DB push press, 10 DB rows, 15 wall balls (sub: DB thrusters), 200-m treadmill run between rounds. |

#### Bodyweight Only (Hotel Room / Park)

| Day | Session (20â€“30 min) |
|---|---|
| 1 | AMRAP 20 min: 10 burpee broad jumps, 20 air squats, 15 push-ups, 200-m run (or 40 high knees). |
| 2 | 30-min easy run at conversational pace (outdoor or treadmill). |
| 3 | 4 Ã— 4-min Tabata blocks (20 sec work / 10 sec rest): block 1 = jump squats; block 2 = mountain climbers; block 3 = walking lunges; block 4 = burpees. 2-min rest between blocks. |

#### Minimal Equipment (Resistance Band + Jump Rope)

| Day | Session (25â€“35 min) |
|---|---|
| 1 | Jump rope intervals: 8 Ã— 1 min fast / 30 sec rest. Band pull-aparts 3 Ã— 20. Band-resisted squats 3 Ã— 15. Band rows 3 Ã— 15. |
| 2 | 25-min easy run + band-assisted stretching 10 min. |
| 3 | Circuit: 5 rounds of 30-sec jump rope sprint, 10 band-resisted lunges per leg, 10 band push-ups, 15 band rows. 60-sec rest between rounds. |

**Travel rule:** No more than 2 consecutive rest days while traveling. If equipment is zero, at minimum perform 20 min of bodyweight movement daily.

section: 5. Environmental & Lifestyle Adaptation > 5.4 Hot Weather Training (>30Â°C / 86Â°F) + 5. Environmental & Lifestyle Adaptation > 5.5 Altitude Training (>1,500 m / 5,000 ft)
content:
Supported by Periard et al. (2015, *Sports Med*) heat acclimatization guidelines.

| Adjustment | Specification |
|---|---|
| Reduce running pace by **8â€“12%** for the first 5 sessions in heat | Allow cardiac drift without chasing normal pace. RPE should guide effort, not GPS pace. |
| Reduce HIIT volume by **20%** for first week in heat | Add 30-sec additional rest between intervals. |
| Hydration protocol | Pre-session: 500 ml water with electrolytes 2 hrs before. During: 200 ml every 15â€“20 min. Post: 1.5 Ã— body weight lost in fluid. |
| Acclimatization timeline | After 7â€“10 sessions in heat, begin restoring normal pace/volume in 5% increments per session. Full acclimatization expected by 14 sessions (Racinais et al., 2015). |
| RPE recalibration | Expect RPE to be 1â€“2 points higher than normal for same workload in heat. Do NOT adjust target RPE downward â€” use actual RPE to drive autoregulation normally. |

| Altitude | Adjustment |
|---|---|
| 1,500â€“2,000 m | Reduce running pace by 5â€“8%. Reduce HIIT intensity by 10%. Expect RPE +1 for same effort. Allow 3â€“5 days for initial acclimatization. |
| 2,000â€“2,500 m | Reduce running pace by 10â€“15%. Reduce all high-intensity volume by 20%. Increase hydration by 50%. Allow 7â€“10 days for acclimatization. Monitor SpO2 if possible. |
| >2,500 m | Reduce all intensity by 15â€“20%. Limit sessions to 45 min for first 5 days. If SpO2 drops below 88% during exercise â†’ stop and descend. |

section: 5. Environmental & Lifestyle Adaptation > 5.6 Return from Minor Illness Protocol + 6. Communication Templates > Template 1: Elevated RPE Pattern
content:
Based on Elliott et al. (2020, *BJSM*) graduated return-to-play framework and Schwellnus et al. (2016) return-after-infection guidelines. The athlete must be symptom-free for â‰¥48 hours before beginning this protocol.

| Day Post-Clearance | Session |
|---|---|
| Day 1 | 15-min easy walk + 10-min light stretching/mobility. Target RPE â‰¤ 3. |
| Day 2 | 20-min easy jog or bike at HR < Zone 1 ceiling (< 65% max HR). Target RPE â‰¤ 4. |
| Day 3 | 30-min Zone 2 run (RPE 4â€“5). If RPE â‰¥ 6 â†’ return to Day 2 protocol for another day. |
| Day 4 | 40-min session at 60% normal volume and 80% normal intensity. Include light strength (bodyweight or 50% normal loads). |
| Day 5 | 50-min session at 75% normal volume, 90% normal intensity. |
| Day 6 | Resume full programming if Readiness Score â‰¥ 7. If Readiness < 7, repeat Day 5. |

**Hard rule:** If symptoms return at any stage â†’ return to Day 1 and add 48 hours of rest. If fever occurs â†’ medical clearance required before any exercise resumes.

---

> **"I've noticed your RPE has been higher than expected this week.** Your last 3 sessions averaged RPE 8.2 against a target of 6.5. This tells me your body is accumulating more fatigue than planned â€” which is totally normal and happens to every athlete.
>
> **Here's what I'm adjusting:** I'm reducing your HIIT volume by 25% for the next session and swapping Thursday's tempo run for an easy Zone 2 run. This gives your body the recovery signal it needs without losing fitness.
>
> **You're not falling behind.** Strategic pullbacks like this are how the best athletes stay consistent across a 16-week block. We'll reassess at Monday's readiness check."

section: 6. Communication Templates > Template 2: Missed Session Restructure + 6. Communication Templates > Template 3: Station Weakness Detected + 6. Communication Templates > Template 4: Deload Week Prescribed
content:
> **"You missed Tuesday's HIIT session â€” no worries, life happens.** Since we're in Specific Prep, HIIT is our top priority this week. Here's how I've restructured your week:
>
> **Wednesday:** I've added a condensed 30-min HIIT block (4 rounds instead of 6) after your strength session. **Friday:** Stays as planned â€” your long run is still locked in. **Saturday's easy run:** Removed to give you recovery time after the compressed week.
>
> **Net result:** You'll still hit 80% of your planned weekly training stimulus. That's more than enough to keep progressing."

> **"Your sled push time hasn't improved in 3 weeks** â€” you're at 3:45 for 50 m, while your tier target is 3:15. Your other stations have been improving steadily, so this is a specific weak link, not a fitness problem.
>
> **Here's my plan:** I'm adding two 15-min sled-focused sessions per week for the next 3 weeks. These include heavy sled pushes at short distances (3 Ã— 15 m) for power, and full 50 m pushes at race weight for pacing. I've also added hip drive and quad-strengthening work (front squats, split squats).
>
> **Why this works:** Station-specific block training has been shown to produce faster improvements than general conditioning. We'll retest in 3 weeks."

> **"Your body is asking for a recovery week, and I'm listening.** Your readiness scores have averaged 5.8 for the past 14 days, and your session RPEs have been running 1.5 points above target. These are classic signs of accumulated fatigue.
>
> **This week's plan:** All sessions are reduced to 60% of normal volume. Intensity drops by 15%. Wednesday's HIIT becomes a 30-min easy bike or swim. I've added an extra rest day on Friday.
>
> **This isn't a step backward â€” it's a supercompensation opportunity.** Research shows that well-timed deload weeks lead to performance breakthroughs in the following block. You'll come back stronger."

section: 6. Communication Templates > Template 5: Goal Pace Reassessment + 6. Communication Templates > Template 6: Hot Weather Adjustment + 6. Communication Templates > Template 7: Return from Illness
content:
> **"Let's talk about your goal time.** Your last full simulation came in at 1:52:30, and your target is 1:30:00 â€” that's a 25% gap with 8 weeks remaining. While big improvements are possible, closing a gap this large requires us to be realistic.
>
> **My recommendation:** Let's reset your goal to 1:42:00, which represents a strong 10% improvement and keeps you on a sustainable trajectory. If you hit 1:42 ahead of schedule, we'll push further.
>
> **What changes:** I'm shifting your running pace zones to align with a 1:42 finish. I'm also adding a weekly half-sim to build race-specific conditioning faster. Let's crush this new target."

> **"I see you're training in 33Â°C heat this week.** Your pace will naturally feel harder â€” that's not you getting weaker, it's your body redirecting blood to cool itself. It's physiology, not fitness loss.
>
> **Adjustments for this week:** All running paces drop by 10% (your 5:00/km tempo becomes 5:30/km). HIIT rest periods increase by 30 seconds. I need you drinking 500 ml with electrolytes 2 hours before each session and 200 ml every 15 minutes during.
>
> **Good news:** After 7â€“10 sessions in this heat, your body adapts and performance returns to normal. Heat training actually improves blood plasma volume â€” you'll be fitter for it."

> **"Welcome back! I know being sick is frustrating, but rushing back causes more problems than patience does.** Here's your 6-day return protocol:
>
> **Today (Day 1):** 15-min walk + 10-min gentle stretching. That's it. **Tomorrow:** 20-min easy jog, heart rate under 130 bpm. **Days 3â€“6:** Gradual ramp-up to full training.
>
> **The rule:** If at any point you feel worse than the day before, we pause and repeat the previous day's session. No exceptions. I'd rather have you 100% for the final 6 weeks than at 70% for 8 weeks."

section: 6. Communication Templates > Template 8: Positive Progress Acknowledgment + 6. Communication Templates > Template 9: Time-Compressed Session Served + 6. Communication Templates > Template 10: Travel Workout Delivered
content:
> **"Your benchmark results just came in, and they're excellent.** Your 5 km time dropped from 24:30 to 23:15 â€” that's a 5.1% improvement in 4 weeks. Your SkiErg dropped from 4:45 to 4:22. This tells me your aerobic engine is building exactly as planned.
>
> **What this unlocks:** I'm advancing your running intensity targets to Specific Prep levels starting this week. Your interval paces move from 4:50/km to 4:40/km. Everything else stays the same â€” no need to change what's working."

> **"Got it â€” you only have 30 minutes today instead of 60. Here's your compressed session:**
>
> **3-min dynamic warm-up â†’ 22 min of today's main set at full intensity â†’ 5-min cool-down jog.** I've removed the accessories and shortened the warm-up, but the core training stimulus is preserved. Research shows that maintaining intensity with reduced volume still drives adaptation (Helms et al., 2018).
>
> **What you lose:** About 15% of today's training benefit. **What you keep:** 85% of the stimulus, and you stay on track. A 30-min session always beats a skipped session."

> **"I see you're traveling this week. I've built 3 hotel-friendly sessions that require only dumbbells and a treadmill:**
>
> **Session 1 (Mon):** Treadmill intervals + DB lunges + DB carries â€” 35 min. **Session 2 (Wed):** Recovery jog + mobility flow â€” 25 min. **Session 3 (Fri):** DB circuit mimicking Hyrox stations â€” 30 min.
>
> **These sessions maintain your conditioning base without requiring any specialized equipment.** When you're back, we'll slot right back into the normal plan. Travel weeks are maintenance weeks, not growth weeks â€” and that's perfectly fine."

section: 6. Communication Templates > Template 11: Under-Training Flag + 6. Communication Templates > Template 12: ACWR Spike Warning + Appendix A: Research Citations Supporting This Framework
content:
> **"I want to flag something positive: your RPE has been consistently below 5, and your readiness scores have been 8+ for 10 straight sessions.** This means either the training load isn't challenging enough, or you're in a great phase of adaptation.
>
> **Here's what I'm testing:** I'm adding 1 extra round to your next 2 HIIT sessions and bumping your running intervals by 5 sec/km faster. If your RPE stays under 6 after these changes, we'll make a larger adjustment.
>
> **This is a great 'problem' to have.** It means you're adapting faster than projected."

> **"Your training load has spiked over the past 7 days â€” your Acute:Chronic Workload Ratio is at 1.52, which puts you in an elevated injury-risk zone** (safe range is 0.8â€“1.3 per Gabbett, 2016).
>
> **Immediate adjustments:** I'm reducing your next 3 sessions by 20% volume. Tomorrow's HIIT drops from 6 rounds to 5. Thursday's run shortens from 8 km to 6.5 km. This brings your ACWR back to ~1.25 by Sunday.
>
> **This is protective, not punitive.** Load spikes are the #1 predictor of soft-tissue injury. A small pullback now protects weeks of training ahead."

---

| Principle | Key Research |
|---|---|
| RPE-based autoregulation outperforms fixed-load programming | Helms et al. (2018), *JSCR*; Graham & Cleather (2019), *JSCR*; Zourdos et al. (2016), *JSCR*; Greig et al. (2020), *Sports Medicine* |
| HRV-guided training produces superior adaptation with less high-intensity volume | Kiviniemi et al. (2007, 2010), *Eur J Appl Physiol*; Vesterinen et al. (2016), *Med Sci Sports Exerc*; Javaloyes et al. (2018), *IJSPP* |
| ACWR and injury risk monitoring | Gabbett (2016), *BJSM*; Blanch & Gabbett (2016), *BJSM* |
| Subjective wellness questionnaires predict training tolerance | Saw, Main & Gastin (2016), *BJSM*; Thorpe et al. (2017), *IJSPP* |
| Graduated return-to-training after illness/detraining | Elliott et al. (2020), *BJSM*; Schwellnus et al. (2016), *BJSM*; NSCA/CSCCa Joint Consensus Guidelines |
| Autoregulation conceptual framework (Fitness-Fatigue Model) | Greig et al. (2020), *Sports Med*; Banister et al. (1975); Hemingway et al. (2020) |
| Heat acclimatization protocols | PÃ©riard et al. (2015), *Sports Med*; Racinais et al. (2015), Consensus Statement |
| Overtraining detection via HRV patterns | Plews et al. (2012, 2013), *Eur J Appl Physiol* / *Sports Med*; Le Meur et al. (2013), *Med Sci Sports Exerc*; Bellenger et al. (2016), *Sports Med* |

---

section: 2. PGVector Optimization for RAG > 2.1 Chunking Strategies for Coaching/Fitness Content
content:
Hyrox coaching content is heterogeneous: race rules, training plans, exercise technique guides, nutrition advice, pacing tables, and athlete Q&A. A single chunking strategy won't work.

| Content Type | Chunking Strategy | Chunk Size | Overlap | Rationale |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| Training plans (weekly blocks) | **Hierarchical** â€” section â†’ day â†’ exercise | 400â€“600 tokens | 50 tokens | Preserve plan structure; each day is self-contained |
| Exercise technique guides | **Semantic** â€” split on topic shifts | 300â€“500 tokens | 75 tokens | Keep setup, cues, and common mistakes together |
| Race rules / station specs | **Document-based** â€” one chunk per station | 200â€“400 tokens | 0 | Each station is a standalone lookup unit |
| Nutrition / recovery articles | **Recursive character** with paragraph boundaries | 500â€“800 tokens | 100 tokens | Longer narrative; preserve paragraph coherence |
| FAQ / Q&A pairs | **Question-answer pairs** â€” one chunk per pair | 100â€“300 tokens | 0 | Each Q&A is an atomic retrieval unit |
| Pacing tables / data | **Table-aware** â€” keep full table in one chunk | Variable | 0 | Tables lose meaning when split |

**Implementation â€” Python chunking pipeline:**

```python
# chunking.py
from dataclasses import dataclass
from enum import Enum
from typing import List
import tiktoken

class ContentType(Enum):
    TRAINING_PLAN = "training_plan"
    TECHNIQUE_GUIDE = "technique_guide"
    RACE_RULES = "race_rules"
    NUTRITION = "nutrition"
    FAQ = "faq"
    PACING_TABLE = "pacing_table"

@dataclass
class Chunk:
    content: str
    content_type: str
    source_document: str
    section_title: str
    metadata: dict  # e.g., {"station": "sled_push", "division": "open"}
    token_count: int

ENCODING = tiktoken.encoding_for_model("text-embedding-3-small")

def count_tokens(text: str) -> int:
    return len(ENCODING.encode(text))

def recursive_split(
    text: str,
    max_tokens: int = 500,
    overlap_tokens: int = 75,
    separators: list = ["\n\n", "\n", ". ", " "]
) -> List[str]:
    """Recursively split text respecting natural boundaries."""
    if count_tokens(text) <= max_tokens:
        return [text.strip()] if text.strip() else []

    sep = separators[0] if separators else " "
    parts = text.split(sep)

    chunks = []
    current = ""
    for part in parts:
        candidate = current + sep + part if current else part
        if count_tokens(candidate) > max_tokens:
            if current:
                chunks.append(current.strip())
                # Create overlap by keeping tail of current chunk
                overlap_text = _get_tail(current, overlap_tokens)
                current = overlap_text + sep + part if overlap_text else part
            else:
                # Single part exceeds limit; try next separator
                if len(separators) > 1:
                    sub_chunks = recursive_split(part, max_tokens, overlap_tokens, separators[1:])
                    chunks.extend(sub_chunks)
                    current = ""
                else:
                    chunks.append(part[:max_tokens * 4].strip())  # Hard truncate
                    current = ""
        else:
            current = candidate
    if current.strip():
        chunks.append(current.strip())
    return chunks

def _get_tail(text: str, target_tokens: int) -> str:
    """Get the last N tokens of text for overlap."""
    tokens = ENCODING.encode(text)
    if len(tokens) <= target_tokens:
        return text
    return ENCODING.decode(tokens[-target_tokens:])

def chunk_document(
    text: str,
    content_type: ContentType,
    source: str,
    section: str = "",
    metadata: dict = None
) -> List[Chunk]:
    """Route to appropriate chunking strategy based on content type."""
    metadata = metadata or {}
    config = {
        ContentType.TRAINING_PLAN:   {"max_tokens": 500, "overlap": 50},
        ContentType.TECHNIQUE_GUIDE: {"max_tokens": 400, "overlap": 75},
        ContentType.RACE_RULES:      {"max_tokens": 300, "overlap": 0},
        ContentType.NUTRITION:       {"max_tokens": 600, "overlap": 100},
        ContentType.FAQ:             {"max_tokens": 250, "overlap": 0},
        ContentType.PACING_TABLE:    {"max_tokens": 800, "overlap": 0},
    }
    cfg = config[content_type]
    raw_chunks = recursive_split(text, cfg["max_tokens"], cfg["overlap"])

    return [
        Chunk(
            content=c,
            content_type=content_type.value,
            source_document=source,
            section_title=section,
            metadata=metadata,
            token_count=count_tokens(c),
        )
        for c in raw_chunks if c.strip()
    ]
```

**Reference:** Weaviate's chunking strategies guide recommends hierarchical chunking for structured documents and semantic chunking for narrative content ([source](https://weaviate.io/blog/chunking-strategies-for-rag)). Unstructured.io's "by title" strategy preserves section boundaries ([source](https://unstructured.io/blog/chunking-for-rag-best-practices)).

section: 2. PGVector Optimization for RAG > 2.2 Optimal Embedding Dimensions + 2. PGVector Optimization for RAG > 2.3 HNSW vs IVFFlat Index Selection
content:
**Model:** `text-embedding-3-small` supports Matryoshka-style dimension reduction. The native output is **1536 dimensions**, but you can request 256, 512, 1024, or 1536 at generation time.

| Dimensions | Storage/Vector | HNSW Index RAM | Retrieval Quality (MTEB avg) | Recommendation |
|---|---|---|---|---|
| 256 | 1 KB | Low | ~90% of full | Too lossy for nuanced coaching queries |
| 512 | 2 KB | Medium | ~95% of full | Good for high-volume, cost-sensitive |
| **1024** | **4 KB** | **Medium-High** | **~98% of full** | **Best balance for our use case** |
| 1536 | 6 KB | High | 100% (baseline) | Marginal gain over 1024 not worth 50% more storage |

**Recommendation: Use 1024 dimensions.** Fitness coaching queries are domain-specific and nuanced (e.g., "my sled push slows down after station 5" vs "sled push technique"). We need high semantic resolution but can sacrifice the last 2% for a 33% storage reduction. OpenAI's Matryoshka architecture preserves semantic ordering in early dimensions ([source](https://particula.tech/blog/embedding-dimensions-rag-vector-search)).

```python
# Generate embedding with reduced dimensions
import openai

client = openai.OpenAI()

def generate_embedding(text: str, dimensions: int = 1024) -> list[float]:
    response = client.embeddings.create(
        model="text-embedding-3-small",
        input=text,
        dimensions=dimensions
    )
    return response.data[0].embedding
```

| Factor | HNSW | IVFFlat |
|---|---|---|
| **Algorithm** | Graph-based (navigable small world) | Clustering-based (inverted file) |
| **Query Speed** | Faster (especially at high recall) | Slower |
| **Build Time** | Slower (hours for >1M vectors) | Faster |
| **Memory Usage** | High (graph in RAM) | Lower |
| **Recall@10** | 95â€“99% typical | 85â€“95% typical |
| **Data Requirement** | Works on empty tables | Needs representative data first |
| **Update Cost** | Moderate (incremental inserts OK) | Requires periodic `REINDEX` |

**Decision: HNSW for our scale.** We'll have ~10Kâ€“100K chunks (not millions). HNSW gives superior recall without significant memory pressure at this scale. IVFFlat's clustering requires existing data before building indexes and degrades more with data drift â€” problematic as we continuously add coaching content.

```sql
-- HNSW index for cosine distance (matches our embedding pipeline)
CREATE INDEX idx_knowledge_chunks_embedding ON knowledge_chunks
USING hnsw (embedding vector_cosine_ops)
WITH (m = 16, ef_construction = 128);

-- Query-time parameter for recall/speed tradeoff
SET hnsw.ef_search = 100;  -- Higher = better recall, slower
```

**HNSW Parameters Explained:**
- `m = 16`: Number of connections per layer. 16 is the recommended default for 1024-dim vectors. Higher m = better recall but more memory.
- `ef_construction = 128`: Build-time search width. 128 gives good quality without excessive build time.
- `ef_search = 100`: Query-time search width. At our scale, 100 gives >98% recall with sub-10ms latency.

**Reference:** AWS deep dive on pgvector indexing recommends HNSW for datasets under 1M vectors where recall is critical ([source](https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/database/optimize-generative-ai-applications-with-pgvector-indexing-a-deep-dive-into-ivfflat-and-hnsw-techniques/)). Pixion's comparison confirms HNSW is data-agnostic and doesn't require pre-existing data for clustering ([source](https://pixion.co/blog/choosing-your-index-with-pg-vector-flat-vs-hnsw-vs-ivfflat)).

section: 2. PGVector Optimization for RAG > 2.4 Hybrid Search: Semantic + Keyword + Metadata Filtering
content:
Pure semantic search can miss exact terminology (e.g., "SkiErg" vs "ski machine"). Hybrid search with Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF) captures both semantic meaning and exact keyword matches.

**The complete hybrid search function with metadata filtering:**

```sql
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION hybrid_search(
    query_text text,
    query_embedding vector(1024),
    match_count int DEFAULT 10,
    content_type_filter text DEFAULT NULL,
    metadata_filter jsonb DEFAULT NULL,
    full_text_weight float DEFAULT 1.0,
    semantic_weight float DEFAULT 1.5,  -- Slightly favor semantic
    rrf_k int DEFAULT 50
)
RETURNS TABLE (
    id bigint,
    content text,
    content_type text,
    source_document text,
    section_title text,
    metadata jsonb,
    fts_rank bigint,
    semantic_rank bigint,
    rrf_score float
)
LANGUAGE sql STABLE
AS $$
WITH full_text AS (
    SELECT
        kc.id,
        ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
            ORDER BY ts_rank_cd(kc.fts, websearch_to_tsquery('english', query_text)) DESC
        ) AS rank_ix
    FROM knowledge_chunks kc
    WHERE
        kc.fts @@ websearch_to_tsquery('english', query_text)
        AND (content_type_filter IS NULL OR kc.content_type = content_type_filter)
        AND (metadata_filter IS NULL OR kc.metadata @> metadata_filter)
    ORDER BY rank_ix
    LIMIT LEAST(match_count, 30) * 2
),
semantic AS (
    SELECT
        kc.id,
        ROW_NUMBER() OVER (
            ORDER BY kc.embedding <=> query_embedding
        ) AS rank_ix
    FROM knowledge_chunks kc
    WHERE
        (content_type_filter IS NULL OR kc.content_type = content_type_filter)
        AND (metadata_filter IS NULL OR kc.metadata @> metadata_filter)
    ORDER BY rank_ix
    LIMIT LEAST(match_count, 30) * 2
)
SELECT
    kc.id,
    kc.content,
    kc.content_type,
    kc.source_document,
    kc.section_title,
    kc.metadata,
    full_text.rank_ix AS fts_rank,
    semantic.rank_ix AS semantic_rank,
    (
        COALESCE(1.0 / (rrf_k + full_text.rank_ix), 0.0) * full_text_weight +
        COALESCE(1.0 / (rrf_k + semantic.rank_ix), 0.0) * semantic_weight
    ) AS rrf_score
FROM
    full_text
    FULL OUTER JOIN semantic ON full_text.id = semantic.id
    JOIN knowledge_chunks kc ON COALESCE(full_text.id, semantic.id) = kc.id
ORDER BY rrf_score DESC
LIMIT LEAST(match_count, 30);
$$;
```

**Reference:** Supabase's official hybrid search documentation uses the same RRF approach with configurable weights ([source](https://supabase.com/docs/guides/ai/hybrid-search)). Instaclustr's pgvector hybrid search tutorial confirms RRF as the standard fusion method ([source](https://www.instaclustr.com/education/vector-database/pgvector-hybrid-search-benefits-use-cases-and-quick-tutorial/)).

section: 2. PGVector Optimization for RAG > 2.5 Re-ranking Strategies + 2. PGVector Optimization for RAG > 2.6 Context Window Assembly
content:
After initial hybrid retrieval, re-ranking improves precision before feeding context to the LLM. For Phase 1 we use a lightweight approach; Phase 2 adds a cross-encoder.

**Phase 1 â€” Heuristic Re-ranking (no external API):**

```python
def rerank_chunks(chunks: list[dict], query: str, athlete_profile: dict) -> list[dict]:
    """Heuristic re-ranking based on relevance signals."""
    for chunk in chunks:
        score = chunk["rrf_score"]

        # Boost chunks matching athlete's division
        if athlete_profile.get("division") and \
           chunk["metadata"].get("division") == athlete_profile["division"]:
            score *= 1.3

        # Boost chunks matching athlete's weak stations
        weak_stations = athlete_profile.get("weak_stations", [])
        if chunk["metadata"].get("station") in weak_stations:
            score *= 1.25

        # Boost recent content (training plans evolve)
        if chunk["metadata"].get("year", 2024) >= 2025:
            score *= 1.1

        # Penalize very short chunks (likely incomplete context)
        if len(chunk["content"]) < 100:
            score *= 0.7

        chunk["final_score"] = score

    return sorted(chunks, key=lambda x: x["final_score"], reverse=True)
```

**Phase 2 â€” Cross-Encoder Re-ranking** (when you need higher precision):
Use a cross-encoder like `cross-encoder/ms-marco-MiniLM-L-6-v2` run locally or via a lightweight inference endpoint. This scores each (query, chunk) pair directly, giving significantly better ranking than bi-encoder similarity alone.

Kimi K2 Thinking has a **256K context window** â€” enormous, but we shouldn't fill it. More context â‰  better answers. The "lost in the middle" problem means LLMs attend more to the beginning and end of context.

**Token Budget Strategy:**

| Component | Token Budget | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| System prompt | ~800 tokens | Coaching persona + rules |
| Athlete profile | ~300 tokens | Structured summary |
| Conversation memory | ~2,000 tokens | Last 3â€“5 messages + rolling summary |
| Retrieved knowledge | ~3,000â€“5,000 tokens | 6â€“10 re-ranked chunks |
| User's current message | ~200 tokens | Current turn |
| **Reserved for output** | **~4,000 tokens** | Workout plans can be long |
| **Total used** | **~8,300 tokens** | ~3% of 256K window |

We deliberately stay far under the 256K limit. Benefits:
1. **Faster inference** â€” latency scales with input length
2. **Lower cost** â€” input tokens are billed
3. **Better attention** â€” model focuses on what matters
4. **Headroom** â€” long multi-turn conversations can grow

```python
def assemble_context(
    system_prompt: str,
    athlete_profile: dict,
    conversation_history: list[dict],
    retrieved_chunks: list[dict],
    user_message: str,
    max_context_tokens: int = 12_000  # Stay well under 256K
) -> list[dict]:
    """Assemble the final message array for the LLM."""

    messages = []

    # 1. System prompt (always first)
    messages.append({"role": "system", "content": system_prompt})

    # 2. Athlete profile injected as system context
    profile_text = format_athlete_profile(athlete_profile)
    messages.append({
        "role": "system",
        "content": f"## Current Athlete Profile\n{profile_text}"
    })

    # 3. Retrieved knowledge (placed early for attention)
    knowledge_text = format_retrieved_chunks(retrieved_chunks)
    messages.append({
        "role": "system",
        "content": f"## Relevant Coaching Knowledge\n{knowledge_text}"
    })

    # 4. Conversation history (summarized older + recent verbatim)
    for msg in conversation_history:
        messages.append({"role": msg["role"], "content": msg["content"]})

    # 5. Current user message
    messages.append({"role": "user", "content": user_message})

    return messages


def format_athlete_profile(profile: dict) -> str:
    return f"""- Name: {profile['display_name']}
- Division: {profile['division']} ({profile['gender']})
- Experience: {profile['experience_level']}
- Last race time: {profile.get('last_race_time', 'N/A')}
- Goal time: {profile.get('goal_time', 'Not set')}
- Weak stations: {', '.join(profile.get('weak_stations', ['Unknown']))}
- Training days/week: {profile.get('training_days_per_week', 4)}
- Injuries/limitations: {profile.get('injuries', 'None reported')}"""


def format_retrieved_chunks(chunks: list[dict]) -> str:
    formatted = []
    for i, chunk in enumerate(chunks, 1):
        formatted.append(
            f"[Source {i}: {chunk['source_document']} â€” {chunk['section_title']}]\n"
            f"{chunk['content']}\n"
        )
    return "\n---\n".join(formatted)
```

---

section: 3. Supabase Schema & RAG Patterns > 3.1 Complete SQL Schema (part 1/2)
content:
```sql
-- ============================================================
-- Enable required extensions
-- ============================================================
CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS vector WITH SCHEMA extensions;
CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS pg_trgm;   -- For fuzzy text matching

-- ============================================================
-- ATHLETES / PROFILES
-- ============================================================
CREATE TABLE public.athlete_profiles (
    id uuid PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
    user_id uuid NOT NULL REFERENCES auth.users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    display_name text NOT NULL,
    gender text CHECK (gender IN ('male', 'female', 'non_binary')),
    division text NOT NULL DEFAULT 'open'
        CHECK (division IN ('open', 'pro', 'doubles', 'relay')),
    experience_level text DEFAULT 'beginner'
        CHECK (experience_level IN ('beginner', 'intermediate', 'advanced', 'elite')),
    date_of_birth date,
    weight_kg numeric(5,1),
    height_cm numeric(5,1),
    last_race_time interval,          -- e.g., '01:32:15'
    goal_time interval,
    weak_stations text[] DEFAULT '{}', -- e.g., {'sled_push', 'wall_balls'}
    training_days_per_week int DEFAULT 4 CHECK (training_days_per_week BETWEEN 1 AND 7),
    injuries text DEFAULT '',
    preferences jsonb DEFAULT '{}'::jsonb,  -- {"metric": true, "language": "en"}
    created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now(),
    updated_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now(),
    UNIQUE (user_id)
);

CREATE INDEX idx_profiles_user_id ON athlete_profiles(user_id);

-- ============================================================
-- KNOWLEDGE BASE (RAG chunks)
-- ============================================================
CREATE TABLE public.knowledge_chunks (
    id bigint PRIMARY KEY GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY,
    content text NOT NULL,
    content_type text NOT NULL
        CHECK (content_type IN (
            'training_plan', 'technique_guide', 'race_rules',
            'nutrition', 'faq', 'pacing_table', 'general'
        )),
    source_document text NOT NULL,      -- e.g., "hyrox_rulebook_2025.pdf"
    section_title text DEFAULT '',
    metadata jsonb DEFAULT '{}'::jsonb,  -- {"station": "sled_push", "division": "open", "year": 2025}
    token_count int NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
    embedding vector(1024),              -- text-embedding-3-small @ 1024 dims
    fts tsvector GENERATED ALWAYS AS (
        to_tsvector('english', content)
    ) STORED,
    created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
);

-- HNSW index for semantic search (cosine distance)
CREATE INDEX idx_knowledge_embedding_hnsw ON knowledge_chunks
    USING hnsw (embedding vector_cosine_ops)
    WITH (m = 16, ef_construction = 128);

-- GIN index for full-text search
CREATE INDEX idx_knowledge_fts ON knowledge_chunks USING gin(fts);

-- GIN index on JSONB metadata for filtered searches
CREATE INDEX idx_knowledge_metadata ON knowledge_chunks USING gin(metadata jsonb_path_ops);

-- Partial index for content type filtering
CREATE INDEX idx_knowledge_content_type ON knowledge_chunks(content_type);

-- ============================================================
-- CONVERSATION SESSIONS & MESSAGES
-- ============================================================
CREATE TABLE public.conversation_sessions (
    id uuid PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
    user_id uuid NOT NULL REFERENCES auth.users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    title text DEFAULT 'New Conversation',
    summary text DEFAULT '',              -- Rolling summary of conversation
    message_count int DEFAULT 0,
    is_active boolean DEFAULT true,
    created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now(),
    updated_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
);

CREATE INDEX idx_sessions_user_active ON conversation_sessions(user_id, is_active);

CREATE TABLE public.conversation_messages (
    id bigint PRIMARY KEY GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY,
    session_id uuid NOT NULL REFERENCES conversation_sessions(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    user_id uuid NOT NULL REFERENCES auth.users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    role text NOT NULL CHECK (role IN ('user', 'assistant', 'system')),
    content text NOT NULL,
    reasoning_content text,             -- K2 Thinking chain (for debugging/training)
    retrieved_chunk_ids bigint[],       -- Which knowledge chunks were used
    tool_calls jsonb,                   -- If function calling was used
    token_count_input int,
    token_count_output int,
    latency_ms int,
    model_id text DEFAULT 'kimi-k2-instruct-0905',
    created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now(),
    -- Training data quality signals
    user_rating smallint CHECK (user_rating BETWEEN 1 AND 5),
    was_helpful boolean,
    follow_through boolean              -- Did user actually do the workout?
);

CREATE INDEX idx_messages_session ON conversation_messages(session_id, created_at);
CREATE INDEX idx_messages_user ON conversation_messages(user_id, created_at);

-- ============================================================
-- WORKOUT LOGGING
-- ============================================================
CREATE TABLE public.workout_logs (
    id bigint PRIMARY KEY GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY,
    user_id uuid NOT NULL REFERENCES auth.users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    session_id uuid REFERENCES conversation_sessions(id),  -- Which chat generated this
    workout_date date NOT NULL DEFAULT CURRENT_DATE,
    workout_type text NOT NULL
        CHECK (workout_type IN (
            'hyrox_simulation', 'run', 'strength', 'hybrid',
            'skierg', 'row', 'technique', 'recovery', 'race'
        )),
    title text NOT NULL,
    prescribed_plan jsonb NOT NULL,     -- The full workout as structured JSON
    completed boolean DEFAULT false,
    actual_results jsonb DEFAULT '{}'::jsonb,  -- What they actually did
    rpe smallint CHECK (rpe BETWEEN 1 AND 10),  -- Rate of Perceived Exertion
    notes text DEFAULT '',
    duration_minutes int,
    created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
);

section: 3. Supabase Schema & RAG Patterns > 3.1 Complete SQL Schema (part 2/2) + 3. Supabase Schema & RAG Patterns > 3.2 Row Level Security (RLS) Patterns
content:
CREATE INDEX idx_workouts_user_date ON workout_logs(user_id, workout_date DESC);

-- ============================================================
-- RACE RESULTS
-- ============================================================
CREATE TABLE public.race_results (
    id bigint PRIMARY KEY GENERATED ALWAYS AS IDENTITY,
    user_id uuid NOT NULL REFERENCES auth.users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    race_date date NOT NULL,
    location text NOT NULL,
    division text NOT NULL,
    overall_time interval NOT NULL,
    run_splits interval[],              -- Array of 8 run times
    station_times jsonb NOT NULL,       -- {"skierg": "4:32", "sled_push": "2:15", ...}
    overall_rank int,
    division_rank int,
    notes text DEFAULT '',
    created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
);

CREATE INDEX idx_races_user ON race_results(user_id, race_date DESC);

-- ============================================================
-- DOCUMENT UPLOADS (for user-submitted content)
-- ============================================================
CREATE TABLE public.document_uploads (
    id uuid PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
    user_id uuid REFERENCES auth.users(id),  -- NULL for admin-uploaded global content
    file_name text NOT NULL,
    file_path text NOT NULL,                  -- Supabase Storage path
    file_type text NOT NULL,
    processing_status text DEFAULT 'pending'
        CHECK (processing_status IN ('pending', 'processing', 'completed', 'failed')),
    chunk_count int DEFAULT 0,
    created_at timestamptz NOT NULL DEFAULT now()
);
```

```sql
-- Enable RLS on all user-facing tables
ALTER TABLE athlete_profiles ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
ALTER TABLE conversation_sessions ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
ALTER TABLE conversation_messages ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
ALTER TABLE workout_logs ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
ALTER TABLE race_results ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;
ALTER TABLE document_uploads ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;

-- Knowledge chunks: readable by all authenticated users (shared knowledge base)
ALTER TABLE knowledge_chunks ENABLE ROW LEVEL SECURITY;

CREATE POLICY "Knowledge chunks are readable by all authenticated users"
    ON knowledge_chunks FOR SELECT TO authenticated
    USING (true);

CREATE POLICY "Only service role can insert/update/delete knowledge chunks"
    ON knowledge_chunks FOR ALL TO service_role
    USING (true) WITH CHECK (true);

-- Athlete profiles: users can only CRUD their own
CREATE POLICY "Users can view their own profile"
    ON athlete_profiles FOR SELECT TO authenticated
    USING (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()));

CREATE POLICY "Users can update their own profile"
    ON athlete_profiles FOR UPDATE TO authenticated
    USING (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()))
    WITH CHECK (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()));

CREATE POLICY "Users can insert their own profile"
    ON athlete_profiles FOR INSERT TO authenticated
    WITH CHECK (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()));

-- Conversation sessions: users own their sessions
CREATE POLICY "Users can manage their own sessions"
    ON conversation_sessions FOR ALL TO authenticated
    USING (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()))
    WITH CHECK (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()));

-- Messages: users can read their own, insert via edge function
CREATE POLICY "Users can read their own messages"
    ON conversation_messages FOR SELECT TO authenticated
    USING (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()));

CREATE POLICY "Service role can insert messages"
    ON conversation_messages FOR INSERT TO service_role
    WITH CHECK (true);

-- Workout logs: full CRUD for own data
CREATE POLICY "Users manage their own workouts"
    ON workout_logs FOR ALL TO authenticated
    USING (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()))
    WITH CHECK (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()));

-- Race results: same pattern
CREATE POLICY "Users manage their own race results"
    ON race_results FOR ALL TO authenticated
    USING (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()))
    WITH CHECK (user_id = (SELECT auth.uid()));
```

**Reference:** Supabase's RAG with Permissions guide demonstrates this exact pattern â€” RLS on `document_sections` filtered by ownership through a parent `documents` table ([source](https://supabase.com/docs/guides/ai/rag-with-permissions)).

content:
**Step 1: Prepare dataset in JSONL format**

```json
{"messages": [{"role": "system", "content": "You are Coach Rox, an expert Hyrox coach..."}, {"role": "user", "content": "My sled push is really slow. I finished last in my wave at the sled station. What should I focus on?"}, {"role": "assistant", "content": "I hear you â€” the sled push is one of the most technique-dependent stations in Hyrox. Let's break this down...\n\n**Immediate fixes for your next training session:**\n\n1. **Body angle**: Get LOW. Your torso should be at roughly 45Â° to the ground. Most people stand too upright, which means you're pushing against gravity instead of into the sled.\n\n2. **Short, choppy steps**: Think 'quick feet' not long strides. Each step should be a powerful drive, not a lunge.\n\n3. **Hand position**: Arms fully extended, locked out. Push through your shoulders, not your elbows.\n\n**Training prescription for this week:**\nI'd recommend 3 sled sessions:\n- Monday: 6 Ã— 25m heavy sled push (heavier than race weight) with 90s rest\n- Wednesday: 4 Ã— 50m at race weight, focusing purely on body angle\n- Friday: 3 Ã— 50m timed efforts with 3min rest\n\nWhat weight are you currently pushing in training?"}]}
{"messages": [{"role": "system", "content": "You are Coach Rox, an expert Hyrox coach..."}, {"role": "user", "content": "Can you give me a workout for tomorrow? I have about 60 minutes and want to work on my running and wall balls."}, {"role": "assistant", "content": null, "tool_calls": [{"type": "function", "function": {"name": "generate_workout_plan", "arguments": "{\"workout_type\": \"hybrid\", \"title\": \"Run + Wall Ball Combo\", \"duration_minutes\": 60, \"warmup\": [\"5 min easy jog\", \"2 Ã— 10 air squats\", \"2 Ã— 10 wall ball at light weight\", \"Dynamic stretches: leg swings, hip circles\"], \"main_block\": [{\"exercise\": \"Run\", \"sets\": 1, \"reps_or_duration\": \"3 Ã— 1km @ race pace\", \"rest\": \"2 min between\", \"notes\": \"Focus on controlled breathing\"}, {\"exercise\": \"Wall Balls\", \"sets\": 5, \"reps_or_duration\": \"15 reps\", \"load\": \"Race weight (6kg W / 9kg M)\", \"rest\": \"60s\", \"notes\": \"Full squat depth, smooth throw rhythm\"}, {\"exercise\": \"Run + Wall Ball Superset\", \"sets\": 3, \"reps_or_duration\": \"400m run immediately into 15 wall balls\", \"rest\": \"90s\", \"notes\": \"Simulate race transitions\"}], \"cooldown\": [\"5 min easy walk\", \"Quad stretch 30s each side\", \"Shoulder stretch 30s each side\"], \"coaching_notes\": \"The key focus today is the transition from running into wall balls. That's where your heart rate will spike. Practice settling into a rhythm within the first 3 reps.\"}"}}]}]}
```

**Step 2: Upload and fine-tune**

```bash
# Install Fireworks CLI
pip install fireworks-ai

# Create dataset
firectl create dataset hyrox-coaching-v1

# Upload JSONL
firectl upload-dataset hyrox-coaching-v1 ./training_data/coaching_conversations_v1.jsonl

# Launch fine-tuning job
firectl sftj create \
    --base-model accounts/fireworks/models/kimi-k2-instruct-0905 \
    --dataset hyrox-coaching-v1 \
    --output-model hyrox-coach-lora-v1 \
    --epochs 2.0 \
    --lora-rank 16 \
    --learning-rate 0.0001 \
    --wandb-entity my-org \
    --wandb-api-key $WANDB_KEY \
    --wandb-project "hyrox-coach"

# Monitor progress
firectl sftj get hyrox-coaching-v1
```

**Step 3: Deploy**

```bash
# Single LoRA deployment (best performance)
firectl create deployment "accounts/YOUR_ACCOUNT/models/hyrox-coach-lora-v1"

# OR Multi-LoRA for A/B testing (same base model cost)
firectl create deployment \
    "accounts/fireworks/models/kimi-k2-instruct-0905" \
    --enable-addons

firectl load-lora hyrox-coach-lora-v1 --deployment $DEPLOYMENT_ID
firectl load-lora hyrox-coach-lora-v2 --deployment $DEPLOYMENT_ID
```

**Reference:** Fireworks AI SFT docs specify JSONL format with `messages` array, optional `reasoning_content` for thinking models, `weight` fields, and LoRA rank up to 64 ([source](https://docs.fireworks.ai/fine-tuning/fine-tuning-models)). Multi-LoRA deployment serves hundreds of adapters at base model cost ([source](https://docs.fireworks.ai/fine-tuning/deploying-loras)).

section: 5. Coaching Conversation Design + Your Persona + Hyrox Race Format (Your Core Knowledge) + How to Use Retrieved Context
content:
### 5.1 System Prompt Architecture

```python
SYSTEM_PROMPT = """You are **Coach Rox**, an expert Hyrox fitness coach and training advisor. You combine deep knowledge of Hyrox race format, exercise science, and practical coaching experience to help athletes prepare for and improve at Hyrox competitions.

- Encouraging but honest â€” you celebrate progress AND call out when athletes are cutting corners
- You speak like a real coach: direct, clear, sometimes using humor to keep things light
- You never give medical advice; for injuries, always recommend consulting a physiotherapist
- You're obsessed with PACING â€” the #1 mistake in Hyrox is going out too fast

Every Hyrox race = 8 Ã— (1km run + 1 workout station), in this fixed order:
1. SkiErg (1,000m) â†’ upper body endurance
2. Sled Push (50m) â†’ leg drive + technique
3. Sled Pull (50m) â†’ grip + posterior chain
4. Burpee Broad Jumps (80m) â†’ explosive endurance
5. Row (1,000m) â†’ full-body cardio
6. Farmer's Carry (200m) â†’ grip + core stability
7. Sandbag Lunges (100m) â†’ leg endurance + balance
8. Wall Balls (75 reps M / 50 reps F) â†’ full-body finisher

Divisions: Open (standard weights), Pro (heavier), Doubles, Relay.

- The coaching knowledge provided below comes from verified sources (official Hyrox rulebooks, certified coaching programs, sports science research)
- ALWAYS prefer retrieved context over your general knowledge when they conflict
- Cite the source naturally: "According to the Hyrox training guide..." or "Research shows..."
- If the retrieved context doesn't cover the question, say so honestly and answer from your general knowledge with a disclaimer

section: How to Use the Athlete Profile + Structured Outputs
content:
- ALWAYS personalize advice to their division, experience level, weak stations, and goals
- Reference their recent workouts and race results when relevant
- Scale workout prescriptions to their training days/week and current fitness
- Account for any injuries or limitations

- When prescribing workouts, use the generate_workout_plan tool to create structured, loggable plans
- When the athlete shares race results, use log_race_result to record them
- Format workout descriptions clearly with sets, reps, rest periods, and coaching cues
- Include RPE targets (1-10 scale) for intensity guidance

section: Conversation Rules
content:
- Keep responses focused and actionable â€” athletes want to know WHAT to do, not just theory
- Ask clarifying questions before prescribing (e.g., "What equipment do you have access to?")
- Break complex topics into digestible pieces
- Use markdown formatting for readability: bold key terms, use bullet lists for plans
- End coaching responses with a clear next step or question to maintain dialogue
"""
```

### 5.2 Conversation Memory Strategy

Rather than naively stuffing the entire conversation history into context, we use a **tiered memory system**:

```
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                MEMORY ARCHITECTURE                  â”‚
â”‚                                                     â”‚
â”‚  Tier 1: ROLLING SUMMARY (persisted in DB)          â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ Summarized every 10 messages by LLM            â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ Contains: key facts, decisions, preferences    â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ ~200-400 tokens                                â”‚
â”‚  â””â”€â”€ Stored in conversation_sessions.summary        â”‚
â”‚                                                     â”‚
â”‚  Tier 2: RECENT MESSAGES (last 6 messages)          â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ Full verbatim messages                         â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ Preserves exact context of current topic       â”‚
â”‚  â””â”€â”€ ~1000-2000 tokens                              â”‚
â”‚                                                     â”‚
â”‚  Tier 3: ATHLETE PROFILE (always loaded)            â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ Structured data from athlete_profiles table    â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ Updated as we learn new information            â”‚
â”‚  â””â”€â”€ ~300 tokens                                    â”‚
â”‚                                                     â”‚
â”‚  Tier 4: CROSS-SESSION FACTS (future enhancement)   â”‚
â”‚  â”œâ”€â”€ Key facts extracted and persisted separately   â”‚
â”‚  â””â”€â”€ "Athlete prefers morning workouts"             â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
```

**Summarization function (runs every 10 messages):**

```python
async def update_conversation_summary(
    session_id: str,
    existing_summary: str,
    recent_messages: list[dict]
) -> str:
    """Use LLM to update the rolling conversation summary."""
    messages_text = "\n".join(
        f"{m['role'].upper()}: {m['content'][:500]}"  # Truncate long messages
        for m in recent_messages
    )

    summarize_prompt = f"""You are summarizing a coaching conversation for future reference.

EXISTING SUMMARY:
{existing_summary or "No previous summary."}

NEW MESSAGES TO INCORPORATE:
{messages_text}

Create an updated summary that captures:
1. Key athlete information learned (fitness level, preferences, constraints)
2. Training decisions made (what workouts were prescribed, what was agreed upon)
3. Progress discussed (improvements, setbacks, race results)
4. Open items or follow-ups promised

Keep the summary concise (under 300 words). Focus on facts the coach needs to remember."""

    result = coaching_completion(
        messages=[{"role": "user", "content": summarize_prompt}],
        temperature=0.3,
        max_tokens=500,
    )
    return result["content"]
```

### 5.3 Progress Analysis from Logged Data

When the `analyze_progress` tool is called, we query the athlete's data and format it for the LLM:

```python
async def execute_progress_analysis(
    user_id: str, period_days: int, focus_area: str
) -> str:
    """Query workout logs and race results, format for LLM analysis."""
    from datetime import datetime, timedelta

    cutoff = datetime.now() - timedelta(days=period_days)

    # Query workout logs
    workouts = await supabase.from_("workout_logs") \
        .select("*") \
        .eq("user_id", user_id) \
        .gte("workout_date", cutoff.isoformat()) \
        .order("workout_date", desc=True) \
        .execute()

    # Query race results
    races = await supabase.from_("race_results") \
        .select("*") \
        .eq("user_id", user_id) \
        .gte("race_date", cutoff.isoformat()) \
        .execute()

    # Compute summary statistics
    total_workouts = len(workouts.data)
    completed = sum(1 for w in workouts.data if w["completed"])
    completion_rate = (completed / total_workouts * 100) if total_workouts > 0 else 0
    avg_rpe = sum(w["rpe"] for w in workouts.data if w.get("rpe")) / \
              max(1, sum(1 for w in workouts.data if w.get("rpe")))

    workout_types = {}
    for w in workouts.data:
        wt = w["workout_type"]
        workout_types[wt] = workout_types.get(wt, 0) + 1

    analysis_context = f"""## Training Data Analysis ({period_days} days)

**Summary:**
- Total workouts logged: {total_workouts}
- Completed: {completed} ({completion_rate:.0f}%)
- Average RPE: {avg_rpe:.1f}/10
- Workout type distribution: {json.dumps(workout_types)}

**Recent workouts (last 5):**
"""
    for w in workouts.data[:5]:
        analysis_context += f"- {w['workout_date']}: {w['title']} ({w['workout_type']}) "
        analysis_context += f"â€” {'âœ… completed' if w['completed'] else 'âŒ incomplete'}"
        if w.get("rpe"):
            analysis_context += f" â€” RPE {w['rpe']}/10"
        analysis_context += "\n"

    if races.data:
        analysis_context += "\n**Race Results:**\n"
        for r in races.data:
            analysis_context += f"- {r['race_date']} ({r['location']}): {r['overall_time']} "
            analysis_context += f"({r['division']})\n"
            if r.get("station_times"):
                analysis_context += f"  Station times: {json.dumps(r['station_times'])}\n"

    return analysis_context
```
