| During gym (60 min) | Water between sets | 300â€“500 ml |
| 5:00 PM (post-gym) | Rehydrate with fluid + post-workout shake | 500 ml |
| 5:00â€“9:30 PM | Steady sipping with dinner, tapering before bed | 500â€“750 ml |
| **Daily Total** | | **~4.0â€“5.0 L** |

---

| Supplement | What It Does | Dosage | Timing | Evidence | Hyrox Application |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Creatine Monohydrate** | Increases phosphocreatine stores â†’ faster ATP regeneration during high-intensity efforts; supports lean mass gains | Loading: 20 g/day (4 Ã— 5 g) for 5â€“7 days; Maintenance: 3â€“5 g/day (or 0.03 g/kg/day) | Daily with a meal (timing is flexible; consistency matters most) | **Strong** â€” ISSN Position Stand (Kreider et al., 2017); one of the most researched supplements in sports science with >500 peer-reviewed studies | Directly benefits sled push/pull, wall balls, burpee broad jumps, and repeat sprint capacity. Also supports muscle mass during concurrent training. Safe for long-term use. |
| **Caffeine** | Blocks adenosine receptors â†’ reduces perceived exertion and pain; enhances endurance and focus | 3â€“6 mg/kg body weight (250â€“500 mg for 82 kg athlete) | 30â€“60 min before training/competition | **Strong** â€” ISSN Position Stand (Goldstein et al., 2010); AND/DoC/ACSM endorsed | Enhances both the running segments and station performance. Use strategically (not daily at high doses) to prevent habituation, though evidence on habituation's effect is mixed (GonÃ§alves et al., 2017). Reserve highest doses for key sessions and race day. |
| **Vitamin D** | Maintains bone health, immune function, muscle function; deficiency impairs performance and recovery | 1,000â€“4,000 IU/day depending on blood levels; target serum 25(OH)D â‰¥ 40 ng/ml (100 nmol/L) | Daily with a fat-containing meal | **Strong** for deficiency correction â€” NIH ODS; Owens et al., 2018 | Indoor-training athletes and those at northern latitudes are at high risk of deficiency. Get 25(OH)D levels tested. Supplement year-round if below 30 ng/ml. |
| **Protein Powder (Whey/Casein)** | Convenient complete protein source to help meet daily targets; whey is fast-absorbing, casein is slow-absorbing | 20â€“40 g per serving as needed to meet daily protein goals | Post-workout (whey), pre-sleep (casein), or whenever convenient | **Strong** â€” ISSN, 2017; Not superior to whole food protein, but practically useful | A tool, not a requirement. Useful when whole-food meals are impractical (e.g., immediately post-workout). Whey provides ~25% leucine by amino acid weight â€” highest of any protein source. |

section: 3. Evidence-Based Supplements > Tier 2 â€” Moderate Evidence
content:
| Supplement | What It Does | Dosage | Timing | Evidence | Hyrox Application |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Beta-Alanine** | Increases muscle carnosine â†’ buffers hydrogen ions â†’ delays fatigue in 1â€“10 min high-intensity efforts | 3.2â€“6.4 g/day in divided doses (800 mg Ã— 4â€“8 servings) for minimum 4 weeks | Daily with meals (loading effect, not acute) | **Moderate** â€” ISSN Position Stand (Trexler et al., 2015); meta-analysis shows benefit for exercise lasting 60sâ€“10 min | Hyrox stations involve repeated 1â€“3 min high-intensity bouts. Carnosine buffering could meaningfully reduce fatigue during sled work, rowing, and wall balls. Expect tingling (paraesthesia) â€” harmless. Use sustained-release formulations to minimise this. |
| **Sodium Bicarbonate** | Alkaline buffer â†’ enhances disposal of hydrogen ions from high-intensity anaerobic work | 0.2â€“0.3 g/kg, 60â€“120 min before high-intensity sessions | Acute, pre-session (use serially during specific prep phases to test tolerance) | **Moderate** â€” Multiple reviews and meta-analyses; individual responses vary | Could benefit Hyrox race performance (sustained high-intensity for 60â€“90 min). GI distress is the major limitation â€” **must** be trialled extensively in training. Take with carbohydrate-rich food and divide into smaller doses over 60 min. |
| **Beetroot Juice / Nitrates** | Increases nitric oxide â†’ vasodilation â†’ improved oxygen efficiency; reduces Oâ‚‚ cost of submaximal exercise | 6.4â€“12.8 mmol nitrate (typically 500 ml beetroot juice or ~140 ml concentrated shot) | 2â€“3 hours before exercise; or daily for 3â€“7 days prior to competition | **Moderate** â€” AND/DoC/ACSM endorsed; greater benefit in recreational vs elite athletes | May improve running economy during the 8 km of running in Hyrox. Benefit is more likely in sub-elite athletes (which most Hyrox competitors are). May also enhance blood flow to working muscles during station work. |
| **Omega-3 Fatty Acids** | Anti-inflammatory; may support MPS, cardiovascular health, and recovery | 1â€“3 g/day combined EPA + DHA | Daily with meals | **Moderate** â€” Philpott et al., 2019; McGlory et al., 2019 | Supports recovery between high-volume training sessions. May reduce exercise-induced muscle soreness (modest effect). Helps maintain joint health during high-impact running. Choose high-quality, third-party tested products. |

section: 3. Evidence-Based Supplements > Tier 3 â€” Weak or Mixed Evidence
content:
| Supplement | What It Does | Dosage | Timing | Evidence | Verdict |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **BCAAs/EAAs** | Provide branched-chain amino acids for MPS | 10â€“15 g BCAAs or 10â€“15 g EAAs | Pre/during/post training | **Weak** â€” Unnecessary if total daily protein (from complete proteins) is adequate; BCAAs alone cannot maximally stimulate MPS without all EAAs (ISSN, 2017) | **Skip** if eating â‰¥1.6 g/kg protein from complete sources. Only useful in a fasted training scenario or if protein intake is low. EAAs are marginally better than BCAAs if supplementation is warranted. |
| **Collagen Peptides** | May support tendon, ligament, and cartilage health via increased collagen synthesis | 10â€“15 g + 50 mg vitamin C | 30â€“60 min before rehab/prehab exercise | **Weak-to-Moderate** â€” Shaw et al., 2017 (small study); mechanism plausible but large-scale evidence lacking | Potentially useful for **joint health** in a Hyrox athlete doing high-impact running + sled work. Low risk. Consider during phases of increased joint stress or if experiencing tendon issues. Not a performance supplement. |
| **Ashwagandha** | Adaptogen; may reduce cortisol, improve recovery, modestly increase strength and VOâ‚‚max | 300â€“600 mg/day of root extract (KSM-66 or Sensoril) | Daily, any time | **Weak-to-Moderate** â€” Some positive RCTs for strength and VOâ‚‚max (Choudhary et al., 2015; Wankhede et al., 2015), but evidence is limited and effect sizes are small | May provide marginal benefits in stress management during heavy training blocks. Not harmful. Not a priority. |
| **Tart Cherry Juice** | Anti-inflammatory and antioxidant polyphenols; may reduce DOMS and accelerate strength recovery | 30â€“60 ml concentrate or 480 ml juice, twice daily | During heavy training blocks; begin 4â€“5 days before target event | **Weak-to-Moderate** â€” Some positive results for reducing soreness (Bell et al., 2016; Levers et al., 2016), but studies are small with varied protocols | May slightly reduce soreness after particularly demanding sessions. Use judiciously â€” chronic high-dose antioxidant intake may blunt training adaptations (see below). Best reserved for competition week or recovery weeks. |

section: 3. Evidence-Based Supplements > What to AVOID + 4. Sleep Optimisation > 4.1 Duration Targets
content:
| Category | Specifics | Reason |
|---|---|---|
| **High-dose antioxidants (Vitamin C >1,000 mg/day + Vitamin E >400 IU/day)** | These interfere with reactive oxygen species signalling necessary for training adaptation | Paulsen et al. (2014) showed blunted endurance and strength adaptations; recent 2025 study confirmed antioxidant supplementation "counteracts positive muscular adaptations" to sprint interval training. **Do not take mega-dose vitamins C and E during training blocks.** |
| **Testosterone boosters** (Tribulus terrestris, DHEA, D-aspartic acid) | No evidence of efficacy; DHEA is banned by WADA; Tribulus has no effect on testosterone in RCTs | Australian Institute of Sport recommends against. Save your money. |
| **Proprietary "pre-workout" blends** with undisclosed doses | May contain harmful stimulants (DMAA, DMBA); doses of active ingredients often subtherapeutic or excessive | ISSN recommends against proprietary blends. Use individual, evidence-based ingredients at known doses instead. |
| **Fat burners / thermogenics** | Often contain excessive caffeine, synephrine, or other stimulants with poor evidence and cardiovascular risk | Not appropriate for performance athletes. Body composition should be managed through diet and training. |
| **Excessive NSAID use** (ibuprofen, naproxen) as a recovery tool | Chronic NSAID use impairs muscle protein synthesis, tendon healing, and bone remodelling | Limit to acute injury management only, not routine post-training recovery. |

---

For an athlete training 10â€“12 hours/week, the research strongly supports **8â€“10 hours of sleep per night**. The IOC (Reardon et al., 2019) and NCAA position statements define a minimum of 7 hours for adults, but athletes typically require more. The most frequently cited recommendation for sleep extension in athletes is to increase sleep by **46â€“113 minutes** above habitual ~7 hr baselines (meta-analysis by Bonnar et al.; Vitale et al., 2019).

**Quantified performance impacts of insufficient sleep:**

| Sleep Deficit | Performance Impact |
|---|---|
| <6 hours for 1 night | 15 watts reduced power output in cyclists (Mougin et al., 2001); reaction time impaired |
| <7 hours for 1 night | 1.7Ã— increased injury risk in adolescent athletes (Milewski et al., 2014) |
| Chronic ~6.5 hrs (athlete average) | Reduced glycogen restorage, elevated cortisol, increased perceived exertion (Charest & Grandner, 2020) |
| Sleep extension to 10 hrs | Improved sprint times, reaction time, shooting accuracy, and mood in collegiate athletes (Mah et al., 2011) |

section: 4. Sleep Optimisation > 4.2 Sleep Quality Metrics + 4. Sleep Optimisation > 4.3 Evidence-Based Pre-Bed Routine
content:
| Metric | Target | Why It Matters |
|---|---|---|
| Sleep efficiency | >85% (time asleep Ã· time in bed) | Low efficiency indicates fragmented sleep |
| Sleep onset latency | <20 minutes | Indicates appropriate sleep pressure and low hyperarousal |
| Wake after sleep onset (WASO) | <30 minutes total | Excessive waking disrupts deep sleep and REM |
| Deep sleep (SWS) | 15â€“25% of total sleep time | Critical for growth hormone release, muscle repair, glycogen restorage |
| REM sleep | 20â€“25% of total sleep time | Critical for motor learning, memory consolidation, emotional regulation |
| Consistency | Â±30 min bedtime/wake time daily | Irregular schedules disrupt circadian rhythm and reduce sleep efficiency |

1. **Set a consistent sleep/wake schedule** (Â±30 min, even on weekends) â€” this is the single most impactful intervention.
2. **Dim lights 60â€“90 min before bed** â€” reduces cortisol and promotes melatonin secretion.
3. **Avoid screens or use blue-light filtering** from 60 min pre-bed.
4. **Cool the bedroom** to 18â€“20Â°C (65â€“68Â°F) â€” core body temperature drop initiates sleep onset.
5. **Pre-sleep nutrition:** A small casein-rich snack (cottage cheese, Greek yogurt, or casein shake) can support overnight MPS without disrupting sleep. A high-GI carbohydrate at dinner may improve sleep onset latency (Vlahoyiannis et al., 2018).
6. **Magnesium supplementation** (200â€“400 mg magnesium glycinate or threonate) 30â€“60 min before bed may improve subjective sleep quality â€” evidence is moderate (Abbasi et al., 2012).
7. **Caffeine curfew:** Avoid caffeine at least **6 hours before bed** (ideally 8â€“10 hours). Caffeine has a half-life of ~5 hours but high individual variability exists (Drake et al., 2013).

section: 4. Sleep Optimisation > 4.4 Napping + 4. Sleep Optimisation > 4.5 Sleep After PM Training
content:
| Recommendation | Details |
|---|---|
| Ideal nap duration | **20â€“30 min** (power nap) or **90 min** (full sleep cycle) |
| Avoid | 40â€“60 min naps â†’ increased sleep inertia (grogginess on waking) |
| Best timing | Early-to-mid afternoon (1:00â€“3:00 PM) to align with natural circadian dip |
| After poor night | A 20â€“90 min nap can restore performance to baseline levels (PMC10354314) |
| Caution | Napping after 3:00 PM or for >90 min can impair night-time sleep onset |

Athletes who train in the evening frequently report difficulty falling asleep due to elevated core temperature, sympathetic nervous system activation, and elevated cortisol/adrenaline. Practical strategies:

- Allow **â‰¥2â€“3 hours** between high-intensity exercise cessation and bed.
- Use a cool shower (not ice cold â€” comfortably cool) post-workout to accelerate core temperature reduction.
- Keep post-workout nutrition low in caffeine (no pre-workout supplements for PM sessions).
- Use a structured cool-down (10 min easy walking + stretching) to initiate parasympathetic activation.
- Consider relaxation techniques: progressive muscle relaxation, box breathing (4-4-4-4), or guided meditation apps.
- If PM training consistently impairs sleep, consider shifting the hardest sessions to AM/midday when possible.

---

section: 5. Recovery Modalities â€” Evidence Review (part 1/2)
content:
| Modality | Evidence Quality | When to Use | How to Use |
|---|---|---|---|
| **Foam Rolling / Self-Myofascial Release** | **Moderate** â€” Meta-analysis (Wiewelhove et al., 2019) shows small reductions in DOMS and small improvements in sprint performance and flexibility | Daily or post-training; particularly after runs and lower-body sessions | 60â€“120 seconds per muscle group. Slow, sustained pressure on quads, hamstrings, IT band, calves, thoracic spine. Does not "break up" fascia â€” likely works via neurological pain modulation and increased blood flow. |
| **Static Stretching** | **Weak for performance; Moderate for flexibility** â€” Pre-exercise static stretching >60s per muscle can transiently reduce strength/power. No consistent evidence for injury prevention or DOMS reduction. | Post-workout cool-down or evening routine; **not** immediately pre-exercise | 15â€“30 seconds per stretch, 2â€“3 sets. Focus on chronically tight areas (hip flexors, calves, hamstrings). |
| **Dynamic Stretching** | **Strong for warm-up** â€” Improves range of motion, activates neuromuscular pathways, and enhances subsequent performance | Pre-every-session as part of warm-up | 5â€“10 min of movement-specific dynamic stretches: leg swings, walking lunges, arm circles, inchworms, hip circles. |
| **Cold Water Immersion (CWI) / Ice Baths** | **Moderate for acute soreness recovery** â€” Meta-analyses (Moore et al., 2023; Machado et al., 2016) show CWI reduces DOMS and creatine kinase more than passive recovery. **However**, chronic CWI post-resistance training may blunt muscle hypertrophy and strength adaptations (Roberts et al., 2015). | After extremely demanding sessions (race simulations, competition), **not** after regular strength training | 10â€“15 min at 10â€“15Â°C. Use strategically, not habitually. Reserve for competition recovery or when 2 high-intensity sessions occur within 24 hours. Avoid after strength sessions during hypertrophy phases. |
| **Contrast Water Therapy (Hot/Cold)** | **Weak-to-Moderate** â€” May enhance perceived recovery and reduce DOMS versus passive recovery, but evidence is less strong than for CWI alone (Moore et al., 2023) | Can use when ice bath is impractical; good psychological benefit | Alternate 1 min cold (10â€“15Â°C) / 2 min warm (38â€“40Â°C) for 12â€“15 min total, ending on cold. |
| **Sauna / Heat Exposure** | **Moderate for health; Weak for direct performance recovery** â€” Regular sauna use improves cardiovascular health (Laukkanen et al., 2015), may stimulate heat shock proteins, and can enhance plasma volume (heat acclimation). Does not directly reduce DOMS. | 2â€“3 sessions per week; useful as a cardiovascular and relaxation tool, and for heat acclimation if racing in warm conditions | 15â€“20 min at 80â€“100Â°C (traditional Finnish) or 30â€“40 min at 55â€“65Â°C (infrared). Rehydrate aggressively after (500 ml+ fluid with electrolytes). Avoid immediately post-strength training during hypertrophy phases (similar blunting concern as CWI). |
| **Compression Garments** | **Weak-to-Moderate** â€” Systematic review (Engel et al., 2016) found small positive effects on DOMS reduction and perceived recovery. Mechanism likely relates to reduced swelling via compression and improved venous return. | Wear during long travel, overnight post-hard sessions, or during easy recovery days | Graduated compression tights or sleeves (15â€“30 mmHg). Effect size is small but risk/cost is low. Primarily a perceptual/comfort benefit. |
| **Massage / Percussion Devices (Theragun, etc.)** | **Moderate for soreness; Weak for performance recovery** â€” Massage reduces DOMS (Poppendieck et al., 2016 meta-analysis). Percussion devices are less studied but likely provide similar neurological pain modulation as massage/foam rolling. | Post-training or evening recovery routine; targeted on areas of highest soreness or tightness | Massage: 20â€“30 min sessions 1â€“2Ã— per week from a sports therapist. Percussion: 30â€“60 seconds per muscle group at moderate intensity. Avoid directly on joints or bony prominences. |
| **Active Recovery (easy walking, swimming, cycling)** | **Moderate** â€” Low-intensity activity enhances blood flow, promotes psychological recovery, and may slightly accelerate lactate clearance. Does not impair subsequent training if truly low-intensity. | Day after hard sessions; or as a second session on double-training days | 20â€“40 min at â‰¤60% max HR. Walking, easy swimming, or cycling. The session should feel effortless. If heart rate is elevated or if it feels like "work," it's too intense. |

section: 6. Nutrition Periodisation Across the 16-Week Program > Phase 1: General Preparation (Weeks 1â€“4) + 6. Nutrition Periodisation Across the 16-Week Program > Phase 2: Specific Preparation (Weeks 5â€“10)
content:
**Training focus:** Aerobic base building, progressive strength loading, movement quality.

**Nutrition strategy:**
- Calories at **maintenance to slight surplus** (+100â€“200 kcal on training days).
- Carbohydrates: **5â€“7 g/kg/day** â€” adequate to fuel increasing volume without excess.
- Protein: **1.8â€“2.0 g/kg/day** â€” consistent foundation for muscle protein turnover.
- Fat: **1.0â€“1.2 g/kg/day** â€” support hormonal health.
- If body recomposition is a goal, implement the small rest-day deficit here (âˆ’200â€“300 kcal).
- Begin creatine loading (20 g/day Ã— 5â€“7 days, then 5 g/day maintenance).
- Begin beta-alanine loading (3.2â€“6.4 g/day â€” it takes 4+ weeks to saturate muscle carnosine).
- **Practice gut training:** Start trialling intra-workout carbs and race-day nutrition products during long sessions.

---

**Training focus:** Increased HIIT density, Hyrox-specific station work, race-pace running.

**Nutrition strategy:**
- Calories at **maintenance or slight surplus** â€” this is not the time to cut; training demands are peaking.
- Carbohydrates: **6â€“8 g/kg/day** â€” higher to support glycolytic HIIT work and faster glycogen turnover.
- Protein: **2.0â€“2.2 g/kg/day** â€” higher to compensate for increased exercise-induced protein breakdown from concurrent high-intensity work.
- Fat: Minimum **0.8â€“1.0 g/kg/day**.
- Use intra-workout carbs (30â€“60 g/hr) during all sessions exceeding 60 minutes.
- Ensure post-workout recovery nutrition is dialed in: 1.0â€“1.2 g/kg carbs + 0.3 g/kg protein within 2 hours.
- **Discontinue any caloric deficit.** Prioritise fuelling and recovery.
- Omega-3 supplementation (2â€“3 g EPA/DHA daily) to support inflammation management from high training load.

---

section: 6. Nutrition Periodisation Across the 16-Week Program > Phase 3: Competition Preparation (Weeks 11â€“14) + 6. Nutrition Periodisation Across the 16-Week Program > Phase 4: Taper (Weeks 15â€“16)
content:
**Training focus:** Race simulations, pacing practice, maintaining fitness while managing fatigue.

**Nutrition strategy:**
- Calories at **full maintenance** â€” no deficit whatsoever.
- Carbohydrates: **7â€“8 g/kg/day** on high-intensity days; **5â€“6 g/kg** on moderate days.
- Protein: **1.8â€“2.0 g/kg/day** â€” maintenance level.
- Trial and finalise **race-day nutrition plan:** Practice the exact pre-race meal, intra-race carb strategy, and caffeine dose during race simulations.
- Continue creatine and beta-alanine. Begin experimenting with sodium bicarbonate (0.2â€“0.3 g/kg, 90 min pre-session) during high-intensity practice â€” assess GI tolerance.
- Trial beetroot juice (140 ml concentrate or 500 ml juice) 2â€“3 hours before race simulations.

---

**Training focus:** Volume reduction (40â€“60% of peak), maintain intensity, sharpen race-specific speed.

**Nutrition strategy:**

**Week 15 (early taper):**
- Reduce caloric intake proportionally to the **reduced training volume** â€” roughly a 15â€“20% reduction from peak training calories.
- Carbohydrates: **5â€“6 g/kg/day** (reduced from peak).
- Protein: **1.8â€“2.0 g/kg/day** â€” maintain; do not reduce protein during taper.
- Sleep: Prioritise â‰¥9 hours/night. This is the phase where sleep extension provides the greatest performance ROI.
- Continue all supplements at maintenance doses.

**Week 16 (race week):**

| Day | Nutrition Focus |
|---|---|
| **Monâ€“Wed** (Race-4 to Race-2 days) | Begin **carb loading**: 8â€“10 g/kg/day. Reduce fibre and fat to accommodate high carb volume without GI distress. Protein at 1.5â€“1.8 g/kg/day. Choose familiar, easily digestible carb sources: white rice, pasta, bread, pancakes, fruit juice, honey. |
| **Thursday** (Race-1 day) | Continue high-carb intake (8â€“10 g/kg). Final light 20â€“30 min shakeout run. Hydrate well. Include **500 mg sodium** with dinner to optimise fluid retention. Go to bed early. |
| **Friday (Race Day â€” example PM race):** | |
| Breakfast (8:00 AM) | Large high-carb meal: 2â€“3 g/kg. White toast, jam, banana, oats with honey, orange juice. Low fibre, low fat. |
| Lunch/Snack (11:00 AMâ€“12:00 PM) | Moderate meal: 1â€“1.5 g/kg carbs. White rice or pasta, lean protein, minimal fat and fibre. |
| Pre-Race (2â€“3 hrs before start) | Final top-up: 1 g/kg carbs. Energy bar, banana, sports drink. Caffeine (3â€“6 mg/kg) 60 min before start. |
| Intra-Race | This is covered by the existing race-day protocol in the coaching knowledge base. |

---

content:
| Parameter | Daily Target |
|---|---|
| Calories (training day) | 3,700â€“4,100 kcal |
| Calories (rest day) | 2,500â€“2,800 kcal |
| Protein | 148â€“180 g (1.8â€“2.2 g/kg) |
| Carbohydrate (training) | 410â€“656 g (5â€“8 g/kg) |

| Fluid (including exercise) | 4.0â€“5.0+ L/day |
| Sleep | 8â€“10 hours/night |

| Caffeine (training/race) | 250â€“500 mg pre-session |
